Date:  Thu, 05 Jan 2006 08:55:10 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Image: C/2004B1 and NGC 6887
Hi all,

On the 2nd Jan 2006 (from 11:00 until 11:30pm local NZDT) - (UT 2006 January 02, 10:00 - 10:30) I imaged Comet 2004 B1 sitting about 2.5' to the west of mag 12.8 (3.2' x 1.3') galaxy NGC 6887 in Telescopium. Sorry that the image isn't the best as the comet was only about 10 degrees above the SW horizon.

It can be seen at:

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet2004b1&ngc6887-22x1min@800asa-061202-web.jpg

or

http://tinyurl.com/c7uxz

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 05 Jan 2006 00:26:43 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Comet C/2005 E2 - 253 Mathilda - 01042005
Once in a while something really happens to grab your attention. At
the link below
http://www.fototime.com/210B328B8D30A68/orig.gif
is a two frame animation of Comet C/2005 E2. What got me was the
almost mirror object. I reprocessed and combined the images 24x45 and
stacked on the comet. Still looked good so I reprocessed and stacked
on the stars.
http://www.fototime.com/E480275D3BB49F5/orig.jpg
O---------WELL! Would have been nice instead of Mathilda to have a
comet fragment but. Thanks, Mike H. 

Date:  Thu, 05 Jan 2006 14:25:29 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  comet C2005E2
Hi, To this address, http://comete.uai.it/comete/C2005E2_060103.jpg
you can see a photo of the comet C2005E2 with the asteroid Mathilda that crosses the
tail.

best regards

Rolando Ligustri

CAST Observatory 

Date:  Sat, 07 Jan 2006 00:41:24 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  C/2006 A1 (Pojmanski) observation and images
Hi all,

well I just visually observed and imaged newly discovered comet C/2006A1 (Pojmanski). It was easy to spot with my 16" Dob from my dark site - even with the nearly 1/4 Moon in the sky. I think it's brighter than what was suggested. Below is my observation and a webpage URL to images of the comet.

C/2006 A1 (Pojmanski). 2006 January 06 .40 UT: m1 = 10.5, Dia.= 2'.5, DC = 2, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (83x). John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Was easy to spot this (A1) newly discovered comet through my 41cm (16") Dob - even with the 6 day Moon in the evening sky (I have a dark, rural sky). C/2006A1 appears as a diffuse coma with no noticeable central condensation. Used three stars for a mag estimate (s). No evident tail. 29d alt in the SW. Stellar LM =14.3 (scope)].

Images can be seen at:

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_2006a1_pojmanski.htm

or

http://tinyurl.com/dsxl5

For astrometry I took two 1 minute images with my Canon 10D DSLR and the 41cm @ f4.5 an hour apart - one at 0900 UT, the second at 1000 UT (Jan 06, 2006). These images are visible on the above webpage. Based on these images and GUIDE 8.0 software I determined (by comparing the images with the computer screen) that the positions were:

2006 Jan 06 0900UT - RA: 21h 25m 08.32s Dec: -66d 38' 30.8"

2006 Jan 06 1000UT - RA: 21h 25m 02.48s Dec: -66d 37' 35.2"

I realise this isn't as accurate as an astrometric software program but it's the best I can do - I think the positions are pretty close...

It's nice to have a fairly bright comet in the sky again!

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sun, 08 Jan 2006 11:58:48 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  C/2006 A1 Vis Obs and image
Hi all,

observed C/2006 A1 again this morning and took another image... The comet looks SLIGHTLY more condensed than last night (could perhaps be observer error(?)), and slightly brighter.

C/2006 A1 2006 January 07 .56 UT: m1 = 10.2, Dia. = 3'.0, DC = 3, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x). John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [C/2006 A1 easy to see thru the 16" even though it is low down. The coma seems to be slightly more condensed than last night(?) but still appears rather diffuse. No evident tail. 15d alt in the South. No Moon (set), dark rural sky. Stellar LM near comet =15.0 (scope)].

An image of the comet can be seen at:

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2006a1-pojmanski-060107-15x2@4min@800asa-41cm-f4,5-web.jpg

or

http://tinyurl.com/bugrv

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Oops, I should have added that the image was a stack of fifteen taken between Jan 07 12:22 and 13:33 UT (Jan 07.51 - .56 UT Decimal). The FOV is about 35' x 22'. North is up, East is left.

Cheers and my apologies.

John

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sun, 08 Jan 2006 11:12:23 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2006 A1 Vis Obs and image
I agree with John's observations - except for one issue. The level of condensation.

I have looked at the light profile of the comet in my CCD images - using the profiling tool in AstroArt. What this shows is a relatively bright nucleus having a similar brightness distribution to stellar images. And a relatively faint but broad coma. I have no idea what the comet looks like 'visually' (the nuclear magnitude that I have measured is at around 15), but my imaging is consistent with a relatively bright nuclear region of only a few arcsecs diameter, with a broad coma extending to somewhat over 1 arcmin. The following table, at approx 2" intervals across the comet, gives an indication (the distance units are approximately arcsecs)

Dist flux (above nominal background)
-40 ~0
-30 120
-20 220
-18 200
-16 500
-14 450
-12 650
-10 810
-8 1000
-6 1450
-4 2000
-2 3800
0 6300
2 4400
4 2150
6 1200
8 950
10 600
12 450
14 400
16 350
18 200
20 180
30 50
40 ~0

This distribution is inconsistent with a weakly condensed comet. I guess there are two possible explanations. Either I am seeing the nucleus, and the coma is broad with little condensation. Or the comet has a very strong central condensation. I guess time will tell.....

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From: John Drummond
To: CometObs-Yahoo ; CometChasing@yahoogroups.com ; comet images - yahoo
Sent: Sunday, January 08, 2006 9:58 AM

Hi all,

observed C/2006 A1 again this morning and took another image... The comet looks SLIGHTLY more condensed than last night (could perhaps be observer error(?)), and slightly brighter.

C/2006 A1 2006 January 07 .56 UT: m1 = 10.2, Dia. = 3'.0, DC = 3, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x). John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [C/2006 A1 easy to see thru the 16" even though it is low down. The coma seems to be slightly more condensed than last night(?) but still appears rather diffuse. No evident tail. 15d alt in the South. No Moon (set), dark rural sky. Stellar LM near comet =15.0 (scope)].

An image of the comet can be seen at:

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2006a1-pojmanski-060107-15x2@4min@800asa-41cm-f4,5-web.jpg

or

http://tinyurl.com/bugrv

John Drummond

Date:  Sun, 08 Jan 2006 22:50:49 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2006 A1 Vis Obs and image
Hi Dave,

I suspect that the CCD is seeing deeper into the coma's shroud than the
naked eye can - that is, spotting the nucleus. I note that my images also
show a fairly condensed nucleus (but this can be influenced by how I stretch
the image in PS), something that isn't as evident visually. I see that
Alexandre Amorim of Brazil also suggests a coma of 3 - as does another
Australian observer of note.

Cheers

John

----- Original Message -----

Date:  Sat, 14 Jan 2006 12:25:41 +0100
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  comet 29P/Schwassman-Wachmann 1 2004
Hello,

comet image of 29P/Schwassman-Wachmann 1 taken with:
C11 telescope @ Focal length of 1110 mm
RS filter and Genisis KAF 1602E camera
14 x 120 sec by full moon
magn. estimation by photometry with Astroart 3.0 -> 17.01 error: +/- 0.26
image can you see on: http://www.eisystems.be/astronomy/

clear skies and best wishes for 2006!
______________________________________________

Erik Bryssinck - Antares

www.eisystems.be/astronomy/
coordinaten: 4?18.6 E - 51?9.8 N
______________________________________________

Date:  Tue, 17 Jan 2006 12:54:35 -0000
From:  jonesgerainth 
Subject:  Call for images of C/2004 Q2 (Machholz)
Dear All,

Professional observations of Comet C/2004 Q2 (Machholz) were made
during 20:40 - 23:00 UT on January 20, 2005.

To help interpret these observations, we wish to obtain amateur images
of the comet taken within a day on either side of the above period.
Images taken during the observing period itself would be particularly
valuable.

If anyone has suitable images, please get in touch by replying
off-list to this message - we'd be extremely grateful for any help.
The contribution of everyone with whom we collaborate will of course
be acknowledged in any resulting publication.

Many thanks,
Geraint Jones

Max Planck Institute for Solar System Research,
Katlenburg-Lindau,
Germany 

Date:  Sat, 21 Jan 2006 11:52:13 -0000

gets through or not. Have images day before and day after if you
still need them. will keep all contact offline from now. Mike H.---

Date:  Sun, 22 Jan 2006 22:22:02 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  C/2006 A1 Pojmanski and tail
I have uploaded a composite image taken a short time ago (to the photos section of -ml,and files section of -images).
Comet altitude about 18 degrees - and getting very difficult to get a decent long exposure after twilight and before one
or more of - (i) setting behind a tree, (ii) my telescope pointing at a light pole, or (iii) my telescope pointing at
the roof of my observatory.

Anyway - the two exposures are each of 4 mins, with a gap of several minutes between (so while the stars are properly
aligned, there is a small displacement in the tail). I haven't done any field flattening or any processing other than
setting a compatible range. The distance from top to bottom is about 14 arc mins - so the tail is a good 10 arc mins
long - in PA 165. Obviously it is still very faint - I doubt it could be observed visually at the moment....

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

Date:  Sun, 29 Jan 2006 19:37:39 -0000
From:  kometman55 
Subject:  comet 73p
Hi all!

We have uploaded a picture to our website from comet 73p taken last
night. Component C is about 14-15 mag. and component B 17.5-18.0 mag.

http://www.astrostudio.at/Astrofotos/aufnahme.php?a_id=453&page=1&kategorie=&k_id=64

Michael and Gerald

Date:  Wed, 01 Feb 2006 03:00:55 +0000
From:  Stéphane Garro 
Subject:  Ephemeris for 2000 EC98
Hello Dennis,

Le mercredi, 1 fév 2006, à 00:56 Europe/London, Dennis Persyk a écrit :

> Where could I find coordinates for P2000EC98? It is not in
> the "Harvard" ephemerides for SkyMap Pro.
>
> Thanks.
>
Just type 2000 EC98 (but do no enter P/2000 EC98 or C/2000 EC98 ! This
peculiar comet is referenced as a minor planet) in the Minor Planet et
Comet Ephemeris Service :

http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/MPEph/MPEph.html

and you will get orbital elements and an ephemeris for it.

A very beautiful object, Good observations !

Stephane 

Date:  Wed, 01 Feb 2006 22:21:38 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Where are the C/2006 A1 Images?
Greetings.
I am wondering why there are not more images of A1. If anyone (John -
Dave) gets a chance, How bout some new images? Cheers, Mike H. 

Date:  Thu, 02 Feb 2006 09:43:32 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Where are the C/2006 A1 Images?
My problem is my horizon. The comet has now moved to a position where it has set behind a neighbour's tree well before civil twilight - and I can even get images earlier in the twilight for astrometry measurement. So the image I posted the other week showing the tail remains the best by far that are available. I do have a couple of subsequent images - but the quality is much less due to twilight and partial aperture cur-off.

In a couple of weeks, I should be able to get images in the morning sky. But my neighbour has a large tree - much higher than the 17 deg altitude cut-off I have at the evening location. But as soon as I can, you can be assured that I will post some more images.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From: tricks46
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, February 02, 2006 9:21 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Where are the C/2006 A1 Images?

Greetings.
I am wondering why there are not more images of A1. If anyone (John -
Dave) gets a chance, How bout some new images? Cheers, Mike H.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 02 Feb 2006 12:28:47 +0200
From:  Mike Begbie 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Where are the C/2006 A1 Images?
Hi Dave and all

Get out your axe, and do what must be done in the middle of the night! Just
joking! But seriously, a friend of mine Richard Fleet here in Zimbabwe at
the time (left the country now, like most others) did exactly that back in
'86. There was a neighbour's tree that was blocking his view of Halley's
post- perihelion recovery. The neighbour didn't even notice as he had a
virtual forest in his backyard anyway. My friend chose the one tree that
was blocking the specific azimuth and altitude that he had established for
the recovery.

He went and did the "deed" and as a result got the very first visual
post-perihelion observation in the world of Halley on February 15.128 UT
1986.

Terry Lovejoy got it a little later at Feb 15.784 UT and cruised in to third
place...but I don't know whether he had to resort to such extreme methods!
Terry, want to share your recovery observation with us? (Note that in those
days we had to report the time of observation to three decimal places!)

Just thought I would share this little bit of "comet crime" with you and the
ml group!

Regards

Mike
----- Original Message -----
From: "Dave Herald"
To:
Sent: Thursday, February 02, 2006 12:43 AM
Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] Where are the C/2006 A1 Images?

My problem is my horizon. The comet has now moved to a position where it has
set behind a neighbour's tree well before civil twilight - and I can even
get images earlier in the twilight for astrometry measurement. So the image
I posted the other week showing the tail remains the best by far that are
available. I do have a couple of subsequent images - but the quality is much
less due to twilight and partial aperture cur-off.

In a couple of weeks, I should be able to get images in the morning sky. But
my neighbour has a large tree - much higher than the 17 deg altitude cut-off
I have at the evening location. But as soon as I can, you can be assured
that I will post some more images.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia 

Date:  Thu, 02 Feb 2006 22:57:43 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Where are the C/2006 A1 Images?
I would dearly love to cut down the tree! But it is a little complicated. The tree is in actually in a laneway between me and my neighbour. In fact there are three of them close together. The other day, one of them dropped a large branch onto the power line to my house - I was lucky that the line didn't break. Anyway the 'Authorities' have agreed to remove that tree, but not the others. And we have local laws that prevent chopping down trees..... I just need to figure out how to make the other two 'fall over', or otherwise become dangerous to people using the path (without them actually being dangerous)

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

Date:  Thu, 02 Feb 2006 08:39:52 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Where are the C/2006 A1 Images?
I would convince the authorities that all three trees are close relatives and
therefore prone for the same psychological stress disorder that results in
continued property damage. That works for human restraining orders.

Clay

Dr. P. Clay Sherrod

tcworks.net security
and is certified Virus and Spam-free

Date:  Thu, 02 Feb 2006 22:31:02 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Where are the C/2006 A1 Images?
Well if you have trees, you know, you have trees. Sometimes, and I
say sometimes they can be a problem for a while. I remember a couple
of years ago my neighbors house to the S/W was in the way. Jokingly
I ask him to open his front and back door so I could image a comet
through his house that was setting behind his place. He did! The
only think worse than him doing that was me actually trying to look
through his open doors!. My wife told me that sometimes you have
just got to draw the line somewhere and I had ought to
apologise. Mike

Date:  Fri, 03 Feb 2006 16:20:31 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Where are the C/2006 A1 Images?
Hi Mike,

I agree, where are my images? My problems are that I had to give a number of
papers at an astronomy conference and needed to get some urgent images done
for the talks. Also, a NZ publishing company is wanting some images of a
certain object by a certain date for a book. And then to really top it off,
my father died a few days ago. Hopefully things will settle down over the
next few days - but, sadly, they won't be as they used to be, with no 'dad'
to chat to anymore...

Cheers

John Drummond
NZ

From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Where are the C/2006 A1 Images?
No problem Mike. I'm very keen to get out there to image/observe A1 again as
soon as this current cloud passes (tomorrow?). I know dad would have wanted
me to get out there under the stars/comets also.

Cheers

John Drummond
NZ

2006 02 03 22h48m-23h28mUT

Date:  Tue, 07 Feb 2006 05:55:33 -0600
From:  Doug Durig 
Subject:  Confirming Comet Comas Sola at 16-17 mag !!!
Here is what I got Tuesday morning on this comet after the notice of outburst:

COD 850
OBS D. T. Durig
MEA D. T. Durig
TEL 0.30-m f/5.8 Schmidt-Cassegrain + 1530x1020 CCD
ACK MPCReport file updated 2006.02.07 05:28:52
AC2 ddurig@sewanee.edu
NET UCAC-2
0032P C2006 02 07.45010 15 02 27.74 -09 19 02.3 16.7 N 850
0032P C2006 02 07.46083 15 02 28.20 -09 19 04.7 16.0 N 850
0032P C2006 02 07.47155 15 02 28.46 -09 19 05.7 16.3 N 850
----- end ----- 

Date:  Tue, 07 Feb 2006 13:49:23 +0100
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Confirming Comet Comas Sola at 16-17 mag !!!
> Here is what I got Tuesday morning on this comet after the notice of outburst:
>
> COD 850
> OBS D. T. Durig
> MEA D. T. Durig
> TEL 0.30-m f/5.8 Schmidt-Cassegrain + 1530x1020 CCD
> ACK MPCReport file updated 2006.02.07 05:28:52
> AC2 ddurig@sewanee.edu
> NET UCAC-2
> 0032P C2006 02 07.45010 15 02 27.74 -09 19 02.3 16.7 N
> 850
> 0032P C2006 02 07.46083 15 02 28.20 -09 19 04.7 16.0 N
> 850
> 0032P C2006 02 07.47155 15 02 28.46 -09 19 05.7 16.3 N
> 850

Hi Doug,
if we consider the astrometric-derived "N" (nuclear) magnitude, then on 2006 Feb.6.4 we measured it as 16.8 (unfiltered, USNO-B1.0 catalogue), that isn't too different from your values, considering the error bars.
Thanks for your valuable input!
Cheers,
Giovanni

Date:  Wed, 08 Feb 2006 21:17:33 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  73P(Schwassmann-Wachmann)  image
Hi all,

last night (centred on Tuesday 08.60 February UT) I imaged Comet 73P (Schwassmann-Wachmann) with my 16" f4.5 Newt and a Canon 10D DSLR. The FOV is about 30' x 20'. East is to the right, North is down. There is an interesting appearance just to the right (east) of the comet that looks like a fainter comet with a tail pointing the other way! I presume it's an image defect... I stacked 9 x 3 minute sub-exposures (800 ISO).

The galaxy at 5 O'clock to the comet is mag 13 galaxy NGC 5162 - and mag 16 galaxy UGC 8486 further on.

The image can be seen at:

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-073p-shwassmann-wachmann-060208-9x3min@800asa-41cm-f4,5-web.jpg

or

http://tinyurl.com/bdakh

After 73P I lined up on C/2006 A1, saw it big and bright in my camera view finder, was just going to start an exposure, and...it clouded over ##@#@#!!

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Wed, 08 Feb 2006 11:11:14 -0000
From:  gvnn64 
Subject:  Re: 73P(Schwassmann-Wachmann)  image
> There is an interesting appearance just to the right (east) of the
comet that looks like a fainter comet with a tail pointing the other
way! I presume it's an image defect...

Hi John,
I think it's the same faint background galaxy images by Ernesto Guido
and myself on 2006 Feb. 7.42 from NM. Its coordinates are: A.R.= 13h
28m 19.9s, Decl.= +10d 55' 03" (Equinox 2000.0).

You can find our image of the field here:

http://f3.grp.yahoofs.com/v1/MM_pQ2R_25yu57GUh8MXd9PwFXe8K9_OCJHY2l7mWig

Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero 

Date:  Thu, 09 Feb 2006 00:49:19 +1030
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  C/2006 A1 (Pojmanski) 7th feb 18:20 UT
Hi all,
FWIW - I was messing around with a Canon 350D at the dark site whilst
there this morning just gone, only using a tripod, and no remote, plus
hand/eye focus. 25 sec exp. 1600 iso with the dog awful kit f/5 zoom
lens that comes with 350d, also my first attempt at a long exposure at
a dark site with it.
My 350D seems to be one of the ones with the bad banding - although
that can be processed out of course.
Processing in CS only - very (non-biased) stretched and some usm - ,
as I am unfamiliar with deep sky digital processing atm.
Please excuse the hot pixels and all ;-) ! dont laugh!
fov 30 d wide - taken at around 4:50 am/18:20 ut 7th -
SE horizon below comet of course
http://southern-x.org/so_x/a1/a1feb7ut.jpg

Cheers
Kearn

Date:  Thu, 09 Feb 2006 01:23:03 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2005 E2 - 26x45 Sec. - Reprocessed
Greetings. Put together 26x45 sec exp looking for a tail where it
should be. I don't see one. The tail is only visible in the anti-tail
position for whatever reason. N is up and E to the left. Stacked on
the comet with 4 of the original 30 images discarded. Combined with
an "add" process then resampled from about 2000 pix wide to 4000 and
croped. Processed in PS and noise control in Neat Image. Thanks, Mike
H.

http://fototime.com/640C9F4FC123933/orig.jpg 

Date:  Wed, 08 Feb 2006 19:31:10 -0600

Date:  Thu, 09 Feb 2006 13:16:24 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2005 E2 - 26x45 Sec. - Reprocessed
Have you considered the geometry of this comet at the moment? It is on the other side of the sun at a heliocentric distance of about 2.2AU, and a geocentric distance of about 1.5AU. So the tail is directed away from the Earth, and we are looking 'along' it. If the dust tail is trailing the motion of the comet (with the tail being generally directed away from the sun) it is to be expected that the dust tail would appear to be on the sunward side of the comet - depending upon the viewing geometry. That is, what you have imaged is a dust tail physically directed away from the sun, but lagging behind the comet's actual motion in space. [If there was also an ion tail, you would expect (in the current geometry) that tail to be pointing in the opposite direction.]

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From: tricks46
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, February 09, 2006 12:23 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] C/2005 E2 - 26x45 Sec. - Reprocessed

Greetings. Put together 26x45 sec exp looking for a tail where it
should be. I don't see one. The tail is only visible in the anti-tail
position for whatever reason. N is up and E to the left. Stacked on
the comet with 4 of the original 30 images discarded. Combined with
an "add" process then resampled from about 2000 pix wide to 4000 and
croped. Processed in PS and noise control in Neat Image. Thanks, Mike
H.

http://fototime.com/640C9F4FC123933/orig.jpg

it should be. Very curious. Is there an error in the way Guide 8
shows the orientation?

Dennis Persyk

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46" wrote:
>
> Greetings. Put together 26x45 sec exp looking for a tail where it
> should be. I don't see one. The tail is only visible in the anti-
tail position for whatever reason. N is up and E to the left.
Stacked on the comet with 4 of the original 30 images discarded.

> 

Date:  Thu, 09 Feb 2006 15:10:45 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Antitail? was Re: C/2005 E2 - 26x45 Sec. - Reprocessed
See my earlier message (where I got the geocentric and heliocentric distances back-to-front).

In particular, the Earth-comet-sun angle is only about 23 degrees. If the tail is lagging the comet in its actual orbit about the sun by more than 23 degs, the tail will appear on the opposite side to the comet/antisun vector - and thus 'appear' to be on the sunward side of the comet.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From: Dennis Persyk
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, February 09, 2006 1:57 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Antitail? was Re: C/2005 E2 - 26x45 Sec. - Reprocessed

Hi Mike,

Yes, according to Guide 8, the tail is about 180 degrees from where
it should be. Very curious. Is there an error in the way Guide 8
shows the orientation?

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Date:  Thu, 09 Feb 2006 10:25:57 -0000
From:  gvnn64

Date:  Thu, 09 Feb 2006 10:33:52 -0000
From:  gvnn64 
Subject:  Re: C/2005 E2 - 26x45 Sec. - Reprocessed
Hi,
IMHO the explanation of Dave is reasonable: this structure pointing to
the Sun has been observed since several weeks now, and we are missing
the physical conditions for a real anti-tail (anti neck-line) since we
were well before perihelium. It could be something similar to the
apparent anti-tail (the ordinary dust tail seen toward solar direction
due to a perspective effect) we observed last year on C/2004 Q2
(Machholz).
Cheers,
Giovanni

Date:  Mon, 13 Feb 2006 19:16:46 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Vis Obs and photo: C/2006A1 - Pojmanski
Hi all,

I visually observed C/2006 A1 (Pojmanski) this morning with a nearly full Moon in the sky - and also imaged it with a 8" f4.6 Vixen RS200 Newtonian...

CometObs -

C/2006 A1 (Pojmanski) 2006 February 12.65 UT: m1 = 6.0, Dia.= 3'.0, DC = 6, 8cm f7.5 Refract (35x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Observed C/2006 A1 during full Moon. Easy to see the head. Much more condensed that my last observation (11 Jan, DC:4). I may be losing some outer coma (hence size) to the bright, moonlit sky. No tail seen - lost in the moonlight, but evident in tonight's photos (10' tail seen in 41cm scope). 16? alt in the SE. Stellar LM = ~10 near comet (scope)].

JPL (NASA) -

C/2006 A1 (Pojmanski)
2006 February 12.65 UT: m1=6.0, Dia.= 3'.0, DC=6/9, 8cm f7.5 Refract (35x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Observed C/2006 A1 during full Moon. Easy to see the head. Much more condensed that my last observation (11 Jan, DC:4). I may be losing some outer coma (hence size) to the bright, moonlit sky. No tail seen - lost in the moonlight, but evident in tonight's photos (10' tail seen in 41cm scope). 16? alt in the SE. Stellar LM = ~10 near comet (scope)].

I took an image (many short exposures due to the bright moonlight) and it shows a fairly pronounced tail nearly 1 degree long. It can be seen at...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2006a1-pojmanski-060212-31x30sec-2min@800asa-20cm-f4,6-full_moon-add-web.jpg

or

http://tinyurl.com/83acm

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Fri, 17 Feb 2006 19:26:55 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /2006 A1 2006Feb17 006.jpg
Uploaded by : dave_herald
Description : Pojmenski 2006 Feb 17

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/2006%20A1%202006Feb17%20006.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/help/us/groups/files

Regards,

dave_herald 

Date:  Sat, 18 Feb 2006 06:40:21 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Pojmenski image
I've uploaded an image of Pojmenski taken an hour ago. Conditions were not ideal - about 80% cloud cover with imaging
in the breaks, at an altitude of about 18 degs. The uploaded image is the best, and shows a fair degree of structure in
the ion tail. There is no obvious dust tail. Image is 14 x 10 arcmins.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia 

Date:  Fri, 17 Feb 2006 23:42:44 +0100
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Pojmenski image
Hi David,
an impressive image, indeed! Which was the scope and the CCD you used?
cheers,
Giovanni Sostero 

Date:  Sat, 18 Feb 2006 10:42:02 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: Re:[Comet-Images] Pojmenski image
I have a Meade 14", with an Starlight Express MX716 camera. Exposure was 30 secs, unguided. I'm sure that if I had clear skies I would get a lot more detail - the comet is bright enough for me to be able to make some long exposures tracking on the comet rather than the stars.

For reference: The faintest stars in the image are around 17.0. The brightest stars are about mag 12.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

Date:  Sat, 18 Feb 2006 13:07:54 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  The Pojmanski Tree Stump - Obs and photo
Hi all,

well, a 22 metre tree got in the way of Comet Pojmanski, so I cut it down! The story and photos (and my reasoning) of the decapitation can be seen at:

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/tree_felling01.htm

or

http://tinyurl.com/9xc73

Please don't condemn me until you've read my reasoning (on the webpage)...

I observed and photographed Pojmanski this morning...

CometObs -

C/2006 A1 (Pojmanski) 2006 February 17.65 UT: m1 = ~5.8, Dia.= 3'.0, DC = 7, 8cm f7.5 Refract (35x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Observed C/2006 A1 with an 18 day Moon in the sky. Easy to see the head. Compact nucleus with some slight fainter coma surrounding it. Can see a short 10' tail (more evident on tonight's photos). 16? alt in the SE. Stellar LM = ~10 near comet (scope)].

JPL (NASA) -

C/2006 A1 (Pojmanski)
2006 February 17.65 UT: m1=~5.8, Dia.=3'.0, DC=7/9, 8cm f7.5 Refract (35x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Observed C/2006 A1 with an 18 day Moon in the sky. Easy to see the head. Compact nucleus with some slight fainter coma surrounding it. Can see a short 10' tail (more evident on tonight's photos). 16? alt in the SE. Stellar LM = ~10 near comet (scope)].

An image of Pojmanski from last night can be seen at...

http://tinyurl.com/93zhg

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Mon, 20 Feb 2006 18:28:53 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  C/2005 E2 McNaught Movie
Comet C/2005 E2 McNaught is the brightest comet in the sky at present
observable from Northern Illinois.

This is a rapidly moving comet, tooling along at 2.1 arc seconds per
minute. That makes imaging a bit challenging.

E-160, SXV-H9, 45 x 1 minute, AP-1200GTO

Images, little (157 kB) movie, and supporting information at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Thu, 23 Feb 2006 21:16:32 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Obs-V and image of Pojmanski with a 5 degree tail
Hi all,

I observed and imaged Comet 2006 A1 over the last two nights...

CometObs-

C/2006 A1 (Pojmanski) 2006 February 21.67 UT: m1 = 5.4, Dia.= 4'.0, DC = 7, 15x70B...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [C/2006 easily seen in the 15x70 binoculars. Bright, condensed nucleus, with some fainter outer coma. Tail visible for about 15' (at least 3degrees in tonight's photos). 17? alt in the SE. Stellar LM = ~10 near comet (binocs)].

C/2006 A1 (Pojmanski) 2006 February 22.67 UT: m1 = 5.3, Dia.= 4'.0, DC = 7, 15x70B...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [C/2006 displays a bright, condensed nucleus, with some fainter outer coma. The head looks awesome in the 16" scope. Tail visible for about 15' (at least 5 degrees in tonight's photos). 15? alt in the SE. Stellar LM = ~10 near comet (binocs)].

A photo showing a five degree tail can be seen at:

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2006a1-pojmanski-060223-10x1-3min@800asa-200mm_sigma-f2,8-web.jpg

or

http://tinyurl.com/jvwth

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

large binoculars despite the moon interference. Here is a wide angle
(28 x 18 degree FOV) shot made with the 300D this morning with Venus
also in the field of view.

Date:  Sat, 25 Feb 2006 09:50:19 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Pojmanski animation
I've uploaded a GIF animation I created from 6 images I took of Pojmanski a few hours ago - into the files section of
both groups. The file is called 'Pojmanski 2006Feb24.GIF'

A few details.
1. The animation consists of a sequence of 4-minute exposures, with the telescope tracking on the nucleus of the comet
(Hence the comet image is totally static with respect to its orbital motion, and the stars are trailed.)
2. Conversion to GIF resulted in the loss of some detail - the image is grainier than the originals
3. Twilight affected the last two images - the effect being seen as a drop of brightness of the comet (and consequential
reduction in the diameter of the coma.)
4. Image size is 14 x 10 arcmins - so it only shows the very inner part of the tail!

I did not anticipate the amount of activity in the tail that is visible in this animation. The 4-minute exposure has
resulted in some loss of detail in the tail structure. If I do this again, I shall be using a shorter exposure to try to
get the tail structure/motion in better detail.

Finally, I can't make up my mind whether there is some indication of a faint, short dust tail extending below the ion
tail. What is apparent, though, is that the outer region of the coma (as seen in the image) is not circular, and is not
symmetric with the tail location (although other image analysis shows that the ion tail does point directly to the
brightest point in the coma). So I'm inclined to conclude that there is a VERY weak dust tail.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

[For the avoidance of doubt, I am not waiving copyright in this animation as a result of this posting!] 

Date:  Sun, 26 Feb 2006 03:42:47 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  OBS-V: C/2006A1 + image
Hi all,

I visually observed C/2006 A1 (Pojmanski) on the 24th... Sadly it has almost disappeared from my New Zealand sky (1-2 days left), you northern folk are in for a treat (initially anyhow). The tail is looking very nice in images (e.g. see the image taken with my 16" below).

CometObs -

C/2006 A1 (Pojmanski) 2006 February 24.67 UT: m1 = 5.2, Dia.= 3.5' - 4'.0, DC = 7, 15x70B...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [A1 still displays a bright, condensed nucleus, with some fainter outer coma. The head looks awesome in the 16" scope. Tail visible for about 15'. 14˚ alt in the ESE. Stellar LM = ~10 near comet (binocs)].

An image of Pojmanski taken through my 16" can be seen at...
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2006a1-pojmanski-060242-14x1min@800asa-41cm-f4,5-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/rsvfr

Regarding the image:
DATE: Fri 24.66 Feb 2006 (UT) (16:00-16:15)

SCOPE: 41cm (16") f4.5 Meade Newtonian

CAMERA: Canon EOS 10D digital SLR

EXPOSURE: 14 x 1 minute @ 800 ASA. FOV = ~35' x 22'

NOTES: 13 degree altitude in ESE. N=down,E=right

Please note that other images of the comet and my observations of it can be seen at:

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_2006a1_pojmanski.htm

or

http://tinyurl.com/dsxl5

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Sun, 26 Feb 2006 12:48:30 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  73P-02262006-Sweet!
Greetings. My first image of this comet so as you could tell with the
4". The FLI Maxcam 10 is a nice improvment for the faint comets using
a small scope. Weather was ok but some high clouds and falling temps
all night with a cold front made focus hard. Info is on the image.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/E33252A4996F15C/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 26 Feb 2006 14:11:58 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  It Is Offical (for me) -C/2006 A1 In The North
The low level of the comet and small 10 minute window for images kept
the tail detail out but man did I enjoy this comet. I started looking
at the horizion before 1100UT. I shot distant trees and I think a cow
moving around but not sure about that. It will improve with height and
a bit more time. Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/FA68C8D57729CDF/orig.jpg

Date:  Mon, 27 Feb 2006 20:39:44 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Pojmanski image on Spaceweather.com
Hi all,

I just wanted to send a 'blanket covering' email to ALL the people who have emailed me privately on getting my Comet Pojmanski image on www.spaceweather.com (Feb 26, 2006). Your congratulations have truly meant a lot to me. Thankyou.

However, a small minority have sent rather nasty emails stating that I'm an evil tree murderer because I (with a bit of tongue-in-cheek) stated that I dropped an exotic (non-native) macrocarpa tree when the comet went behind it. In seriousness the tree was diseased and had 1/3 rotted on the south side - and would have fallen in a severe storm in a year or two (the foliage/leaves was already dying back). So, not wanting the tree to fall on a car and injure someone - as a man I know can attest to (he still carries a badly scarred face to this day), I decided to do a controlled drop. The comet was a catalyst to a job that needed doing...

For those who wanted a larger version of the image, go to...
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/c-2006a1-pojmanski-060242-14x1min@800asa-41cm-f4,5-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/rsvfr

Now it's up to you 'northerners' to keep us 'down-underers' up to date re the comet...

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Date:  Mon, 27 Feb 2006 13:10:11 -0000
From:  Mark S Deprest 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] It Is Offical (for me) -C/2006 A1 In The North
--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Holloway"
wrote:
I
> will be glad when the B fragment is added to Guide8 for quick
reference
> cordinates. Mike H.

Hey Mike,
You lmow you can add the B fragment elements manually to Guide 8.0,
like I did.
Just click Extras, then Edit Comet data ..., then scroll to the
bottom of the list and click (new comet)and OK. Then enter:
Name: Schwassmann-Wachmann(73Pb)
Date of perihelion: 7.93879 Jun 2006
Perihelion distance (q): 0.939123
Eccentricity (e): 0.6933024
Argument of perihelion: 198.8047
Long. of ascending node: 69.89227
Inclination (i): 11.39751
Absolute magnitude (H): 11
Slope parameter (G): 5

I got the elements from Seiichi Yoshida's site.
Mark Deprest 

Date:  Mon, 27 Feb 2006 09:01:11 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: Re:[Comet-Images] It Is Offical (for me) -C/2006 A1 In The North
Thanks for this Mark; note that the elements of a splintered fragment such as
this will likely change as the dynamics of the motion of the primary comet
continues; however this is useful information and a good reminder on how quick
and adaptable Guide8 can be.

Dr. Clay
--------------------
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Mon, 27 Feb 2006 15:52:29 -0000
From:  Mark S Deprest 
Subject:  73P (e) Component Elements for Guide 8.0
Name: P/Schwassmann-Wachmann (73Pe)
Date of perihelion: 9.67135 Jun 2006
Perihelion distance (q): 0.9392433
Eccentricity (e): 0.6934703
Argument of perihelion: 198.79513
Long. of ascending node: 69.88808
Inclination (i): 11.40189
Absolute magnitude (H): 15 ????
Slope parameter (G): 5

Please note that these are from old elements and since this fragement
has not been recovered yet the "Absolute magnitude" is kind of a guess.
But they should work well for searching ...

Mark S Deprest 

Date:  Mon, 27 Feb 2006 16:57:24 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  A1 Pojmanski Imaging Attempt from 42 N
Hi Group,

I imaged A1 Pojmanski Sunday morning Feb 26 from latitude 42 d 8
min N (Northern Illinois) but conditions were very poor. I was
pointed toward Chicago, 40 miles away, and the sky glow was
terrible. My VLM was about -2, and I could see no stars visually
below Venus. My exposures were limited to 10 seconds (CCD binned 2x2
at f/3.3) to avoid saturation, and I was not able to capture much of
a tail. The comet is very fast moving relative to the star field,
6.4 arc seconds per minute, so I might make a movie of what I've got.

I'd appreciate it if posters would give their latitude. We folks in
the northern climes have a more challenging task.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Date:  Tue, 28 Feb 2006 08:11:18 -0000
From:  Dave Kodama 
Subject:  Comet Pojmanski
Finally, I've got an image to post!

>From just before sunrise on Saturday morning:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2006/0224c/15.htm

The comet was visible in my finder, but just barely because of the
glare of Venus and the moon. As you can see the clouds were already
moving in. A few hours later, the location was totally clouded over
and now we're getting several inches of rain.

Dave

Date:  Wed, 01 Mar 2006 00:05:48 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  2006 A1 Pojmanski - another animation
I've uploaded into the files section of the Comet-Images group another animation of Pojmanski. Details are:

Time - 2006 Feb 27, 18h 09m => 19h 00m UT
# images - 17
Exposure - 3 minutes each

Best viewing of the animation is obtained by running it at full size, but viewing it from a distance.

At the start of the animation, the comet was at low altitude, and half the aperture of my scope was blocked by my
observatory wall. At the end of the animation, twilight had become significant. These issues result in the size of eth
coma (and darkness of the image) increasing in the first couple of frames. And the comet becoming fainter in the last
half-dozen frames.

The tail activity is not as great as for the animation of Feb 24. The most notable movement is in a knot near the right
hand end of the central streamer. But other movements are noticeable.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia 

Date:  Wed, 01 Mar 2006 02:43:12 +1030
From:  belatrix 
Subject:  2006 A1 Pojmanski
Hi
Please visit our A1 page for a couple of wide field 35mm film pics of
the comet on the morning of 27th feb 2006 local time from a dark sky
site. http://southern-x.org/gallery-a1.html
Cheers and thankyou for visiting.
Kearn Jones
Adelaide, Australia 

Date:  Wed, 01 Mar 2006 06:16:30 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Pojmanski
I've posted another image of Pojmanski, for Feb 28.75 UT, in the files section of Comet-Images.

The tail structure near the coma is VERY different from 24 hours ago, with there being a larger number of streamers.

The comet is now getting too low for me to do any sensible animation.... Within a few days this comet will be out of my
reach. I trust the northerners will enjoy this comet, which is showing considerable activity in the ion tail (but no
appreciable dust tail).

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

Date:  Thu, 02 Mar 2006 20:57:53 +1030
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  C/2006 A1 report Feb 28th 2006
Hello all,

My latest images reveal Comet 2006 A1 Pojmanski is sporting a rather long
ion tail.

See images posted to my website at:

http://www.yp-connect.net/~mmatti/

Details:
Comet C/2006 A1 Pojmanski on 2006 February 28.78UT.
Left: 2x2 minute exposure. Canon 300D digital camera + 90mm telephoto lens.
Field of View approximately 8 degrees high.
Note the ion tail is at least 8 degrees in length.
Alpha Capricornus is to the right.
Right: 2x2 minute exposure. Canon 300D digital camera + 200mm telephoto
lens. Field of View 4 degrees high.

The ion tail was visible to about 5 degrees in 25x100mm and 7x50mm
binoculars and the comet was faintly visible to the naked eye at magnitude
5.4.

Kind Regards,
Michael Mattiazzo 

Date:  Thu, 02 Mar 2006 19:48:09 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2006 A1 report Feb 28th 2006
> Kind Regards,
> Michael Mattiazzo

Beatiful images!

Rolando

Date:  Fri, 03 Mar 2006 18:06:07 -0000
From:  sunblack74 
Subject:  Comet C/2006 A1 from Italy
Second image of the comet from my very polluted sky.
I post only the link since its a big image.
Image isnt very nice since heavy postprocessing.
I converted in B/W and negative type.
To see in the best way pic, use Photoshop or Paint Shop in order to
reduce image manually and have more contrast.
Canon 300D + 70-210mm at 70mm f/2.8 5x15s 1600iso CROPPED

http://tinyurl.com/g9hu8

Date:  Sat, 04 Mar 2006 02:33:51 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 A1-Mosaic-03/03/2006
Greetings. Took a bit of processing to remove the gradients for a
close match of images but the improvement of the comet over a couple
of days ago was well worth the work. 4" FSQ refractor and an FLI
Maxcam 10 ccd. A total of 6x45 second images with N up and E left.
If first light had not set in I could have easly increased the tail
length. There are two links. First is a small file and the second is
a full size (650kb) file. Thanks, Mike H.

http://fototime.com/E5AD2941580E310/standard.jpg

http://fototime.com/E5AD2941580E310/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 04 Mar 2006 15:37:54 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2006 A1-Mosaic-03/03/2006
Great image Mike!

would the FOV along the major access be 3 - 4 degrees?

Cheers

John D

Very nice image. In my system I can only get 0.2 deg of tail length in the field....

of days ago was well worth the work. 4" FSQ refractor and an FLI
Maxcam 10 ccd. A total of 6x45 second images with N up and E left.

length. There are two links. First is a small file and the second is
a full size (650kb) file. Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Sat, 04 Mar 2006 14:44:35 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2006 A1-Mosaic-03/03/2006
I've compared the image to the HeraldBobroff AstroAtlas chart covering this area (C-42). The image shows a triangle of over-exposed stars. The one at the bottom left (near the edge of the frame) is 69 Aquila. The distance from that to the other overexposed star (half-way across the image) is close to 1.0 deg. On that basis, the width of the picture is about 2.3 deg.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From: Mike Holloway

comet is showing about 2.5'. Thanks, Mike

Date:  Sat, 04 Mar 2006 11:54:38 +0100
From:  ligustri rolando

Date:  Sat, 04 Mar 2006 21:08:14 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  C/2006 A1 Pojmanski
This is a rapidly moving comet, racing along at 7.1 arc seconds per
minute. That makes imaging a bit challenging. It was fairly low on
the horizon, 15 degrees elevation, putting it smack dab in the
middle of Chicago's sky glow on my eastern horizon. I estimate the
VLM there to be -2. Yes, minus two! If I could image it, anyone
can .

E-160, SXV-H9, 26 x 45 seconds, AP-1200GTO

Images and supporting information at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Sun, 05 Mar 2006 03:27:32 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: C/2006 A1-Mosaic-03/03/2006
> I wouldn't mind seeing the image in negative. There appears to be a
far bit of structure in the tail, and I'm sure it will be more apparent
if the image is in negative form.
>
> Dave Herald
> Canberra, Australia

Negative
http://fototime.com/7DC288EE27730FB/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 05 Mar 2006 08:59:56 +0100

Rolando

>
> Thank you for visiting my site.
>
> Clear skies,
>
> Dennis Persyk
> Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
> Hampshire, IL
> 

Date:  Sun, 05 Mar 2006 20:21:18 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2006 A1-Mosaic-03/03/2006
Thanks. The detail in the tail is much more evident. It shows a series of points along the tail where divergent structures focus. This gives me the impression that there periods of extra activity in emitting material from the nucleus, and these are evidenced by these points along the tail

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

I think that the main doubt arises for fragment "G": if Nakano is correct, we will be informed by the CBAT or the MPC that its designation has to be switched to "E", instead. Date:  Tue, 07 Mar 2006 15:34:20 -0000
From:  Eric Briggs 
Subject:  Pojmanski Sighted from Toronto
http://tinyurl.com/ghybr

Details: Comet Pojmanski, 5 AM EST March 7th. 200mm/400mm at f/2, 26
one-second exposures median-combined in MaxIm DL 4.0. Run through
Photoshop 6.0 to bring out more dynamic range in the core. It's tough
to draw the tail out longer than about 30 arcminutes with my images.
This is the first go-around on processing.

I also looked at Pojmanski with my 11 x 80 binoculars, and the tail
was not in evidence. I really love the colour of comets in the coma
though.

Telescope: Celestron NexStar 8 GPS (Standard Starbright) with Fastar
Camera: Astrovid StellaCam EX
Field of View: 50 x 40 arcminutes Alt-Az, flipped horizontally
Limiting magnitude: about 15
Inside Toronto, Canada city limits

Date:  Mon, 13 Mar 2006 18:50:36 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Making a Comet Movie
C/2006 A1 Pojmanski had a very fast relative speed of motion, 7 arc
seconds per minute on March 4, making it a prime candidate for
animation. (Now it is 5.9 arc seconds per minute, still pretty
fast.) You can't image for long due to the speed (unless you guide),
so you wind up with lots of short exposure frames. Ideal movie
material.

Images and short (593 kB) movie at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Here's what I do in ImagesPlus:

1) Stretch the midpoint frame to pleasing histogram shape and apply
that histogram to all images. The sky background may vary
considerably from beginning to end, but it will look fine in the
movie.
2) Convert FITs to JPGs
3) Align on the stars. This is important! If you align on the
comet head, the animation will not look as pleasing.
4) Crop all images down to a small size, like 300 x 200 pixels.
Please . Most viewers don't want to download a 15  20 MB movie!

Next, in Ulead GIF Annimator:
1) Click on Annimation wizard and import the jpgs
2) Preview and remove any bad frames
3) Under Optimize, reduce the color bit depth from 256 bits to 16
(or less) bits. This has a profound effect on reducing file size.
Experiment with different settings to make the file size as small as
you can without sacrificing image quality too much.
4) Hope the Academy Awards will nominate your movie .

Notes on the software I described:

Of the many image processing aps I use, ImagesPlus seems best suited
for handling a hundred or so frames at once. The "Apply to all
images" command is greatly appreciated when dealing with a whole
bunch of images simultaneously.

Ulead GIF Animator replaced my all-time favorite Animagic. When I
got a new computer I somehow lost the password to it and now it's
broken. The Ulead ap is ok, gets the job done, and is easy to use.
I've not tried other animation aps so I don't know how it compares.

Give comet movie making a try. It is fun and a good way to use up
all of those frames you took.

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Tue, 14 Mar 2006 10:06:21 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Making a Comet Movie
There is one point in your process that I do not necessarily agree with. And that is the point about tracking on the stars rather than the comet head.

If you merely want to show the comet's motion amongst the stars, I would agree with you. It is nice to have point stars. However this option necessarily limits the exposure to short times - especially for a fast-moving comet. As a result, detail in the tail is not recorded. If you want to record tail detail, with the animation showing motion of features within the tail, you need to have sufficiently long exposures to record this detail. This means tracking on the comet, not the tail.

So...
* imaging to show motion of the comet amongst the stars - short exposures, track on the stars;
* imaging to show motion within the comet - longer exposures, track on the comet.

As this group will be aware, I did several animations a few weeks ago, while the comet was still visible at my latitude (-35) - and over a 40 min period there were on occasions quite large changes in the tail. One animation shows a knot which moved over 30" along the tail. Another showed the apparent width of the tail within 5 arcmins of the nucleus reducing by 20%. Consequently I would encourage people to do animations designed

PS. I did my animations by using the images as displayed in Astrometrica. Exported each image to a BMP file (to avoid image loss at this point). Then using PAINT, saved each image as a GIF file. And then used a short utility I downloaded called 'GIF Animator' to combine the individual GIF images into an animated GIF file. Simple process, not involving anything commercial other than Astrometrica and Windows.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From: Dennis Persyk
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, March 14, 2006 5:50 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Making a Comet Movie

C/2006 A1 Pojmanski had a very fast relative speed of motion, 7 arc
seconds per minute on March 4, making it a prime candidate for
animation. (Now it is 5.9 arc seconds per minute, still pretty
fast.) You can't image for long due to the speed (unless you guide),
so you wind up with lots of short exposure frames. Ideal movie
material.

Images and short (593 kB) movie at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Here's what I do in ImagesPlus:

1) Stretch the midpoint frame to pleasing histogram shape and apply
that histogram to all images. The sky background may vary
considerably from beginning to end, but it will look fine in the
movie.
2) Convert FITs to JPGs
3) Align on the stars. This is important! If you align on the
comet head, the animation will not look as pleasing.
4) Crop all images down to a small size, like 300 x 200 pixels.
Please . Most viewers don't want to download a 15 - 20 MB movie!

Next, in Ulead GIF Annimator:
1) Click on Annimation wizard and import the jpgs
2) Preview and remove any bad frames
3) Under Optimize, reduce the color bit depth from 256 bits to 16
(or less) bits. This has a profound effect on reducing file size.
Experiment with different settings to make the file size as small as
you can without sacrificing image quality too much.
4) Hope the Academy Awards will nominate your movie .

Notes on the software I described:

Of the many image processing aps I use, ImagesPlus seems best suited
for handling a hundred or so frames at once. The "Apply to all
images" command is greatly appreciated when dealing with a whole
bunch of images simultaneously.

Ulead GIF Animator replaced my all-time favorite Animagic. When I
got a new computer I somehow lost the password to it and now it's
broken. The Ulead ap is ok, gets the job done, and is easy to use.
I've not tried other animation aps so I don't know how it compares.

Give comet movie making a try. It is fun and a good way to use up
all of those frames you took.

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

SPONSORED LINKS Solar system Ccd Telescope

b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
Comet-Images-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.

Date:  Tue, 14 Mar 2006 09:26:30 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  Making a Comet Movie
Very well done. Great stuff
Dr. Eric Flescher
Comet Observer Chairman
Astronomy League

**

>
> Message: 2
>    Date: Mon, 13 Mar 2006 18:50:36 -0000
>    From: "Dennis Persyk"
> Subject: Making a Comet Movie
>
> C/2006 A1 Pojmanski had a very fast relative speed of motion, 7 arc
> seconds per minute on March 4, making it a prime candidate for
> animation. (Now it is 5.9 arc seconds per minute, still pretty
> fast.) You can't image for long due to the speed (unless you guide),
> so you wind up with lots of short exposure frames.  Ideal movie
> material.
>
> Images and short (593 kB) movie at
> http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm
>
> Here's what I do in ImagesPlus:
>
> 1) Stretch the midpoint frame to pleasing histogram shape and apply
> that histogram to all images.  The sky background may vary
> considerably from beginning to end, but it will look fine in the
> movie.
> 2) Convert FITs to JPGs
> 3) Align on the stars.  This is important!  If you align on the
> comet head, the animation will not look as pleasing.
> 4) Crop all images down to a small size, like 300 x 200 pixels.
> Please .  Most viewers don't want to download a 15 – 20 MB movie!
>
> Next, in Ulead GIF Annimator:
> 1) Click on Annimation wizard and import the jpgs
> 2) Preview and remove any bad frames
> 3) Under Optimize, reduce the color bit depth from 256 bits to 16
> (or less) bits. This has a profound effect on reducing file size.
> Experiment with different settings to make the file size as small as
> you can without sacrificing image quality too much.
> 4) Hope the Academy Awards will nominate your movie .
>
> Notes on the software I described:
>
> Of the many image processing aps I use, ImagesPlus seems best suited
> for handling a hundred or so frames at once.  The "Apply to all
> images" command is greatly appreciated when dealing with a whole
> bunch of images simultaneously.
>
> Ulead GIF Animator replaced my all-time favorite Animagic. When I
> got a new computer I somehow lost the password to it and now it's
> broken. The Ulead ap is ok, gets the job done, and is easy to use.
> I've not tried other animation aps so I don't know how it compares.
>
> Give comet movie making a try.  It is fun and a good way to use up
> all of those frames you took.
>
> Thank you for visiting my site.
>
> Clear skies,
>
> Dennis Persyk
> Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
> Hampshire, IL
>

using but it sits not far from C/2005 E2 which I was after before
Moonrise. Took 11x45 sec exposures and stacked on the comet although
there probably wasn't much movement to matter. This is one I haven't
imaged in the past. Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Sat, 25 Mar 2006 12:50:49 -0500
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  Mini-Comets Approaching Earth
FYI
Dr. Eric Flescher
Comet Observers Chairman, Astronomy League
**
Mini-Comets Approaching Earth

03.24.2006

A cometary "string-of-pearls" will fly past Earth in May closer than any
comet has come in almost 80 years.

March 24, 2006: In 1995, Comet 73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 3 did something
unexpected: it fell apart. For no apparent reason, the comet's nucleus split into
at least three "mini-comets" flying single file through space. Astronomers
watched with interest, but the view was blurry even through large telescopes.
"73P" was a hundred and fifty million miles away.
We're about to get a much closer look. In May 2006 the fragments are going
to fly past Earth closer than any comet has come in almost eighty years.
Right: Comet 73P breaking up in 1995. Photo credit: Jim V. Scotti. [More]
"This is a rare opportunity to watch a comet in its death throesfrom very
close range," says Don Yeomans, head of NASA's Near Earth Object Program at
JPL.
There's no danger of a collision. "Goodness, no," says Yeomans. "The closest
fragment will be about six million miles away--or twenty-five times farther
than the Moon." That's close without actually being scary.
Sign up for EXPRESS SCIENCE NEWS delivery

The flyby is a big deal. "The Hubble Space Telescope will be watching," says
Yeomans. "Also, the giant Arecibo radar in Puerto Rico will 'ping' the
fragments to determine their shape and spin." Even backyard astronomers will be able
to take pictures as the mini-comets file through the constellations Cygnus and
Pegasus on May 12, 13 and 14.
Ironically these comets, so nearby, will not be very bright. The largest
fragments are expected to glow like 3rd or 4th magnitude stars, only dimly
visible to the unaided eye.
"Remember," says Yeomans, "these are mini-comets." They're not like the
Great Comets Hayutake and Hale-Bopp of 1996 and 1997. Those could be seen with the
naked eye from light-polluted cities. The fragments of 73P, on the other
hand, are best viewed from the countryside--and don't forget your binoculars.
The number of fragments is constantly changing. When the breakup began in
1995 there were only three: A, B and C. Astronomers now count at least eight:
big fragments B and C plus smaller fragments G, H, J, L, M and N. "It looks as
though some of the fragments are themselves forming their own sub-fragments,"
says Yeomans, which means the number could multiply further as 73P approaches.
No knows how long the "string of pearls" will be when it finally arrives.

Above: Fragments B and C approaching Earth on Feb. 26, 2006. Credit:
Giovanni Sostero and Ernesto Guido of the Remanzacco Observatory in Italy using a
remote-controlled 14-inch telescope in New Mexico.
Bonus: There could be a meteor shower, too.
This is very uncertain, indeed, forecasters consider it unlikely. But an
expanding cloud of dust from the 1995 break-up of the comet could brush past
Earth in May 2006 producing a display of meteors.
Astronomer Paul Wiegert at the University of Western Ontario has studied the
possibility:
"We believe the cloud is expanding too slowly to reach Earth only eleven
years after the break-up," he says, "but it all depends on what caused the comet
to fly apartand that we don't know."
"The most likely explanation is thermal stress, with the icy nucleus
cracking like an ice cube dropped into hot soup: the comet broke apart as it
approached the Sun after a long sojourn the frigid outer solar system," he explains.
"If this is truly what happened, then the debris cloud should be expanding
slowly, and there will be no strong meteor shower."
Right: Clouds of comet dust from Comet 73P are expected to miss Earth in
2006. [More]
On the other hand, what if "the comet was shattered by a hit from a small
interplanetary boulder?" A violent collision could produce faster-moving debris
that would reach Earth in 2006.
Wiegert expects to see nothing, but he encourages sky watchers to be alert.
It wouldn't be the first time a dying comet produced a meteor shower:
"One outstanding example is comet Biela, which was seen to split in 1846,
and had completely broken apart by 1872," he says. "At least three very intense
meteor showers (3000-15000 meteors per hour) were produced by this dying comet
in 1872, 1885 and 1892."
Assuming a thermal breakup for 73P, Wiegert and colleagues have calculated
the most likely trajectory of its dust cloud. Their results: dust should reach
Earth in 2022, "producing a minor meteor shower--nothing spectacular.
However," he adds, "the ongoing splitting of the comet means new meteoroids are being
sent in new directions, so a future strong meteor shower from 73P remains a
real possibility."
The watch begins on May 12th.

SEND THIS STORY TO A FRIEND
Author: Dr. Tony Phillips | Editor: Dr. Tony Phillips | Credit: Science@NASA
References

Sky maps: May 12, May 13, May 14.
Comet fragment ephemerides -- from JPL
The τ Herculid meteor shower and Comet 73P/SchwassmannWachmann 3
The story says, "In May 2006 the fragments are going to fly past Earth
closer than any comet has come in almost eighty years." What was the comet that
came closer almost eighty years ago? Answer: 7P/Pons-Winnecke, which flew past
Earth at a distance of 3.6 million miles on June 26, 1927. Comet
7P/Pons-Winnecke was small and faint in spite of being nearby; it glowed like a 3rd or 4th
magnitude star, about as bright as the larger fragments of 73P will be in May
2006.
Comet 73P/SchwassmannWachmann 3 -- a history of observations
Comet 3D/Biela -- a comet that broke apart in 1846 and subsequently produced
three strong meteor showers.
The Vision for Space Exploration

From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  73P - 3x mosaic - 03/25/2006
Greetings. It took 2 frames to put B & C fragments together where as a
week ago or maybe a bit longer it only took one frame. I put another
frame in but don't know if any other pieces were there or not. Took
the images when the comet was low on E Horizion. Gradients were a
killer. Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Tue, 28 Mar 2006 12:22:04 -0000
From:  gvnn64 
Subject:  Mosaic of 73P/Scwassmann-Wachmann
Hi all,
a wide-field mosaic of comet 73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann (fragments B + C
+ G) is available here: http://tinyurl.com/lakkd

Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero and Ernesto Guido (Remanzacco Observatory, Italy)

Date:  Wed, 29 Mar 2006 00:47:11 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: 73P-03/26/2006-Images
Dennis.
For Guide 8
Go to create a "new comet" using edit comet data under the extras
drop down box. Scroll to the bottom for create "new comet". Find
the listing for 73P already in the comet list for a reference untill
a couple of new comet comp. have been created

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann (73P-B) - The B is just an example of how
to list each new fragment changing the letter for a new piece of the
comet. Use the dates below changing for each piece. Leave all other
information the same for each piece.

Example for comp. "B"

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann (73P-B)
7.9400 Jun 2006
0.939142
0.69338
11.3907
198.7881
69.9066
12
6

B 7.9400 Jun 2006
C 6.95
G 8.11
H 8.29
J 8.14
K 8.24
L 8.35
M 8.28
N 8.30
P 7.88
Q 7.74
R 8.20
S 8.24

This works pretty good and gives an amazing screen when finished.

Thanks, Mike H.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Dennis Persyk"
wrote:
>
> Hi Mike,
>
> Where are you getting the coordinates of the components from? I
> think you use Guide 8, as I do. I don't think the Harvard link has
> the components yet for any of the planetarium programs.
>
> Clear skies,
>
> Dennis Persyk
> Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
> Hampshire, IL
>
> New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm
>

> wrote:

Dennis.
For Guide 8
Go to create a "new comet" using edit comet data under the extras
drop down box. Scroll to the bottom for create "new comet". Find
the listing for 73P already in the comet list for a reference untill
a couple of new comet comp. have been created

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann (73P-B) - The B is just an example of how
to list each new fragment changing the letter for a new piece of the
comet. Use the dates below changing for each piece. Leave all other
information the same for each piece.

Example for comp. "B"

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann (73P-B)
7.9400 Jun 2006
0.939142
0.69338
11.3907
198.7881
69.9066
12
6

B 7.9400 Jun 2006
C 6.95
G 8.11
H 8.29
J 8.14
K 8.24
L 8.35
M 8.28
N 8.30
P 7.88
Q 7.74
R 8.20
S 8.24

This works pretty good and gives an amazing screen when finished.

Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Wed, 29 Mar 2006 11:13:41 +0200
From:  Maik Meyer 
Subject:  Re: 73P-03/26/2006-Images
Dave,

the perihelion times are okay. I guess Mike took my list from my postings of
comets-ml or the homepage. K and S are 0.001 days apart in perihelion time:

from CBET 442:
"Component S, of mag 20.9=21.5, has T only some 0.001 day earlier than component
K, which has now been redetected at mag 20.9-21.3."

When rounding to 2 digits one receives of course the same time.

Cheers, Maik
--
If they give you ruled paper, write the other way. * Juan Ramon Jimenez
________________________________________________________________________
maik@comethunter.de http://www.comethunter.de
German Comet Section http://www.fg-kometen.de
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/comets-ml 

Date:  Wed, 29 Mar 2006 19:22:54 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  C/2003 WT42 (LINEAR)
This comet is presently at magnitude 13.6 in UMa. It is not as bright
or exciting as Pojmanksi or 73P with its many fragments, but has a
nice 2 arc minute long tail.

Images and supporting information at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Wed, 29 Mar 2006 22:48:04 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: 73P-03/26/2006-Images
Maik. I did take the dates as-is from your post on the ml board.
Hope you don't mind as this was the easist way I have found to have
guide8 show these fragments.
Mike H.

Date:  Sun, 02 Apr 2006 09:41:28 +0200
From:  Frank Jungclaus 
Subject:  Image of 73P on 2006/03/24
Hello!

While preparing my image setup for a later on imaging session an
C2006 A1 Pojmanski, I used Arcturus for focusing. Then, while looking to
"Cartes du Ciel" running on my laptop, I suddenly saw 73P only a stone's
throw away from Arcturus. So I spontaneously decided to give 73P a try ...



or

http://tinyurl.com/jom9a

Clear skies
Frank

Date:  Wed, 05 Apr 2006 09:03:07 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Magnitudes of 73P B and C?
As best I can tell from the CometObs site, fragments B and C have
similar magnitudes. I tried looking on the NASA Recent Observations
page which I used to use but that link no longer works.

I just finished imaging B and am working on C as we speak/read. I
don't know how to do photometry but B certainly seems a lot brighter
than C, and additionally sports a tail well over 50 arc minutes in
length, whereas C has a short tail. Is B in outburst or is my eyeball
estimate of magnitudes woefully poor?

I'll post both images to my New Images page shortly (after I get some
sleep, however).

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Date:  Wed, 05 Apr 2006 22:17:48 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  73P Fragment B
Comet 73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 3 was featured in the May
Sky&Telescope and Astronomy magazines. I imaged fragments B and C
last night. Fragment B was considerably brighter and had a beautiful
tail over 35 arc minutes long. I have posted the B images on my web
page linked below.

I did not resolve the "plume" reported G. Sostero and E. Guido using
simple stretching and isophote display techniques.

Images and supporting data at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Thu, 06 Apr 2006 09:50:51 -0000
From:  gvnn64 
Subject:  Re: 73P Fragment B
> I did not resolve the "plume" reported G. Sostero and E. Guido using
> simple stretching and isophote display techniques.

Hi Dennis,
apparently this feature was visible for a brief time. I'm pretty
confident about its reality, since another author reported it
indipendently, few hours before our observation:
http://tinyurl.com/gpjqm

On the other hand, on the images of Rolando Ligustri (March 4.86), as
well as our images obtained on March 5.31, it is not visible anymore.

In the cometary scientific literature, sometimes are reported similar
structures (referred to as "coma arclets" or "coma wings") immediatly
after a nuclear splitting. Since normally they are made of gases, are
short living features.

Cheers,
Giovanni 

Date:  Thu, 06 Apr 2006 22:33:45 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  73P (Shwassmann-Wachmann) image
Hi all,

last night I imaged 73P with my 41cm (16") f4.5 - 8 x 5 minutes @ 800asa.
Date: Wed 05.62 April 2006 (UT), 14:45 - 15:30 hours UT

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/73p-shwassmann-wachmann-060405-8x5min@800asa-41cm-f4,5-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/jvsak

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/Remanzacco%20Observatory/73P-B_2006April07_GuiSos.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/help/us/groups/files

gvnn64

Date:  Fri, 07 Apr 2006 20:49:40 -0400
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  Dying comet 73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 3
Space Weather News for April 7, 2006
http://spaceweather.com

Dying comet 73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 3 continues to break apart. Astronomers
are tracking at least 20 fragments approaching Earth for a harmless but
beautiful close encounter in May.

In particular, fragment B of the comet has brightened 15-fold since April
2nd. This signals a possible breakup of "73P-B" into even more fragments.
Amateur astronomers with backyard telescopes and CCD cameras can monitor the ongoing
disintegration.  Visit Spaceweather.com for sky maps, images more
information.

-Get ready for a comet observing fest in May

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com), Olathe, KS: State of Kansas Solar
System Ambassador: Comet Observer Chairman- Astronomical League: Black Sun
Eclipse website and newsletter:http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/blacksun/eclipse:
Subscribe: blacksuneclipse-subscribe@egroups.com: E.O.A.S. (Earth, Oceans,
Atmosphere and Space Blog) -http://www.xanga.com/dreric1kansas

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sat, 08 Apr 2006 01:03:17 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: 73P-03/26/2006-Images
Came across these 73P elements for Guide users. Copied them to the
comet folder after deleting all other 73p elements then updated
the "add MPC comet/asteroids" under extras. Can't get any clear skys
to see how close they are but these came from guide users on yahoo.
Mike H.

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann3C (73P) 6.9515 6 2006
0.0 0.939160 0.693383 11.3905 198.7891 69.9055
2000.0 9.0 7.2

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann3B 7.9203 6 2006
0.0 0.939114 0.693471 11.3904 198.7854 69.9027
2000.0 11.5 7.2

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann3G 8.0928 6 2006
0.0 0.939036 0.693654 11.3917 198.7970 69.8947
2000.0 14.5 7.2

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann3H 8.3004 6 2006
0.0 0.938341 0.690858 11.3785 199.0183 69.7243
2000.0 17.5 7.2

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann3J 8.1465 6 2006
0.0 0.938809 0.691587 11.3813 198.9063 69.8044
2000.0 17.0 7.2

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann3K 8.1635 6 2006
0.0 0.942951 0.703409 11.4318 197.7321 70.6872
2000.0 19.0 7.2

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann3L 8.2886 6 2006
0.0 0.937335 0.695561 11.4093 199.0326 69.7504
2000.0 17.0 7.2

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann3M 8.7182 6 2006
0.0 0.923757 0.628547 11.0615 204.2033 65.6421
2000.0 18.0 7.2

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann3N 8.3000 6 2006
0.0 0.939123 0.693302 11.3975 198.8047 69.8923
2000.0 18.0 7.2

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann3P 8.9248 6 2006
0.0 0.926300 0.590196 10.7650 205.0245 64.8933
2000.0 17.0 7.2

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann3Q 7.8855 6 2006
0.0 0.943632 0.680266 11.2756 198.2646 70.1539
2000.0 18.0 7.2

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann3R 8.2000 6 2006
0.0 0.939123 0.693302 11.3975 198.8047 69.8923
2000.0 17.5 7.2

P/Schwassmann-Wachmann3S 8.2400 6 2006
0.0 0.939123 0.693302 11.3975 198.8047 69.8923
2000.0 18.0 7.2

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Holloway"
wrote:
>
> Dennis.
> For Guide 8
> Go to create a "new comet" using edit comet data under the extras
> drop down box. Scroll to the bottom for create "new comet".
Find
> the listing for 73P already in the comet list for a reference
untill
> a couple of new comet comp. have been created
>
> P/Schwassmann-Wachmann (73P-B) - The B is just an example of
how
> to list each new fragment changing the letter for a new piece of
the
> comet. Use the dates below changing for each piece. Leave all
other
> information the same for each piece.
>
> Example for comp. "B"
>
> P/Schwassmann-Wachmann (73P-B)
> 7.9400 Jun 2006
> 0.939142
> 0.69338
> 11.3907
> 198.7881
> 69.9066
> 12
> 6
>
> B 7.9400 Jun 2006
> C 6.95
> G 8.11
> H 8.29
> J 8.14
> K 8.24
> L 8.35
> M 8.28
> N 8.30
> P 7.88
> Q 7.74
> R 8.20
> S 8.24
>
> This works pretty good and gives an amazing screen when finished.
>
> Thanks, Mike H.
>

Date:  Sat, 08 Apr 2006 14:17:04 -0000
From:  Mark S Deprest 
Subject:  Re: 73P-03/26/2006-Images
Hi Mike,
These elements are very good, I've used Guide since v. 3.0. I like it a
lot, but thats for another user group.
We finally got some clear skies here in Michigan, and I am going out
tonight & tomorrow morning to see what I can see. I just hope component
B is still there when I get out. By what I'm reading it sounds like its
beginning to die!
I should be posting a drawing or two tomorrow some time. I'll keep you
posted.
By the way, I love your images and hope you get some clear skies soon!
Mark Deprest

Date:  Sat, 08 Apr 2006 14:46:16 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: 73P-03/26/2006-Images
A short thought to add. I have piggybacked my ST2k CCD on the 4"
with a 120mm Nikon giving a 4' or larger FOV. Some fragments should
be bright enough to show, I hope. A good subsitute for a DSLR if you
have adaptors for your CCD's. This also gives my CFW a chance to be
used

Mike
