Date:  Sat, 08 Apr 2006 14:25:24 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Comet 73P (B, C, G, R) images posted
Hello to all; just finished posting four images of the fragments 73P - B, C, G,
and R on the ASO News Section website; morphological and physical observations
are posted (http://www.arksky.org/ ) on the Comet Pages of the site. Daily
astrometric results on any fragments are posted daily on the site's Astrometry
Tables link.

The direct link to the images is:
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=980.msg4653#msg4653

to the physical reports on the ASO Comet Tables:
http://www.arksky.org/php/ctable.php
(will be posted in about one hour)

Details of CCD, field, etc. accompany the description of the four components.

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

NOTE that all ASO outgoing mail is protected by McAfee, Zone Alarm and
tcworks.net security
and is certified Virus and Spam-free
----- Original Message -----
From: "Roberto"
To: "MPLM"
Sent: Saturday, April 08, 2006 9:26 AM
Subject: Fw: {MPML} 73P astrometry from G96, 06Apr07 (fwd)

>
> The fragment "R" of the comet 73P is dissolving itself. The 7.90 April them
> was of mag 17.5 with one coma and tail much diffusing.
> Clears Skies,
> Roberto Haver
> 157 Frasso Sabino
>
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: "Eric Christensen"
> > To: ;
> > Sent: Saturday, April 08, 2006 3:11 AM
> > Subject: {MPML} 73P astrometry from G96, 06Apr07 (fwd)
> >
> > > Below is my report to CBAT for the latest round of G96 data. I wasn't
> > > able to download and measure everything, but this is the majority of it.
> > >
> > > Regards,
> > >
> > > Eric
> > >
> > > ------------------------------------------------------
> > >
> > > Rik Hill obtained images of 73P from the Mt. Lemmon 1.5m telescope last
> > > night, UT April 07. Exposures were all 120 second unfiltered
> > > integrations. Seeing was fair.
> > >
> > > Astrometry is below. There will be more astrometry from April 07 to
> > > follow, probably next week some time (and hopefully astrometry from
> April
> > > 08/09 as well). Included in the forthcoming report will be astrometry
> of
> > > B and C close in time to all minor fragment observations.
> > >
> > > Again, I will highlight just a few of the components.
> > >
> > > We searched an additional few fields in front of component C and
> continued
> > > to find fragments. The easternmost fragment, 6GC3554, is approximately
> > > 2.5 degrees ahead of C. There are no visible fragments an additional
> 0.5
> > > degree ESE of 6GC3554, down to V=22.0.
> > >
> > > On the west end of the complex, we found 6GC3553, bringing the total
> > > angular length of the complex to around 12 degrees at this time
> (eyeballed
> > > from one of our planning aids, not rigorously calculated).
> > >
> > > All 4-digit numbers below have an implicit "6GC" in front of them, to
> > > associate with the temporary designations in the astrometry.
> Descriptions
> > > are given independent of order within the complex.
> > >
> > > 3553: 4" coma, no tail.
> > > 3554: 10" coma elongated ~15" toward PA 230
> > > 3556: slightly condensed 10" coma with a 30" tail toward PA 230.
> > > 3539: no coma or tail to speak of. FWHM is comparable to stars of
> similar
> > > magnitude.
> > > 353A: very diffuse 12" coma. Threshhold object, confirmation necessary.
> > > 353B: 8" coma elongated toward PA 230
> > > 353C: an apparent companion to 353B, located only 12" away in PA 255.
> > >
> > > 354A: I believe this is the same object that I reported as stellar in
> > > appearance on April 02 (6GAF4F1). Last night this object displayed a
> > > condensed 12" coma with a 20" tail in PA 230. Additionally, I searched
> > > G96 images from Mar 23 2006 for the stellar object (conveniently located
> > > between U and V), and could find nothing. This leads me to conclude
> that
> > > 6GAF4F1 is not an inert piece of 73P, but is an active fragment.
> > >
> > > 3559: condensed 12" coma, 18" tail spanning PA 200-250
> > >
> > > 355D: fragment R. 40" coma, 1.5 arcminute tail in PA 230. This
> fragment
> > > is apparently continuing to brighten. No evidence of a split.
> > >
> > > 355E: fragments K/S. Again, this appears to be 2 overlapping fragments
> > > of low surface brightness. Measured what I believe to be the
> easternmost
> > > fragment.
> > >
> > > 3561: this fragment appears almost stellar: extremely condensed 5" coma
> > > with no tail.
> > > 3562: diffuse 8" coma with 15" tail in PA 230
> > >
> > > 356E: this fragment is unremarkable aside from its position, located
> > > approximately 6 arcminutes NNE along a line perpendicular to the line of
> > > variation.
> > >
> > > 357D: G fragment. This is considerably brighter than on April 02, and
> > > there is no evidence of the secondary condensation reported on that
> night.
> > > Instead, the coma has grown to a diameter of 1.5 arcminutes, with a 2
> > > arcminute tail toward PA 230.
> > >
> > > I'm not submitting any astrometry for the B fragment since I haven't
> > > measured the non-saturated images yet, however approximate total
> magnitude
> > > is V=9.7. The coma is approximately 12 x 15 arcminutes, elongated
> toward
> > > PA 230. Additionally, there is a faint narrow tail extending at least
> 30
> > > arcminutes, also toward PA 230.
> > >
> > > Regards,
> > >
> > > Eric J. Christensen
> > >
> > > ---------------------------
> > > COD G96
> > > OBS R. E. Hill
> > > TEL 1.5-m Schmidt + CCD
> > > NET UCAC2
> > > AC2 sixty@lpl.arizona.edu, eric@lpl.arizona.edu
> > > MEA E. J. Christensen
> > > ACK 06Apr07.neos.mrpt
> > > 6GC3533 C2006 04 07.43746 14 58 30.21 +21 02 37.8 20.1 V

Date:  Sat, 08 Apr 2006 21:55:24 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  Comet 73P: brightest fragments
Hi all,

I managed to upload some recent images of this comet, showing its brightest
fragments.

They are available here:

http://www.bellatrixobservatory.org/comets.html

Cheers,
Gianluca

***********************************************************************
* Gianluca Masi "Two things fill the soul *
* Via Madonna de Loco, 47 with awe and reverence [...]: *
* 03023 Ceccano (FR) the starry sky above me and *
* ITALY the moral law within me" *
* e-mail: gianluca@bellatrixobservatory.org *
* web: http://www.bellatrixobservatory.org I. Kant *
* Minor Planet Center Obs. Code: 470 - Ceccano *
* Center for Backyard Astrophysics - Italy *
* VSNET Collaboration Team member *
* CCD-astrometry-photometry@yahoogroups.com mailing-list moderator *

Date:  Sun, 09 Apr 2006 03:49:01 -0000

Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /Remanzacco Observatory/73P-B_2006April09_GuiSos.jpg
Uploaded by : gvnn64
Description : Possible disruption of 73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann, fragment "B"

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/Remanzacco%20Observatory/73P-B_2006April09_GuiSos.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/help/us/groups/files

Regards,

gvnn64

Date:  Sun, 09 Apr 2006 15:19:52 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  73P-04092006-Images
Once again gradients a problem with the position. Comp."C" - 5x45 sec
exp N up E left. Pretty good size file.
http://www.fototime.com/C4A94112B482872/orig.jpg
"B" comp and another which I don't know at this time. Same times
http://fototime.com/F3B67CFFF24F166/orig.jpg
2 frame animation of "B" and what ever else is there. Once again this
is a 750kb file but preserving some quality is needed.
http://www.fototime.com/9066936B6362358/orig.gif

Thanks, Mike H. 

Date:  Sun, 09 Apr 2006 15:54:36 -0000
From:  Mark S Deprest 
Subject:  Re: 73P-04092006-Images
Very Nice Mike,
I too got out and spent hours visually observing these fragments. I did
get a couple of drawings done. One of "B" and the other of "C", I need
to them scanned and processed a bit, I should have them posted here
tonight sometime. I think I was able to see component "G" but with the
gibbous moon it was very difficult to confirm visually, your image says
that I did see it. Thank you for posting them.
My drawings are .50degree FOV, so your hope of wide-angle drawings will
have to wait a couple of weeks until I can do some with the 5" F/5
refractor and my 38mm Erfle (gives me 3.6 degrees FOV).
Mark S Deprest

Date:  Sun, 09 Apr 2006 16:59:42 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  73P-6x Mosaic-04092006
Before you open this I will appologize for the quality. My flats
didn't cut the mustard and Moon glow was a killer with the large
images. It does show about 4.4 deg of FOV with N up. Images from
about 0400UT 04062006. Gives a perspective of distance with the pieces
spreading out . Once again if you use aol right click the image and
reload full quality or distortion will destroy this picture.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/9C5875AB5AD41CF/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 09 Apr 2006 18:20:39 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  73P-C-1x1 bin-04092006
2x45 sec added and croped.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/841F82AF56E4CED/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 09 Apr 2006 18:53:13 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  73P-B&G(?)-04092006
2x45 sec exp. 2x2 bin resampled to 1900 pix wide and croped. LR
sharp. N up.
Thanks and I think this is all for today
Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/22A531EF7BE832B/orig.jpg

Date:  Mon, 10 Apr 2006 00:01:28 -0000
From:  Mark S Deprest 
Subject:  New Drawings Posted P73 - B & C
Hello Group,
I just posted two drawings I did from last night / early morning
observing run. They are in the photo section of this group, under the
folder "MarkDeprest Drawings "
Enjoy, let me know what you think.
Carpe Nocturne - Clear Skies & Dark Nights
Mark S Deprest
Astronomical League
University Lowbrow Astronomers
Association of Lunar & Planetary Observers
American Association of Amateur Astronomers
A.L.Comet Observers Club Gold Award Recipient
http://home.comcast.net/~msdeprest/wsb/index.html
"Hung be the heavens with black, yeild day to night! Comets, importing
changes of times and states. Brandish your crystal tresses in the
sky!" -- Shakespeare, 1 Henry VI, c. 1590

Date:  Tue, 11 Apr 2006 08:35:59 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Main fragment of Comet 73P April 10, 2005
I got up at 2:30 A.M. yesterday morning to image the
main fragment of Comet 73P.

The field is approximately 20 arc minutes wide.

http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/imagefiles/73P-04102006.JPG 

Date:  Thu, 13 Apr 2006 10:16:13 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Elongated (extended?) core of "B" component of 73P
Comet Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P, "B" component: The elongation of the "B" component
is very evident now in spite of full moonlight last morning (April 13); the inset
shows the bright elongated core (nucleus?) of the comet in addition to a faint
field star immediately adjacent to the comet's coma; taken at about 05:00 UT,
shortly after the coma was covering this field star somewhat and we have received
reports of a secondary fragment within the coma this attributed to the star's
position shortly after 05:30 UT.

http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD125F0.jpg

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Fri, 14 Apr 2006 08:36:55 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Update on Comet 73P Schwassmann-Wachmann
Non-fragmented "B" component of 73P; strong "C" component; early reports of
fragmentation or splitting of the "B" component of this remarkable comet were
premature....the comet seems very much intact. The following images and reports
are posted at the ASO website:

Component B of Comet 73P Schwassmann-Wachmann; note the intensity of the nucleus,
clearly not disintegrated nor broken into fragments at this time; Larsen-Sekanina
filtering applied. The Ion tail of this comet is beginning to exhibit a beautiful
shape with a symmetrical contour developing.
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD25DE8.jpg

Component C of Comet 73P Schwassmann-Wachmann; the brightest (total magnitude 8.2
on April 14) of the multiple components; this fragment is demonstrating a "typical"
strong coma with no visible nucleus; straight tail is developing.
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD26161.jpg

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

NOTE that all ASO outgoing mail is protected by McAfee, Zone Alarm and tcworks.net
security
and is certified Virus and Spam-free

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sat, 15 Apr 2006 10:02:15 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[comets-ml] Update on Comet 73P Schwassmann-Wachmann
> Non-fragmented "B" component of 73P; strong "C" component; early reports of
> fragmentation or splitting of the "B" component of this remarkable comet were
> premature....the comet seems very much intact.

Have you directly measured it with a ruler or a balance?

In short: a fragmentation doesn't automatically imply the *total* destruction of the nucleus.

Longer version: fragment "B" of comet 73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann has shown in the past week the typical behaviour of a fragmented comet: all the evidences (photometry, morpholoy, etc.) from a numer of observers pointed to it. In the last 24-36 hourse a sharp condensation toward the coma head is again visible: yesterday's images from various observers (T. Puckett, H. Mikuz, E. Guido and R. Ligustri just to cite some) clearly show the progressive enhancement of this detail. The explanation offered by a break-up event in the nucleus (and its consequences) fits quite well the events sequence (outburst of several magnitudes, disapparition of the central condensation, trailed aspect of the optocenter, flatness of the afrho, etc.).
If now a central condensation is again visible, this likely means that we witnessed a *partial* break-up of the nucleus; may be worth to remind that a similar fact happened also to C/1999 S4 (LINEAR) some weeks before its *total* disgregation.
What is missed up to now, is a direct imaging of the train of debris that was released after the partial split; but since these events happened with the interference of the moonlight, it was unlikely that any real big scope (the same class of instruments that were used to clearly show the C/1999 S4 demise) would be headed to the comet.

However, IMHO fragment "B" has proved to be intrinsivally fragile, so the next few weeks could provide further opportunities to witness additional fragmentation events (partial or total), and then we will see if all of us were fooled by the "trailing star traces within the coma".

Cheers,
Giovanni 

Date:  Sat, 15 Apr 2006 05:32:27 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re:[comets-ml] Update on Comet 73P Schwassmann-Wachmann
Thanks Giovanni; true that some morphological characteristics can suggest a breakup
or massive outgassing of component B and it is possible that some fragmentation
(physically observable might have been missed); in fact, Mike Holloway has taken
our April 14 image of the central portion of "B" and enhanced it greatly to reveal
a distinct "knot" some 13" arc from the strong nucleus in the direction of the tail
(our measurement PA 225 degrees). He suggested to me that it may indeed show a
fairly large, albeit somewhat diffuse, fragment following the primary core of "B".
Hopefully Mike will post this negative image today on the Comet-Images forum for
others to deduce and make their own judgments.

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

NOTE that all ASO outgoing mail is protected by McAfee, Zone Alarm and tcworks.net
security
and is certified Virus and Spam-free

Date:  Sat, 15 Apr 2006 12:33:51 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re:[comets-ml] Update on Comet 73P Schwassmann-Wachmann
This image is Dr. Clay's. Taken and owned by Ark Sky Observatory.
Yes I am posting it and feel a bit bad for it. I took the excelent
image and reprocessed it with some software and processes that in the
past has helped me to see things that might be lost. I contacted Dr.
Clay and told him I thought there might be a change but I only do
images and in no way could even tell you how bright this comet is in
the image with my limited knowledge of astronomy. Only with and at
his request do I post this. Things done by the book don't always get
a true result but rules are there for a reason. Thanks, Dr. Clay
Mike Holloway

http://www.fototime.com/59B890B18BC2200/orig.jpg

Date:  Sat, 15 Apr 2006 08:25:07 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re:[comets-ml] Update on Comet 73P Schwassmann-Wachmann
Excellent work and thanks for posting this Mike; indeed it looks like I may have
missed a bit of fragmentation following in the path of component "B"; hopefully you
or other good images will be able to pick up on the comet and get some low density
images that show the core. I really appreciate your spotting this and taking the
time to reprocess out image.

Clay

Date:  Sun, 16 Apr 2006 14:03:40 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Possible fragmentation of 73P-b
Attached are two processings of the same image of Component B of Comet
Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P; the first is normal processing of the comet, clearly
showing a very stellar and distinct nucleus from April 14 through the ASO 0.41m RC
@ f/3.3 using a Kodak CCD KAF0402ME chip; a very beautiful and symmetrical
"butterfly" tail is seen to the southwest of the comet. The second negative and
higher resolution image of the same CCD capture reveals a possible large fragment
relative to the nucleus of this comet.

For those not having an image attached, a summary of these with both images is
posted at ASO:
http://www.arksky.org/smf/index.php?topic=984.msg4671#msg4671

The original image from Petit Jean Mountain south H-45 was taken by P. Clay Sherrod
and posted in full format.
However, veteran comet imager Mike Holloway, of Van Buren, AR, reprocessed this
image to higher scale and resolution to reveal that there might be a SECOND
fragmentary body following in the wake of the primary nucleus; the re-processed ASO
image (in negative to enhance contrast and define slight gradients) is seen
following the "white-on-" wider field image.

Measurements at ASO reveal that the fragment is trailing the primary nucleus some
13 arc seconds in position angle 225.

Nightly results of observations of fragments of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P from ASO
can be found at the Comet Tables:
http://www.arksky.org/php/ctable.php or astrometry under that related link from the
home page.

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

NOTE that all ASO outgoing mail is protected by McAfee, Zone Alarm and tcworks.net
security
and is certified Virus and Spam-free

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sun, 16 Apr 2006 15:35:34 -0700
From:  Doug Snyder 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 24 image animation of 73P-b
I've posted a slightly 'wind-blown' animation of 73P-b on this web page:
http://c3po.cochise.edu/astro/images13a.htm

Don't get seasick looking at it! :)
Right now, off to an Easter dinner!

Doug

----- Original Message -----

Date:  Sun, 16 Apr 2006 16:08:22 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  73P Fragments B  and C April 16, 2005

Date:  Mon, 17 Apr 2006 08:28:56 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Four components of 73P
The four major/brightest components of 73P Schwassmann-Wachmann recorded last
morning (April 17) at ASO-H45 prior to the near-full moon rising too high in the
sky; the remarkable development of component "B" is well recorded.

An attached copy of the results of the "B" component attached (if allowed); the
direct links to images at the ASO website are:

"B" component:
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD65065.jpg and
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD65096.jpg (negative image)

"C" component:
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD650E0.jpg

"G" component:
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD65128.jpg

"R" component:
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD65170.jpg

Clay

Dr. P. Clay Sherrod

Date:  Tue, 18 Apr 2006 03:03:51 -0400
From:  Tim Puckett 
Subject:  images of component "B" just taken
Hi All,

Has been years since I was monitoring current comets.
Getting the bug again.

Here are 3 unfiltered fits files of component "B" just taken
with my 0.60m rc + Site 502AB ccd, three 90 second exposures.
I do not see any fragmentation at this time.

Enhance and enjoy.
http://www.cometwatch.com/73p_b_041806_001.fts
http://www.cometwatch.com/73p_b_041806_002.fts
http://www.cometwatch.com/73p_b_041806_003.fts
Cheers
Tim

Date:  Tue, 18 Apr 2006 10:29:43 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] images of component "B" just taken
> Here are 3 unfiltered fits files of component "B" just taken
> with my 0.60m rc + Site 502AB ccd, three 90 second exposures.
> I do not see any fragmentation at this time.

Hi Tim,
nice shots! It seems that a few arcsec South-West of the main condensation, there is a kind of diffused and elondated feature; in that point, it originates a kind of "widening" of the tail; may be a small cloud of debris, of some kind of sublimating feature?
Cheers,
Giovanni

Date:  Tue, 18 Apr 2006 09:48:14 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] 73P-G is not looking so good
Hmmm....if there is a demise of component "G", it did not show itself well over the
skies of Arkansas this morning.
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD7B7A4.jpg
In fact, this component appears to be developing more rapidly morphologically than
the other components; a very strong tail in P.A. 217 deg., and m1 measured at 11.4;
the coma's inner section is elongating similar to that of the "B" component.

Images of C, B, and R will be posted later on the ASO Comet Tables.

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

NOTE that all ASO outgoing mail is protected by McAfee, Zone Alarm and tcworks.net
security
and is certified Virus and Spam-free
----- Original Message -----
From: "chergen"
To:
Sent: Tuesday, April 18, 2006 8:23 AM
Subject: [comets-ml] 73P-G is not looking so good

> I've been following 73P-B, C and G with the SAO 1.2-m almost nightly
> for the past 11 nights.
>
> www.lpl.arizona.edu/~chergen/73P.html
>
> When comparing contour plots of the near-nucleus region of 73P-G over
> the past week, it is apparent that G is not healthy. A sharp central
> condensation observed on Apr. 12 and 13 UT is no longer visible.
> Similar to 73P-B's appearance last week, G's central condensation is
> elongated towards the anti-solar direction. The brightness of the
> central condensation has also diminished over the past week.
>
> 73P-B still displays a "spine" of material trailing the nucleus in the
> anti-solar direction. Over the past 3 nights, the brightest part of
> the spine has been detached from the nucleus by ~4-5". The appearance
> of the "spine" has not changed much in the past few days. I believe it
> is this spine and its local maximum in brightness that is being
> identified as a secondary in recent images.
>
> Regards,
> Carl
>
> NOTICE: Material quoted or re-posted from the Comets Mailing List should be
indicated by:
>
> Comets Mailing List [date]
> http://www.yahoogroups.com/group/comets-ml
> Yahoo! Groups Links
> 

Date:  Tue, 18 Apr 2006 11:20:34 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Components of 73P
Further development in fragment "B"; images of C, B and G are posted on the ASO
Comet Tables with the links below; note in the negative enhanced image of component
"B" (inset) that a fragment is possible immediately "following" (PA 224 deg.) the
primary component in the PA of the tail. This appears to be the same possible
fragment as documented earlier this week.

Component "C" is growing rapidly in terms of brightness (m1-8.2, April 17) and
overall size of coma.

Links to Component B:
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD7CA14.jpg (negative enhanced)
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD7C9EF.jpg (with high resolution inset of nucleus)

Link to Component C:
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD7CC8A.jpg

Link to Component G:
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD7B7A4.jpg

Details on the particular physical morphology are available on the ASO Comet
Tables, and astrometric positions are posted on that appropriate link from the ASO
home page.

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Wed, 19 Apr 2006 08:49:32 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  73-b fragmentation, ASO
73P Schwassmann-Wachmann component "B", showing clear fragmentation within the
nucleus (inset) and highly elongated coma; magnitude measured = 10.0 (m1, ccd).
Component "G" is developing nicely and seems to be somewhat more active.

Component "B"
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD8F5E9.jpg and
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD8F645.jpg (negative image, enhanced)

Component "C"
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD8F97F.jpg

Component "G"
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBD8FB1C.jpg

Clay

Date:  Wed, 19 Apr 2006 21:59:08 +0200
From:  Tomek 
Subject:  Fragmenting Comet Flyby To Be Webcast
http://www.spacedaily.com/reports/Fragmenting_Comet_Flyby_To_Be_Webcast.html

Slooh.com, an astronomical event Web site, said Tuesday it will begin live monitoring of the approach of Comet 73P
Schwassmann-Wachmann, beginning this week at 9 p.m. Eastern Time.
The comet, which has broken up into 19 separate pieces, is heading for a rendezvous with Earth. Slooh.com broadcasts live celestial
events via its Web site from its telescopes stationed at high altitude at the Institute of Astrophysics of the Canary Islands.

The Web coverage will be hosted by astronomer David Levy, the co-discoverer of Comet Shoemaker-Levy; Bob Berman, a columnist for
Astronomy Magazine; Michael Narlock, head of astronomy at the Cranbrook Institute of Science, and Jeffrey Bass, head of astronomy at
the Milwaukee Public Museum.

"We have assembled the equipment and the commentators for just such a spectacle," said Michael Paolucci, president of Slooh.com. "It
will amaze people to see it live while the experts explain exactly what they are seeing."

First discovered 76 years ago, Comet 73P Schwassmann-Wachmann split into 3 pieces in 1995 and, as a result, it grew brighter by
three orders of magnitude.

The brightest fragment "C" will zoom past Earth at a distance of 0.0735 Astronomical Units (11 million kilometers or about 7 million
miles), and therefore does not threaten the planet. The other two main pieces may pass a little closer at 0.0515 AU and 0.0505 AU,
respectively.

Although rare, comet splits have been reported in the past, with the best-known case the comet Shoemaker Levy, which split into 21
pieces before plowing into Jupiter in 1994.

Launched in 2003 and with members in 60 countries, Slooh.com is the only live online telescope available to the public. Its
patent-pending technology collects the light of distant celestial objects and streams it over the Internet in real time.

Slooh.com's telescopes are configured to optimize the view of thousands of astronomical objects such as the Orion Nebula, the
Whirlpool Galaxy and the Pleiades Cluster -- objects that are nearly impossible to see with backyard telescopes.

The organization's telescopes are stationed five hours ahead of Eastern Standard Time, which enables viewers in North America to see
the night sky during daylight hours in the United States, starting as early as 2 p.m. Eastern Time.

Slooh.com's partners include Discovery.com, Astronomy Magazine, and VSNL, one of the largest broadband companies in India 

Date:  Wed, 19 Apr 2006 22:30:30 +0200
From:  Tomek 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Fragmenting Comet Flyby To Be Webcast
My apologieze for sending this , it is paid web cast .

Date:  Wed, 19 Apr 2006 23:43:46 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  73P-B image
Dear All,

I have just grabbed a few images of this fragment, from Bellatrix
astronomical Observatory, using a C11@f/7 and a SBIG ST-7XME camera;
resulting scale is 0.9"/pixel: seeing was quite good. I managed to sum 8
images, each integrated for 60 seconds. You can see it here:

http://www.bellatrixobservatory.org/73p_b060419.jpg

the "head" is apparently detached, as also shown by the photometric profile,
along the comet axis:

http://www.bellatrixobservatory.org/73p_b060419_sl.jpg

More later,
Gianluca

***********************************************************************
* Gianluca Masi "Two things fill the soul *
* Via Madonna de Loco, 47 with awe and reverence [...]: *
* 03023 Ceccano (FR) the starry sky above me and *

Date:  Fri, 21 Apr 2006 23:19:40 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  73P-B
Dear All,

I had a look right now from Belatrix Observatory and the head of the B
fragment shows a more evident "double" structure when compared to images
grabbed earlier. The two 'dots' shows almost equal brightness.

You can see the pciture here:
http://www.bellatrixobservatory.org/73p_b060421.jpg

More later!

Date:  Sat, 22 Apr 2006 18:24:13 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  73P and Alpha CrB - Vis Obs and image
Hi all,

I visually observed and imaged Schwassmann-Wachmann-3 C (73P-C) last night. It looked great sitting in the same FOV as Alpha Corona Borealis.

CometObs - ( http://groups.yahoo.com/group/CometObs/ )
73P (Schwassmann-Wachmann)
2006 April 21.54 UT: m1 = 8.6, Dia.= 2'.0, DC = 6, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [73P-C is looking good. Nice and bright with a broad 20' long tail in PA 230*. Fairly condensed coma. Alpha CrB is in the same FOV (31' south). 23 day Moon interference. 23? alt in the N. Stellar LM = 14.0 near comet (scope)].

Charles Morris's, 'The New Comet Observations Page' ( http://cometobservation.com/ )
73P (Schwassmann-Wachmann)
2006 April 21.54 UT: m1=8.6, Dia.=2'.0, DC=6, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [73P-C is looking good. Nice and bright with a broad 20' long tail in PA 230*. Fairly condensed coma. Alpha CrB is in the same FOV (31' south). 23 day Moon interference. 23? alt in the N. Stellar LM = 14.0 near comet (scope)].

ICQ (International Comet Quarterly) ( http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/icq/CometMags.html )
73P (Schwassmann-Wachmann)
2006 April 21.54 UT: 8.6, 2'.0 (John Drummond, Gisborne, New Zealand, 41cm f4.5 Reflect);

An image of 73P and Alpha CrB can be seen at...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_schwassmann-wachmann-73p-060421-31x3min@800asa-41cm-f4,5-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/owra5

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Sat, 22 Apr 2006 03:15:51 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Separation of 73P, component B
Showing the "B" components of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P, now split into two nearly
equal (15.4 and 16.0 ccd M1) magnitudes; inset showing a low saturation view of
both components clearly with the "new" fragmentin PA 230 degrees, 7.2" arc from the
primary component.
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBDCA160.jpg

Date:  Sat, 22 Apr 2006 09:06:08 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Primary components of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P (C,B,R, G)
Summary of a very active 73P, the four primary (brightest) components on April 22;
note that all ASO images of 73P can be viewed on the Image Archives or under the
Comets Table on the ASO home page; we have made an effort to obtain and archive all
images at the exact same orientation, scale, density and optical characteristics
for consistency.

Components B and C are easily visible in smaller instruments and are ideally viewed
in wide field, low power instruments; it is my suspicion that component "B" is
become less visible in terms of total brightness due to its current fragmentation.

Component C:
Largest and brightest, with total mag. = 7.9 (102mm refr.); a very strong nucleus
is now detected within a very dense elongated coma (m2=14.4ccd)
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBDCEE96.jpg

Component B: Now fragmented into two nearly equal components
Showing the "B" components of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P, now split into two nearly
equal (15.4 and 16.0 ccd M1) magnitudes; inset showing a low saturation view of
both components clearly with the "new" fragment in PA 230 degrees, 7.2" arc from
the
primary component. NOTE: m1 of primary = 15.4 / secondary = 16.0 ccd
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBDCA160.jpg

Component G:
Component "G" of Schwassmann-Wachmann, in negative showing strong nuclear core
(m2=17.4ccd), total mag. 14.4ccd; note the curving tail and some mottling within
the nuclear core; astrometric measurements reveal a second fragment 5" in PA 213
from primary.
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBDCF09D.jpg

Component R:
Component "R" of Schwassmann-Wachmann, showing weaknuclear core (m2=18.2ccd), total
mag. ~19.0ccd; note the fanning weak tail in PA 215
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBDCF215.jpg

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

NOTE that all ASO outgoing mail is protected by McAfee, Zone Alarm and tcworks.net
security
and is certified Virus and Spam-free 

Date:  Sat, 22 Apr 2006 14:09:26 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Comp.B & G - 04/22/2006
At 0600UT on 04222006 the fragment was close to "chi Boo" - GSC 2030-
1317 a magnitude 5.27 star. This is a 7x40 sec stack on the stars with
an inset stack on the comet and regenerated to show the at least two
fragments of "B". Guess if it were going to hit something they would
be the Killer Bee's. (small funny (very small). I used a 4" FSQ
refractor and FLI Maxcam 10 CCD Bin at 1x1. I gave two links with the
original and a smaller version as the standard.
Standard Size
http://www.fototime.com/517DA35735C8536/standard.jpg
Original Size
http://www.fototime.com/517DA35735C8536/orig.jpg

All images can be found at
http://hometown.aol.com/tricks46/myhomepage/photo.html?mtbrand=AOL_US

Thanks, Mike H.

Subject:  Comp. C - 04/22/2006
This is a 3x40 second image stacked on the stars. Deep image for such
a short exposure. Used the 4" FSQ & FLI Maxcam 10 CCD. 0215UT
04222006.

croped.

Date:  Sat, 22 Apr 2006 23:16:28 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  73P-C-B-G Mosaic
Greetings. This is a full mosaic with the 3 fragments. It
took a bunch of images, over 20 not counting the dozens of subframes,
and a hardrive that wanted to give up a couple of times working with
the almost 900mb to start. Anyway this gives a perspective of the
distance between fragments at a med. time of 0600ut - 04/22/2006.
At one time the working image was 9600 pix wide but publishing that
was a problem so I reduced it to 2000 pix wide.
Thanks
Mike H.

Standard
http://www.fototime.com/45A75A52E4AA806/standard.jpg
Original
http://www.fototime.com/45A75A52E4AA806/orig.jpg

Date:  Sun, 23 Apr 2006 11:55:12 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  73P components C, B, G
Images of three primary components of 73P from ASO_H45 this morning:

Components B1 and B2
Showing component "B" of comet Schwassmann-Wachmann; both segments of the now-split
nucleus are clearly shown; primary nucleus is mag. 15.2ccd / secondary 16.0ccd;
separation appears to be about the same (~8") as previous night.
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBDE6B16.jpg
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBDE6B44.jpg (negative enhanced)

Component C
Image showing component "C" of comet Schwassmann-Wachmann; magnitude is now 7.9
(102mm refr.), tail in PA 221, with an overall (ccd) diameter of 2.5' arc
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBDE6BE9.jpg

Component G
Image showing component "G" of comet Schwassmann-Wachmann; magnitude is now 11.4
(ccd) Note the increasingly prominent jet-like spike in the tail
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBDE6CF0.jpg
---------------------

Date:  Mon, 24 Apr 2006 10:37:43 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Two components of 73P-b / Componets C and G
Component "B" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73-P; the new component has drifted to a
distance of 12.34" from the primary nucleus in PA 220 deg; brightness of each is:
14.9 primary and 15.7 secondary, ccd. Note that neither of the two images
indicates a possible new trailing fragment as has been suggested:
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBDFA7B5.jpg
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBDFA7EB.jpg (enhanced negative)

Component "C" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73-P; steady brightening now to 7.9 (visual,
102mm refr.), without much development in terms of strength of tail; note the very
stellar and prominent nucleus of the comet (inset), which is very difficult to
discern visually or via ccd because of the density of the large coma.
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBDFAADF.jpg

Component "G" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73-P; very fine developing tail, with
strongly arched coma/nuclear center and some suggestion of possible fragmentation
near center; note the negative inset showing some defined spikes in widely fanned
tail.
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBDFAD54.jpg

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

NOTE that all ASO outgoing mail is protected by McAfee, Zone Alarm and tcworks.net
security
and is certified Virus and Spam-free

Description : 73P, fragment B in outburst

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/Remanzacco%20Observatory/73P-B_2006April24_Sos.jpg

Date:  Wed, 26 Apr 2006 17:49:03 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  73P B Split Nucleus April 23
I measured a centroid-to-centroid spacing of the two nuclei of 16 +/-
2 arc seconds in 0330 UT 23 April images. I believe Doc Clay
reported 12 arc seconds separation on the same night.

For the first time ever I was able to guide on the head and take 6-
minute subframes. The relative motion was 2.5 arc seconds per minute
so guiding really helped me obtain a good SNR.

In past attempts the autoguider would latch onto a star in the
comet's path and get lost. On my 23 April 0330 UT imaging session
there were no stars brighter than magnitude 16 in the comet's path.
That seldom occurs.

Images and supporting data at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Thu, 27 Apr 2006 13:18:36 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Comet 73P (S-W3) with a .7 degree tail
Hi all,

here's an image of Comet 73P-C (Schwassmann-Wachmann 3-C) I took with an 8cm f7.5 ED80 Skywatcher refractor - 5x5 minutes@f7.5@800ISO... The FOV is cropped is about 1.6 x 1.0 degrees (cropped).

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_73p-schwassmann-wachmann3-060425-5x5min@800asa-8cm-f7,5-ed-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/fa3d9

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Thu, 27 Apr 2006 09:52:55 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  73P - Remarkable transformation of component "B"
An outstanding night of activity with comet 73P....each major (four) components has
shown some incredible transformation.

Component "B" of comet Schwassmann-Wachmann, showing a remarkable transformation of
morphology between the nights of April 24 and April 27 (UT); note that the
fragments of the comet "B", particularly the brighter fragment "aq" was not seen,
even in high resolution imaging; no secondary fragments were found. At this time
component "B" rivals component "C" in brightness (8.3 and 7.9 m1 respectively)
Component "B":
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBE38E24.jpg

Component "C" of comet Schwassmann-Wachmann, showing a very pronounced coma with
highly differentiated layers; note the inset which suggests that this fragment is
still intact and Has NOT fragmented. Magnitude 7.9
Component "C":
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBE39263.jpg

Component "G" of comet Schwassmann-Wachmann, showing a strong indication of major
fragmentation of the primary component; note the mottled appearance of the nebulous
area following throughout the immediate tail area from the nucleus which is clearly
offset slightly north and west from physical center.
Component "G":
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBE39481.jpg

Component "R" of comet Schwassmann-Wachmann, in a fairly substantial outburst over
the past few evenings; the comet is now at mag. (m1) 14.1 ccd and has become far
more concentration (5/9) since April 24
Component "R"
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBE39628.jpg

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

security
and is certified Virus and Spam-free

Date:  Thu, 27 Apr 2006 12:55:45 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] 73P - Remarkable transformation of component "B"
Hello Maciej...
On April 24, only three nights ago, we measured component "R" at magnitude 17.4
(m2, nuclear, via CCD); our physical description revealed it to be very obscure and
faint with very little central condensation (3/9) and quite diffuse. So this
outburst is most definitely something that has happened only in the past couple of
days.

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Thu, 27 Apr 2006 21:28:42 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  73P-c-04272006
Hello. I agree with Rolando. What can you say about the Hubble and
other big scope images. They are great! I can't do what they do so I
do what I do.
From the 27th 0650UT. C is a bright comet and increasing. This
image covers about 1 x 1.5 deg. of sky and it appears that one frame
will not cover the developing tail to the W and S in the next few
days. In this image N is up and E to the left. 3x40 sec exp with a 4"
refractor and FLI ccd. Thanks, Mike H.
standard
http://www.fototime.com/F2248A3C606AB62/standard.jpg
original
http://www.fototime.com/F2248A3C606AB62/orig.jpg

outgrowing my chip or I would have expanded my coverage. Structure in
the tail is showing and it looks great. The fragment G is also shown.
Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Fri, 28 Apr 2006 03:12:21 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Developing tail in 73P, component "B"
Component "B" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P; showing new development in tail and very
significant brightening (m1=7.8ccd) in past 24 hours; the overall diameter of the
coma can be traced to better and 4' arc with some elongation in PA 221,
Image now posted on ASO Image Archives:\
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBE489B8.jpg

Clay

Dr. P. Clay Sherrod

Date:  Fri, 28 Apr 2006 08:13:26 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO - Major components of 73P
Component "B"
Component "B" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P; showing new development in tail and very
significant brightening (m1=7.8ccd) in past 24 hours; the overall diameter of the
coma can be traced to better and 4' arc with some elongation in PA 221
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBE489B8.jpg

Component "C"
Component "C" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P; showing a very distinct and brightening
nucleus, with strengthening tail in PA 221 deg
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBE4CC93.jpg

Component "G"
Component "G" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P; two very distinct nuclear fragments
appear, aligned nearly E-W offset from physical center of comet coma; note the very
faint but fanned tail
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBE4CE38.jpg

Component "R"
Component "R" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P; brightening continues with some degree
of mottling behind (anti-sun direction)nucleus within coma; some fragmentary
appearance suspected; very wide stubby tail and broad uniform nucleus; ;M1=14.2ccd
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBE4D00F.jpg

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)

From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Split of "C"? was: [Comet-Images] 73P-C-False color-04272006
This is excellent work Mike; knowing your methodical and very particular and
cautious way of post-processing, I am certain that you have shown certainly two
fragments, possibly three or four, in the "C" component nucleus on this April 27
image. Hopefully others can obtain some high resolution images of this soon, but
it appears that the US and much of the western world has inclement weather at the
moment.

Subject:  Re: 73P-C-False color-04272006
WOW! Mike, nice job!! Now thats what I call a dynamic comet!!!
We were out last night at 00:00 EDT and at 350x we thought we were
seeing something going on in the nuclear area! I also noticed that the
B component seemed to have settled down with an elongated central
condensation. G component was almost not visible visually but the R
component was a much easier visual object.
Absolutely awesome image, Mike! Thank you for sharing!
Mark S Deprest

Date:  Sat, 29 Apr 2006 21:09:30 -0000
From:  sabiajohn 
Subject:  New image of 73/P R  Uploaded
I've added a negative image of 73/P R fragmention to the Photos section
under Miscellaneous. Used a Televue NP 101 refractor and a SBIG ST-7
camera on April 29, 2006 4:28 UT. There are 3 x 30 second exposures
stacked with AIP4Windows.

Note: The comet is near center. I do not know what the feature is on
the left. It was capture on 4 the individual frames and trailed with
the stars on the one bad image of the FOV of 73/P R.

It did not show up on any other frames that night so I do not suspect
it to be an image artifact.

John D Sabia
Clarks Summit PA USA 

Date:  Sun, 30 Apr 2006 12:23:41 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: 73P-C-False color-04272006
--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "ligustri rolando"
wrote:
>
> > You have got to love computers and modern CCD equiptment. Mike H
> > http://fototime.com/17239AFD47254DC/orig.jpg
>
> GASP!
> Is the component C also shattered?
>
> regards
>
> Rolando
>

Rolando. This image was not said to be anything more than false
color added to a B&W image. I did not want anyone to think this was
true color. Also I don't know why the center came out looking as it
does. It is a combination of 3 images stacked on the brightest pix
of the comet head. All 3 images were of the same quality and taken
within a two minute time span. Perhaps a star is behind the comet
showing through, I don't know. The small bright area below the
double center is also not known. I allowed the computer to find and
assighn colors to dim and bright levels.
It is always dangerous to claim anything without confirmation by
others or taking another set of images which give the same results.
I have not done because of heavy rain and T-Storms. Let me show you
another image taken on 4/18/2006 and never published of B.
http://www.fototime.com/A89A6D4CE34435E/orig.jpg
I suspected that Fragment B was in more than 2 pieces but dare not
publish and probably should not now as I can only use the computer to
show areas not pieces. I was glad to see many fragments imaged by
the large scopes and find a little satisfaction in my image as
although skeptics will say they see nothing, and I respect there
opinion, I did..
Getting back to C for a minute, why would it not be the next step
for this fragment to come apart. Is this not a part of the same
comet and with almost everything else breaking up why would C be any
different. I hope it comes all to pieces and puts on the best show
ever! At the least, this C fragment shoud be sheading some big hunks
of skin.
Your excellent images, Rolando, will in the future confirm what
others suspect and the process of confirmation will continue to show
or not show what is or is not there. My skin is not to thick so I
tend to be really conservative about what I publish.
Thanks,
Mike H 

Date:  Sun, 30 Apr 2006 13:10:44 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO - Main components of 73P, April 30
Not much change overall in the four major components of 73P in the past two days.
ASO Observations and measurements from this morning (April 30): (astrometry posted
under the Astrometry Pages link on home page, and physical details posted daily
under Comet Tables)

Component "C"
A very bright component "C" with inset that possibly hints at some elongation or
separation of the nuclear central mass; comet is mag. 7.3 visual, with m2-13.5ccd
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBE7AFE7.jpg

Component "B"
Now equally as bright as "C" this showing component "B" which has a somewhat more
rounded coma (ellipse with "C");with inset showing that the "aq" secondary fragment
has now greatly faded or disappeared. Nucleus appears very much singular
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBE7B403.jpg

Component "G"
Component "G" is still weak, but nucleus shows a curious diffuse appearance,
perhaps somewhat of an arc; comet was a bit brighter, Mag. 15.5 ccd, and the
diameter measured at 20"
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBE7B6A2.jpg

Component "R"
Component "R" at magnitude 14.2 (ccd), with strong tail in PA 211 deg, m2=16.8ccd;
note that the two faint objects in the anti-sun direction are 18th mag. field
stars, not fragments
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBE7B8C2.jpg

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)

Date:  Mon, 01 May 2006 11:57:18 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  73P, fragment B
Dear All,

I just uploaded an image of 73P, fragment B. It is the sum of 36 x 30
seconds images, grabbed between 20:52 and 21:13 UT on Apr. 30.
C11@f/7.3, CCD SBIG ST-7XME, scale 0.9"/pixel. North is up, East on the
left. DDP scaling.

The image is available here:

http://www.bellatrixobservatory.org/73pb_060430.jpg

Its aspect partly remembers me that observed on Apr. 19: a condensation
is visible, followed by a more diffuse, but relatively bright zone,
still providing a double-picked brightness profile.

More date will be published later on.

Cheers,
Gianluca

Date:  Tue, 02 May 2006 14:50:05 -0000
From:  Dave Kodama 
Subject:  Wide view of some pieces of Comet P/73
Here's a wide view of Comet P/73 Schwassmann-Wachmann from Sunday morning
showing the spread of some of the pieces:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2006/0429/2.htm

This was a 30 minute exposure at f/3.3 on E100S 4x5 film (pushed 1 stop)
through a Borg 125EDF2.8 astrograph. This was tracked on the stars, not
the comet, so the comet fragments are smeared.

Dave 

Date:  Tue, 02 May 2006 15:25:38 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO, Components "B" and "C" of 73P, May 1
Component "B" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 3, showing singularity of the nucleus on May
1, 2006; note that the core does appear to be elongated in the tail direction (216
deg); magnitude (visual) = 7.8; m2=10.1ccd
Conditions very poor, imaging between storms and clouds.
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBEA7A5E.jpg

Component "C" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 3, very concentrated coma, maintaining both
size and intensity; some brightening of tail seems evident; magnitude (visual) =
7.1
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBEA7CA9.jpg

Clay

Date:  Wed, 03 May 2006 17:46:51 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  73P B  Split Nucleus Movie April 23
I've added a short movie to my web page illustrating the rapid
motion of 73P-B against the fixed star field. It comprises 7 six-
minute frames during which time the comet moves 1.8 arc minutes.

Tips for comet movies:
1) Crop around comet to keep file size small
2) Align on stars, not comet, for smooth viewing
3) Use minimum bit depth and lots of compression to keep file size
small
4) Throw out frames that do not follow a smooth comet motion

I emphasize small file size because of late I've seen comet movies
of 10-20 MB file size that would look just as good at 100 kB and
would attract more viewers.

Note: Mine is a dial-up-friendly movie. It is only 68 kB.

Movie and supporting data at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Thu, 04 May 2006 05:10:53 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  73P-B fragments
Hi all,

Just finished a very fruitful session and this fragment looks, of course,
quite interesting.

As you can see here:

http://www.bellatrixobservatory.org/73pb_060504.jpg

there are at least two possible minor fragments there (oh, yes, nothing
compared to Carl's images :) ), SW from the main condensation. N is up, E on
the left.

That picture is the sum of 60, 20 seconds images, the properly processed.
Images grabbed around 01.30UT, May 4 2006.

Date:  Thu, 04 May 2006 17:04:26 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO: 73P- component B, May 4
>From ASO on May 4 under poor conditions, Component "B" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P,
showing insets with elongation indication a possibility of secondary component in
direction of tail (PA 211 deg), and slightly dimmer than the main component;
nuclear mag. = 10.1, visual mag. = 7.7; note that image and estimates were with
comet very low on horizon prior to approaching storms.
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBED35EB.jpg

Clay

Dr. P. Clay Sherrod

Date:  Fri, 05 May 2006 02:09:35 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  73P-B
Hi all,

this image is just few minutes old and still shows a number of small
fragments around the main condensation. The latter is apparently undergoing
a major break-up, as evident from my images. I processed the current frame
to underline the small fragments, while a better view of the main
condensation (as well as a nhigh S/N of the present image) will follow.

http://www.bellatrixobservatory.org/73pb_060505.jpg

Cheers,
Gianluca

Date:  Fri, 05 May 2006 14:13:20 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  73P-B: final images
Dear comet enthusiasts,

I'm pleased to show the final version of my 73P-B images. The summarizing
picture is available here:

http://www.bellatrixobservatory.org/73pb_060505.jpg

I added a number of details about my setup and imaging technique on the same
picture, so I kindly invite those interested to check the image above.

In brief, I used a short (20 sec) integration time, collecting up to 100
frames to be added later on. I did the all the processing on that master
frame, to assure the higher S/N. Scale is about 1"/pixel.

Wishing you clear skies,
Gianluca

Date:  Fri, 05 May 2006 14:00:51 -0000
From:  gvnn64 
Subject:  73P-B on 2006, May 5.3

Giovanni and Ernesto 

Date:  Sat, 06 May 2006 02:09:38 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO:  Components of 73P:  Duplicity in "B"; C, R, and G
Component "B" of Schwassmann-Wachmann3; note the duplicity of the nucleus
(b=10.1ccd; b2 [aq?]=11.3ccd); two components were measured 7.2 arc seconds
separation in PA 218 deg; tail in PA 224; coma is very elongated in tail angle and
very compressed (DC=7/9)
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBEF03A8.jpg

Component "C" of Schwassmann-Wachmann3; without a doubt the brightest of all 73P
components; tail angle is changing (232 deg), while coma is very compressed and
uniformly bright (m1=7.1 visual); note that coma is about twice as long (in tail
angle) as it is wide at this point (1.2 x 2.3' ccd)
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBEF0540.jpg

Component "R" of Schwassmann-Wachmann3; at total magnitude 16.4 (ccd) this
component is fading rapidly within the past 7 days; tail is quite extended and can
be traced on computer for 5.1' arc in PA 217 deg. Very tenuous and diffuse without
much central condensation...however, mottling in tail direction behind center of
coma may indicate fragmentation
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBEF06D6.jpg

Component "G" at this time is very diffuse and quite difficult, with a nuclear mag.
of 19.1 ccd; the coma is very tenuous and large without a good astrometric center;
total magnitude estimated at 18.2, with very faint wide tail in PA 221 deg.

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

NOTE that all ASO outgoing mail is protected by McAfee, Zone Alarm and tcworks.net
security
and is certified Virus and Spam-free 

Date:  Sat, 06 May 2006 11:14:43 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  73P-B: still many fragments around
I all,

here is a preliminary image coming from a session performed
atCampocatino Observatory - Italy, using a 25cm-f/9 APO refractor + CCD
SBIG STL-1001E. The images were colleced on May 5, around 23:30UT. 30 x
60 seconds frames were median combined then properly processed to show
the fragments around the B component.

The image is available here:

http://www.bellatrixobservatory.org/73pb_060506.jpg

The observers were G. Masi, F. Mallia and U. Tagliaferri. Image
processing by G. Masi.

More soon,
Gianluca 

Date:  Sat, 06 May 2006 16:16:49 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  73-P: B, C, G, R and a possibly new component
Dear All,

I'm pleased to introduce the final, summarizing pictures from last night,
when my team imaged several fragment. Close to R, we saw a possibly new (I
was not able to identify it) fragment.

This 'poster' image is available here:

http://www.bellatrixobservatory.org/73p_060506.jpg

Cheers,
Gianluca

From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  73p breakup
Another week until closest encounter with Earth encounter with 73p
Nice photos almost daily at
spaceweather.com
especially lately with fragment B

Also look in the archives for more pictures of the comet and fragments -
really nice pics too at
May 4 and April 26 archives
http://antwrp.gsfc.nasa.gov/apod/archivepix.html

Remember if you are trying for the comet awards silver or gold
each fragment count as one sighting
but you must have a different sketch/picture/or ccd image for each and the
related information

Starry Night Pro (my choice) has finally started poping up the coordiates for
the bigger fragment finally

? let me know

Date:  Sun, 07 May 2006 17:31:26 -0000
From:  Howie 
Subject:  Comet 73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann
Comet 73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann.
*** If anyone is going to image it tonight at 10:30ish while it is
next to M57. You will have to be ready and fast. You will also need a
"low eastern horizon" view. The head was almost as large as M57. This
will make an incredible picture as it will be only a few arc minutes
away from M57. A once in a lifetime shot.
______
Howie
15" Obsession #821 /Argo Navis/ServoCAT Jr./Meade DSI CCD 

Date:  Sun, 07 May 2006 21:38:20 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Reminder:  Schwassmann-Wachmann 3 at Messier 57!
Hello to all....
A quick reminder that in about one hour local time, Comet Schwassmann-Wachmann 3
will be passing by the famous Ring Nebula (M57) in Lyra....so close that you will
be able to view and/or photograph both in the same medium power field of
view....this is an incredible once in a lifetime opportunity; the comet will be
brighter than the Ring and appear somewhat brighter overall. An extraordinary
not-to-be-missed photo op.

The constellation and objects will be very low in the northeast sky for this event,
and close pass is between the hours of 3 and 4 UT (about 10-11 p.m. CDT).
Observers in the eastern US are favored with the constellation somewhat higher in
the sky at the time of closest pass.

Dr. Clay
--------------------
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

NOTE that all ASO outgoing mail is protected by McAfee, Zone Alarm and tcworks.net
security
and is certified Virus and Spam-free

Date:  Mon, 08 May 2006 19:49:05 -0000
From:  Johannes Schedler 
Subject:  73P meets M57
As I missed all previous meetings of comets the past years due to bad
weather I was lucky today.
I nearly spent the whole last night in my observatory, chasing 73P
approaching M 57. Clouds rolled in from time to time, but cleared
right in time.
The awesome shot from Stefan showing the tiny fragments in B motivated
me the first time to image a comet at my full f/10 setup (4m f/l).
The comet moves very fast, so a guiding on the nucleus is essential
and I used my TEC140 with the external STL guider and 200 sec
subexposures at 2x2 bin.

I invested 4000 sec for the L files to have an optimum S/N ratio and
to get rid of the stars when using the median combine.

Unfortunately no subfragments were visible even after applying all
possible processing tricks. It seems that today even Stefan could not
show them with his 0.9 m setup.

Nevertheless I made seperate exposures of the M57 area before the
comet reached this area. Then I blendedn the seperately processed
comet with the Star field.

The huge magnification makes the comet much bigger than it appears in
visual mode, still I had fun with the processing:

http://panther-observatory.com/gallery/comets/doc/73P_F10_M57cass.htm

Enjoy,

Johannes 

Date:  Mon, 08 May 2006 22:08:35 +0200
From:  "H.Luethen" 
Subject:  73P using a Mintron on a Celestron 8
Just did stack the images of P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 3 from Mai 4-5.
Used a Celestron 8, focal length reduced to about 900mm using a
binocular lens. Camera: Mintron, video recorded on Camcorder for 10-15
minutes. Images stacked with Fitswork.

Have fun
Hartwig
----------------
Fragment A
http://home.tiscali.de/astrohardy/mintron/sw3/fragmenta.jpg

Fragment B (f=900mm)
http://home.tiscali.de/astrohardy/mintron/sw3/fragmentb_800.jpg

Fragment B (f=2000mm), Sekanina-Larson-filter
http://home.tiscali.de/astrohardy/mintron/sw3/fragmentb_2000.jpg

Fragment G
http://home.tiscali.de/astrohardy/mintron/sw3/fragment_g.jpg

M. Gembec, Jablonec n.N., Czech Republic 

Date:  Tue, 09 May 2006 03:32:11 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  A remarkable change in 73P, "B"
A magnificent view of the "B" component of Schwassmann-Wachmann 3, showing two "bow
arches" in the sunward direction of a very pronounced, singular nucleus
(m2=9.9ccd); total magnitude (6.9) of the comet tonight is considerably brighter
that just two nights ago and a very pronounced spike in PA 233 has developed; high
resolution CCD imaging of the core of the comet reveals only a single bright
nucleus.
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBF30E15.jpg

Fragment "C": Still maintaining an elongated coma, uniformly bright (m1=7.3ccd),
considerably smaller and less bright at this time than component "B"; long narrow
tail; nucleus is singular in high resolution views.

Both components are quite easily visible and nebulous in appearance in a standard 8
x 50 telescope finder; the "B" component is spectacular in 10 x 50 binoculars in
spite of strong moonlight to the west.

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

security
and is certified Virus and Spam-free

Date:  Tue, 09 May 2006 20:34:56 +0200
From:  Klaas Jobse 
Subject:  Hello
Hi,

I am new to this group, learn more about my (meteor) history at:
http://www.klaas-jobse.net/cyclops/
The "Comets" link leads to what I still call, my trial and error page.

Comets have always fascinated my and the relationship with meteors is
obvious.
So about about two years ago I started to do some inquiries in the "comet
market".
I became a member of the Dutch Comet Section and did some try outs with
photographic and CCD techniques. At the moment I use my 250/4 Newtonian
and 350D/ST7E.
For wide field images I use my 300/2.8 Canon lens. Both are mounted on an
AP1200 GTO mount. Later this year I hope to recieve my 12" Astrograph and
CCD.
I also became a member of the RAS Observatory NM USA to do some remote
imaging when the weather overhere is bad.
My location is close to the South-West Coast of the Netherlands. We have
about 50 useful clear nights a year. A 12 inch Meade SCT is also available,
this instrument is owned by the Public Observatory Philippus Lansbergen
witch is based in the nearby city of Middelburg.
Because of lichtpollution reasons they had to place there Observatory on my
property, next to my own.
My observing site is not free of lichtpollution but it is quit good for
Dutch standards.

I am hoping to learn a lot from this group!

Klaas Jobse

Date:  Tue, 09 May 2006 22:18:53 +0200
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  AW: [Comet-Images] Hello
Hi Klaas!

Welcome to this group!

Here you will find comet pictures posted and news about comets away from the
"pretty picture" one way shooters of bright comets, who, looking back to the
last day, copying the fast moving comet to the star field or object where he
"must" be ...

I wish you much fun with comet photography!

Gerald

Date:  Thu, 11 May 2006 09:00:46 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO: Components "B" (very bright) and "C" of 73P
Component "B" of Schwassmann-Wachmann3, showing some diminishing of overall
turbulent activity from the past week; however, the coma is still very interesting,
being quite fanned or butterfly shaped as opposed to the remarkable "manta-ray"
shape of May 9; note that the nucleus (m2-8.8ccd) is singular with no bright
fragments trailing; spike (ion) tail in PA 233 has now seemingly vanished. The
comet is MAGNITUDE 4.7 overall at this time, about twice the intensity total as
component "C"; the image at LEFT demonstrates the comet's overall size (coma) and
brightness and is a single unprocessed 20-sec exposure; at RIGHT is an enhanced
image, showing the delicate coma, quite uniform throughout, with the magnitude 8.8
(ccd) nucleus evident, somewhat elongated.
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBF5FDEB.jpg

Component "C" of Schwassmann-Wachmann3, showing a very elongated, almost oblate
coma; note the considerable morphological differences in "C" and "B"; the nucleus
(m2-10.1ccd) is singular with no bright fragments trailing; The comet is
MAGNITUDE 6.7 overall at this time, about half the intensity total as component "B"
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBF5FEFD.jpg

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)
Harvard MPC H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC H44 (Cascade Mountain)
http://www.arksky.org/

NOTE that all ASO outgoing mail is protected by McAfee, Zone Alarm and tcworks.net
security
and is certified Virus and Spam-free 

Date:  Thu, 11 May 2006 21:39:39 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  73P-B-05112006-With Tails
Greetings. A good night but with a bright Moon. Single 20 second
image in a rich star field. Strange look to the area ahead of the
comet. Looks almost as if the bow waves from a couple of days ago have
reversed angle. I have an inset which is 20x20 second exposures with a
median combine. PS was used to bring out the double tail. I say ion
but will let others confirm which tails these are. 0900ut with the 4"
and FLI Maxcam 10 ccd. N is up and E to the left.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/227B12FB7B36449/orig.jpg 

Date:  Thu, 11 May 2006 22:19:22 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  73P-C-05112006
Greetings. 10x20 second images make this image with an average
combine. The inset is 10x20 second images with a median combine. N up
and E left. 4" refractor and Maxcam 10 ccd.
Thanks, Mike H

http://www.fototime.com/0E9997398B78B4E/orig.jpg

Date:  Fri, 12 May 2006 09:24:42 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  "B" is waning (?) ; ASO, Comet 73P on May 12
Component "B" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 3; note that the comet has faded over one
magnitude from two nights prior (m1=7.3); the nucleus (m2=9.9ccd) continues to be
singular, although somewhat elongated; exposure is only 20sec. to negate the rapid
proper motion of the comet at this time; the "manta-ray" appearance of this comet
only 5 days ago has waned to a very broad and fanning tail; no evidence of sharp
ion tail on May 12.
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBF75546.jpg

Component "C" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 3; note the sunward side of the coma, the
comet presenting two nearly equal segments of coma pr. and following the nucleus at
this time. Coma continues elongated and oval, but is much less intense/dense at
this time; total magnitude = 8.0 with a coma diameter measured (ccd) at 40",
substantially smaller than during previous weeks. 20sec. to negate the rapid
proper motion of the comet at this time.
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBF756E3.jpg

Clay
--------------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC H45 (Petit Jean Mountain South)

Date:  Sat, 13 May 2006 01:54:55 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  73P-B-05112006 Full Tail Image
The tail structure in the comet was there but very hard to bring out.
I have worked on this information for hours and finally decided on the
unprocessed image. I reduced from the original 2150 pix wide to 1200.
Covers about 1.5 deg wide. This is the full image. Best thing to do
is load the image, adjust your contrast bright and stand back from the
screen. The things I do for a little tail.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/F5BA8F206E3E240/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 13 May 2006 10:06:04 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Imaging bright fast moving comets in Color with CCDOps Track and Accumulate - Life just got immensely easier
The following image of comet 73P Fragment B was taken
this morning using the CCDOps Track and Accumulate
(TA) feature using a ST-2000XCM single shot color CCD.
The program took 20 subframes of 15 second each, plus
a dark frame too, and aligned them on the comet
centroid and stacked them automatically.

http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/imagefiles/73P-B-05132006-TA-20x15s.jpg

LRGB color image was created from the SBIG color image
file using CCDSoft and then processed a little with
Adobe Photoshop CS2 (curves, levels, layer masks,
etc..)

Thanks to the SBIG yahoo user who posted the recent
comment about Track and Accumulate working with color
one shot cameras!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I can hardly believe how easy that was compared to the
tedious manual way.

The comet is so bright and moving so fast that this
method beats everything else.

Then the sun came up.... 

Date:  Sat, 13 May 2006 10:33:59 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Comet 73P fragment B from Friday Morning May 12, 2006
Comet 73P fragment B from Friday Morning May 12, 2006

http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/73P-B-05122006.html

30 x 30 second subframes taken with ST-2000XCM

Manually aligned each color component subframe in
CCDSoft (~120 total: 30 R, 30 G, 30 B, 30 L)

Web page above shows three results for average, add,
and median combine.

I was surprised to find how much median combine dulls
the background stars, but am pleased with all three
results.

Any comments are appreciated.

Thanks to Dennis Persyk who posted about "average"
combine recently. It does look so much more clearer.

Any hints how to registered images to get fine startrails ?

Stefan Beck

"Astrophotography with small telescopes auf Deutsch" 

Date:  Sun, 14 May 2006 19:51:03 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: New images and a question.
Stefan. The software I use to align and combine images (CCDSoft) has
a magnifier or enlarger. It is sometimes helpfull with the bright
core of a comet to do an extreme histogram on the images to get rid
of any excess brightness blead. I then enlarge with the magnifing
tool untill the brightest pix is showing in each image. Select the
bright pix or which ever looks to be the same pix in every image and
do an align. When you close these images they should revert to there
original size. Do a image combine to see if star trails are close to
straight. It is good to make duplicate files of the originals before
starting so when you screw up you have the originals to go back to
and preserve your work. An automatic selector on a bright comet core
will often select different areas and give the uneven star trails.
Hope this can help.
Mike H.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, Stefan Beck
wrote:
>
> Hi list,
>
> I have taken some images of fragments B + C.
> What happend with Q and J ?

Wachmann_3_12052006.html

Date:  Sun, 14 May 2006 15:11:38 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: New images and a question.
Thanks for this tip Mike.

After zooming in on the coma, clicking the lower left
button on the Histogram tool (reset background and
range) and then adjusting the right slider sure makes
the centroid center on the right pixels.

Much better than the way I was doing it.

From:  Ralf Vandebergh 
Subject:  2006/05/15_73P/SW-3 fragment B image
To the observers,

This is 73P-SW-3 fragment B from last night, May 15. Circumstances were poor(cirrus clouds,full-moon and twilight)
It's appearance seems not much changed since the last images on May 11 and 12.
A nice dust-tail is still obvious.

http://img305.imageshack.us/img305/377/73pb200605150210p32tu.jpg

imaging data (ATK-1HS/10´´ Newtonian) Regards,Ralf.
(local time).

Date:  Mon, 15 May 2006 15:47:32 +0200
From:  Klaas Jobse 
Subject:  about jets on 73P-B
Hello,

My latest picture of 73P-B on 05-11 shows at least one jet pointed sunward.

A second image the same night shows maybe a second jet. This image was
exposed twice as long as the first one.

I used the Larson-Sekanina filter to show the jets more clearly.

As I am a newbie is this field, some question arises.

Are there really two jets visible in my image?

As I understand, the LS filter is a "dangerous" one to use.

Is there some literature available on how to use the LS filter properly on
comet images?

If I have a good look on the monitor screen then there really seem to be two
jets visible in the original (30x25s stacked) image.

Both images can be seen on top of
http://www.klaas-jobse.net/cyclops/cometspage.htm

Comments are always welcome.

Klaas Jobse

Date:  Mon, 15 May 2006 11:11:05 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 73p B & C 2006.05.15

----- Original Message -----

Date:  Mon, 15 May 2006 20:50:58 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images
> What software does 1/r coma correction as is shown in
> this image here and discussed in Comets II processing
> techniques chapter.

Hi Charles,
it is a special image processing tool prepared by Martino Nicolini (Cavezzo Observatory) for the CARA collaboration (http://cara.uai.it).

As you commented, it creates a "virtual" coma that obeys the 1/r theoretical photometric profile produced by the dust distribution (the brightest pixel in the optocenter is used as starting value for the rest of the the calculations). This virtual coma is then subtracted from the actual image; in this way any departure from the theoretical 1/r coma profile is enhanced (tails, jets, arclets, etc.).

Another software we use within the CARA for comae studies, is the common rotational gradient filtering (also known as "Larson-Sekanina"), and the Azimuthal Median Subtraction (also commented in Comets II) where you build up a synthetic coma averaging the real one through a series of consecutive annulus starting from the optocenter.

It must be said that the interpretation of the details obtained with these techniques are not always straightforward, and some cross-check analysis among the different image processing packages is needed, in order to decrease the probability of misinterpretations. Obviusly these softwares are supposed to work with images where the S/N is as high as possible.

Cheers,
Giovanni

Date:  Tue, 16 May 2006 15:18:43 -0000
From:  Adrian Jones 
Subject:  73/P-B Jet  and animation on May 12
Hi. This image shows some hint of the jet on the B fragment. It was
taken in the early hours of May 12, using an SC3 modified webcam on
LX200 10" at f/7. Sum of 254 x 3 sec exposures.

http://universalconstant.com/73P-B_20060512.07.jpg

In fact, these multiple short exposures were taken by my auto-guider
camera whilst I was actually imaging with a piggy-backed 80mm f/5
refractor. It just seemed a shame not to save and use the guide cam.
shots too :-)

If you're interested, here is a DivX animation of the shots taken with
the 'real' imaging scope. It covers approximately 80 minutes of the
comet's passage through Cygnus.

WARNING: Large file (930 KB), and you will need a DivX codec to view it:
http://universalconstant.com/73P-B_12May2006_0140-0259UT.avi

The animation is 135 x 30 sec exposures taken with an Artemis-285
camera, 2x2 binning, and 80mm f/5 achromat. The frame is approximately
one degree wide. The bright star towards the top of the frame is 19
Cyg. (magnitude 5) and the faintest stars visible are approx. magnitude
13-14. The brightening of frames towards the end of the animation is
due to the first glimmers of dawn light, but exaggerated by the fixed
histogram stretch I applied to every frame.

Adrian

Subject:  S-W 3B animation
Hello!
At http://www.filelodge.com/files/room26/719805/sw3b.gif you can see
an animation with comet Schwassmann-Wachmann 3 B. The animation is
composed of individual frames shot on friday night with a Canon EOS
Digital Rebel and a celestron C9.25 with f/6.3 reducer.
The movie shows the movement of the comet during 24 minutes.
