Date:  Wed, 17 May 2006 07:14:27 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Fragmentation of "B" / odd coma of "C", Schwassmann-Wachmann 3
Component "B" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P; note the very pronounced string
of fragments in the trailing direction (PA 254d, anti-sun) from the primary
nucleus (m2=10.5ccd); in addition there is a very diffuse and large fragment
seen to the NW of the primary comet, in PA 304 deg. from "B". This exposure
is tracking on the comet, 8sec ea, 20 exposures. Total magnitude is 7.6
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBFDCD99.jpg

Component "C" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73-P, showing a beautiful "dumbbell"
shaped nebulous coma surrounding a very bright (m2=10.6ccd) nucleus. Very
unusual symmetry to the central region of this object, particularly on the
sunward side of the nucleus
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBFDCE7B.jpg

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Wed, 17 May 2006 08:38:55 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Fragmentation of "B" / odd coma of "C", Schwassmann-Wachmann 3
Could the shape of fragment C possibly be interpreted
that it is rotating with an axis pointing sunward,
i.e. more apparent outgassing seen from earth along
head and tail?

Date:  Thu, 18 May 2006 05:52:03 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO:  Component "B" quiescent; "C" in outburst
Component "B" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P; note that the streaming fragments
in the tail angle noted on the previous morning (May 17) are not clearly
visible, although some mottling appears to be in the anti-sun direction;
there is a conspicuous sunward SPIKE seen in this image, series of 10, 10sec
exposures, tracking on the comet's nucleus; comet is fainter than previous
night, total magnitude = 8.0ccd
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBFF0A0C.jpg

Component "C" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P; seesm to be in slight outburst
over past 24 hours, with the conspicuous hourglass shape increasing
dramatically; strong central condensation (m2=10.0), total magnitude =
7.8ccd
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComBFF0D21.jpg

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Fri, 19 May 2006 05:38:51 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  73P from ASO: Strong duplicity in "B" of Schwassmann-Wachmann
>From ASO-H45 on May 19
Component "B" of Schwassmann-Wachmann 73P on May 19, in twilight; note the
once-again strong duplicity of the nucleus with near-equal (m2-10.2ccd)
components; a small fragment is seen moving in concert with the comet to its
northwest (lower left of main coma); the slight sunward spike recorded on
May 18 is not seen. Total magnitude of "B" component 8.0
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComC005B5F.jpg

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)

Date:  Sat, 20 May 2006 05:42:22 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  ASO: Components "B" and "C", May 20, 73P
Component "C" now outshines "B" by better than a magnitude; "B" m1=8.1 / "C"
m1=6.6; the sunward side of the coma of "C" is developing very rapidly with
considerable morphological changes in short periods.

Component "B" of Schwassmann Wachmann, 73P, imaged very low in east,
moonlight and twilight; note the intense secondary fragment of 5-19-06 is
still evident, but has subsided in intensity somewhat; a very distinct
fragment is seen in the tail, nearly due west (left) of the primary nucleus
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComC01AB8A.jpg

Component "C" of Schwassmann Wachmann, 73P, imaged very low in east,
moonlight and twilight; note the rapid change in the coma from previous
morning, with comet increasing dramatically to mag. 6.6; very strong nucleus
without any fragmentation evident. Note that the sunward side of the coma
is far greater in both density and overall area than that in the anti-sun
(tail) direction
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComC01ADA9.jpg

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Sat, 20 May 2006 17:21:23 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  73P-B&C-05202006
Greetings. Images from the 20th. Not the best conditions but we take
what we can get. Each has 17 sub-frames of 15 sec each. Aleign is not
perfect but results look OK. Croped from the original and imaged with
a bin of 1x1. Two sizes for each image with the standard being the
smaller size.
Thanks, Mike H.

standard - B
http://www.fototime.com/E96A9A297D26BB7/standard.jpg
original
http://www.fototime.com/E96A9A297D26BB7/orig.jpg

standard - C
http://www.fototime.com/DE426A58A7BF02A/standard.jpg
original
http://www.fototime.com/DE426A58A7BF02A/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 20 May 2006 18:41:55 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  4P-Missed?
Greetings.
At 0400UT 05/20/2006 I imaged the area shown by Guide to be area of 4P
which is in the center of the 3 bright stars. The brightest star is 5
Psc mag 5.42. N up and E left. Even if the cordinates are off a
little this covers almost 1.5 deg wide. Easly down to 15-16 mag
range. did anyone else go for 4P at about the same time? A faint blur
is in the area but there are also some faint stars according to DSS
images. If anyone knows if I am not in the correct area, help
appreciated.
Thanks
Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/729D77110877753/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 20 May 2006 13:30:04 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 4P-Missed?
I circled the approximate point where 4P/Faye is
supposed to be at 0400UT 5/20/2006 and attached it.

The time you mention must really be 0400 CDT since 4P
does not rise until 02:14 local time.
Attached is a screen dump for 4P Faye this morning at
0400 local time (CDT) from TheSky6 with a DSS image
superimposed.

You were in the right area.

One thing Astrometrica does is plot the position of
known objects onto the current image, once you the
program has plate solved the image. Its based upon an
orbit calc. It could help locate it on your image.

--- Mike Holloway wrote:

> Greetings.
> At 0400UT 05/20/2006 I imaged the area shown by
> Guide to be area of 4P
> which is in the center of the 3 bright stars. The
> brightest star is 5
> Psc mag 5.42. N up and E left. Even if the
> cordinates are off a
> little this covers almost 1.5 deg wide. Easly down

> area, help
> appreciated.
> Thanks
> Mike H.
> http://www.fototime.com/729D77110877753/orig.jpg

> You were in the right area.
>
> One thing Astrometrica does is plot the position of
> known objects onto the current image, once you the
> program has plate solved the image. Its based upon an
> orbit calc. It could help locate it on your image.
>
> --- Mike Holloway wrote:
>
> > Greetings.
> > At 0400UT 05/20/2006 I imaged the area shown by
> > Guide to be area of 4P
> > which is in the center of the 3 bright stars. The
> > brightest star is 5
> > Psc mag 5.42. N up and E left. Even if the
> > cordinates are off a
> > little this covers almost 1.5 deg wide. Easly down
> > to 15-16 mag
> > range. did anyone else go for 4P at about the same
> > time? A faint blur
> > is in the area but there are also some faint stars
> > according to DSS
> > images. If anyone knows if I am not in the correct
> > area, help
> > appreciated.
> > Thanks
> > Mike H.
> > http://www.fototime.com/729D77110877753/orig.jpg

Date:  Sat, 20 May 2006 16:56:59 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  73P-"B" changes in May
The story of changing morphology of Comet Schwassmann-Wachmann 3 (73P),
component "B"; a composite of dates: May 9 (outburst), May 16 (fragmentary
string), May 18 (duplicity), May 19 and May 20. From ASO_H45 Petit Jean
Mountain South, P. Clay Sherrod, all taken with the 0.41m R.C. @ f/5 via ST
402ME ccd; no filters nor post-processing
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComC02473C.jpg

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Sun, 21 May 2006 11:36:22 +0200
From:  Stefan Beck 
Subject:  Aligning comet images
Hi Mike,

great images !

How do you align the images to get fine star trails ?

Normally I use Astroart and do a manual align on the comets head.
But with such a bright coma it is very difficult.

Regards,

Stefan Beck

"Astrophotography with small telescopes"

Date:  Sun, 21 May 2006 05:30:10 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  73P, Component "B" May 21
Component "B" of 73P Schwassmann-Wachmann3 in strong moonlight and twilight;
note the obvious singularity of the "B" component and development of slender
ion tail; no fragmentation could be found in anti-sun direction and sunward
spike is not visible; total magnitude has dropped to 8.8
http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComC02FC65.jpg

Component "C" (magnitude 7.2 visual) seen in dawn skies, no evidence of
hourglass appearance of previous nights.

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Sun, 21 May 2006 23:30:09 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: Aligning comet images
Stefan. Thank you. Looking at my last attempt at this comet, my
star aleign is not so good due to high clouds making starpoints
bload . I can only tell you my way of manual aleign and bet others
have different and better ways.
I use the software CCDSoftV5. After aquiring images in the FITS
format and applying dark and flats, each images has a strong
histrogram applied which will reduce any overblead in the core area.
I then use the zoom or magnify tool to zoom in on the core of the
comet until it pixelates and shows a bright point. Bad seeing will
make this vary so the better the seeing of course the better the
outcome. Select the same area with the aleign tool with a manual
select (CCDSoft has "CTRL-ENTER" to overide auto-select) and do an
aleign on the pixel I want in each image. When I close the images
they revert to the original size. Combine and make corrections if
possible. Be sure to save a duplicate set of original files for
backup before starting. Combining in an add, average and median are
always performed to have different possibilities and bring out
different structures in the tail. After combining in the fits format
I save the images in TIFF format for transfer to PS for the next step
of processing. Final images are then saved as tiff and a copy is
saved as jpeg for publishing. One more thing, I apply the histogram
to the fits image after combine to once again reduce the core blead
and give a nice image to start with in PS as a TIFF image. Hope this
helps if you can follow my instructions.
Mike H.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, Stefan Beck
wrote:
>
> Hi Mike,
>
> great images !

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Tue, 23 May 2006 10:07:50 -0000
From:  Adrian Jones 
Subject:  Re: Aligning comet images - animation
Mike, I use K3CCDTools to align images on the comet's head. I use a
2-stage process at x2 up-sample to get accurate alignment using
the 'view difference' function. Then down-sample back to normal size
at the end.

Here is an example of an animation of 73/P-B that I made from 135 x
30 sec images aligned this way: (warning: large DivX file 1.1MB)

http://universalconstant.com/73P-B_12May2006_0140-0259UT_ff.avi

One issue I found with getting exact alignment of frames: if you auto-
guided on the comet during image capture, over a period of say 60
minutes, there is some slight field rotation with respect to the
background stars! If you look closely at the above AVI (covering 80
minutes of movement of the comet) you can just detect the rotation as
the frames progress.

Adrian

Date:  Thu, 25 May 2006 16:23:23 +0200
From:  Ralf Vandebergh 
Subject:  73P-B fragmentations_new results(May 5)
To the observers,

I now processed all data of the observations of the 73P-B splitting on May 5.
Several condensations are visible,note especially the large second component which has
faded away later.Surprisingly,the smaller remnant seemed to contain enough energy to produce
another outburst a few days later.

http://img131.imageshack.us/img131/9992/73pb20060505fragmentationp4wu.jpg

Best regards,
Ralf Vandebergh

Imaging data _10´´´Newtonian/ATK-1HS)
0000. 5/05/2006 5:03:09; 4,99s; AMP_ON
0001. 5/05/2006 5:03:15; 4,78s; AMP_ON
0002. 5/05/2006 5:03:20; 4,83s; AMP_ON
0003. 5/05/2006 5:03:26; 4,81s; AMP_ON
0004. 5/05/2006 5:03:31; 4,81s; AMP_ON
0005. 5/05/2006 5:03:36; 4,78s; AMP_ON
0006. 5/05/2006 5:03:42; 4,84s; AMP_ON
0007. 5/05/2006 5:03:47; 4,77s; AMP_ON

Date:  Fri, 26 May 2006 01:11:43 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Comet 41P
Comet 41P Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak has a history of rapid brightening
pre-perihelion. It was rather bright at its last two apparitions,
and at its 1973 apparition underwent two large outbursts of 9-10
magnitudes peaking at magnitude 4-5. Comet 41P is expected to reach
magnitude 10 around perihelion on June 11, but in light of above may
well be brighter. It passes from Cancer into Leo in early June and
spends the rest of the month in this constellation.

The comet was moving at a relative rate of 2.2 arc seconds per
minute on May 23rd. I imaged it at 5.0 arc seconds per pixel,
binned 2x2, which allowed two minute exposures without blurring the
comet. Actually, with the comet fairly low in the west against the
setting sun, I started with 60 second exposures to avoid saturation.

My sky conditions were 20.30 mags/sq arc second at zenith ~ Bortle
4.5 ~ 5.6-5.9 VLM as measured with the Sky Quality Meter; seeing ~
Pickering 3.

Images and supporting data at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Hi list,

Namibia.

http://www.fg-kometen.de/bildere.htm

Quote:

- the first week is over. We have taken lots of images.

- the tail of 73P-B will move over the coma of the c-component.

- we have observed new components as well.

Further information about Tivoli can be found at
http://www.tivoli-astrofarm.de

Hi all,

I imaged Comet 73P (Schwassmann-Wachmann 3 (C and B)) yesterday morning (Monday 29th @ 1600 hours UT). The image is a combination (averaged) of 6 x 3 minute @ 800asa through a Sigma 70-200mm lens @ 200mm @ f2.8.

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet-73p-schwassmann-wachmann3-c-b-060530-5x3min@800asa-200mm_sigma_lens-f2,8-ave-web.jpg

or

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'

group.

Date:  Thu, 01 Jun 2006 13:42:44 -0000
From:  Howie 
Subject:  Another imaging close encounter
If you missed the close encounter of 073C Schwassmann-Wachmann and
M57. Here is chance for another close encounter. Albeit not as
spetacular as M57.
On this Saturday night June 3rd. at 10:30pm EST. USA.
073C Schwassmann-Wachmann will be approximately 23' from NGC337. A
very interesting looking irregular morphological galaxy.

Right Ascension: 0 : 59.8 (hours : minutes)
Declination: -07 : 35 (degrees : minutes)
Apparent Magnitude: 11.6
Apparent Diameter: 2.8 (arc minutes)
______
Howie
15" Obsession #821 /Argo Navis/ServoCAT Jr./Meade DSI CCD 

Date:  Sat, 03 Jun 2006 06:40:03 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  73P-C Visual Obs and image (B and C)
Hi all,

I visually observed 73P-C (Schwassmann-Wachmann 3) two mornings ago...

CometObs - ( http://groups.yahoo.com/group/CometObs/ )
2006 June 01.70 UT: m1 = 7.3, Dia.= 4'.0, DC = 4, Tail: 1.7 deg...15x70B...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [73P segments C and B seen in the same 4 degree FOV. Segment C is fairly bright with a large, diffuse coma and 1.5 degree tail. Segment B is about a mag fainter, smaller, and with a shorter tail. 40˚ alt in the NE. Stellar LM = 11.0 near comet (binos)].

Charles Morris's, 'The New Comet Observations Page' ( http://cometobservation.com/ )
2006 June 01.70 UT: m1=7.3, Dia.=4'.0, DC=4, Tail: 1.7 deg...15x70B...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [73P segments C and B seen in the same 4 degree FOV. Segment C is fairly bright with a large, diffuse coma and 1.5 degree tail. Segment B is about a mag fainter, smaller, and with a shorter tail. 40˚ alt in the NE. Stellar LM = 11.0 near comet (binos)].

ICQ (International Comet Quarterly) ( http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/icq/CometMags.html )
June 01.70, 7.3, 4'.0 (John Drummond, Gisborne, New Zealand, 15x70B);

An image of this comet on the morning of the observation can be seen at...
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet-73p-schwassmann-wachmann3-c-b-060602-7x30sec-3min@800asa-200mm_sigma@f2,8-webd.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/oryrv

Other images of 73P can be seen at:
http://tinyurl.com/g2noh

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Thu, 08 Jun 2006 19:08:23 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Vis Obs and Image: 73P C (and B)
Hi all,

I visually observed 73P-C (Schwassmann-Wachmann 3) two mornings ago...

CometObs - ( http://groups.yahoo.com/group/CometObs/ )
2006 June 06.72 UT: m1 = 7.7, Dia.= 4'.0, DC = 5, tail=2 degrees, 15x70B...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [73P segments C and B are about 1.5 degrees apart - same binocular FOV. C is slightly fainter than five days ago. It appears as an elongated streak where coma forms into tail. Has a 2 degree tail. Segment B is much fainter than 5 days ago - about 2 mags fainter than C, smaller, and with a shorter tail.Through the 16"scope B has hardly any coma (nucleus not readily evident) - it looks just like a tail in the sky with no/little head (is it disappearing?). 41˚ alt in the NE. Stellar LM = 11.0 near comet (binos)].

Charles Morris's, 'The New Comet Observations Page' ( http://cometobservation.com/ )
2006 June 06.72 UT: m1=7.7, Dia.=4'.0, DC=5, tail=2 deg, 15x70B...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [73P segments C and B are about 1.5 degrees apart - same binocular FOV. C is slightly fainter than five days ago. It appears as an elongated streak where coma forms into tail. Has a 2 degree tail. Segment B is much fainter than 5 days ago - about 2 mags fainter than C, smaller, and with a shorter tail.Through the 16"scope B has hardly any coma (nucleus not readily evident) - it looks just like a tail in the sky with no/little head (is it disappearing?). 41˚ alt in the NE. Stellar LM = 11.0 near comet (binos)].

ICQ (International Comet Quarterly) ( http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/icq/CometMags.html )
2006 June 06.72 UT: 7.7, 4'.0, (John Drummond, Gisborne, New Zealand, 15x70B);

An image from the night can be seen at...

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet-73p-schwassmann-wachmann3-b-c-060607-13x3min@800asa-200mm_sigma_lens-@f2,8-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/hbsrb

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Thu, 08 Jun 2006 17:50:39 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  C/2004 B1 (Linear) June 8 observations
To the observers,

These are observations of comet C/2004 B1 (Linear) on June 8. The
image is a composite of the data of all images of the session.
The movie shows its movement in 41 minutes,centered on the comet.
(10 inch Newtonian & ATK-1HS).

movie:
http://img442.imageshack.us/img442/8910/c2004b1200606080000410sv.gif

images:http://img323.imageshack.us/img323/8690/c2004b120060608p0ii.jpg

Best regards,
Ralf Vandebergh

several new images.

Date:  Sat, 10 Jun 2006 13:04:12 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  C/2004 B1 Linear_June 10
To the observers,

These are observations of C/2004 B1 (Linear) on June 10.(last night).

-It seems steady,with a condensed coma and fainter outer coma.
-The movie shows its movement in 96 minutes time.

movie:
http://img100.imageshack.us/img100/7622/c2004b120060610001501511uo.gif

images:
http://img134.imageshack.us/img134/9052/c2005b12006061000150122p0zq.jpg

Best regards,
Ralf Vandebergh

10 inch Newtonian & ATk-1HS)

http://help.yahoo.com/help/us/groups/files

Regards,

gvnn64

Date:  Mon, 12 Jun 2006 08:19:05 -0000
From:  Mahmoodreza Samiei Zafarghandi 
Subject:  CCD Astronomy Questions


In the name of GOD
Dear researchers , professors , students , company's , astronomical
groups & ...
This is Mahmoodreza Samiei Zafarghandi . I am student of Azad
university in Iran ( Tehran ) . and I research about " Astronomical
CCD ( Charge Couple Device ) Camera & their Software " .i would like
to have some experience information's of CCD camera or any
astronomical camera user's in one of part of my project .then please
response ( & explain ) to this questions( in below ) and send your
answer to astronomy@board.ir . Thank you for your cooperation .
1. How many camera did you know ?
a. CCD
b. CMOS
c. ...
2. What is important in camera's ?
3. Camera's Parameters .
4. Application of photography in astronomy .
5. What information can you get from pictures?
6. Compration between image sensors .
a. CCD
b. CMOS
c. ...
7. How can you use CCD in photography ?
8. CCD parameters in photography and choose a CCD .
9. Operation in a CCD image sensor's.
10. Noise effect in photography.
11. Application of CCD ( as image sensor ) in astronomy.
12. Photography in UV , IR , ... .
13. Photography with CCD in UV , IR , ... .
14. CCD camera that you use . ( resolutions , software , ... )
15. CCD applications in signal processing ( image processing ) .
16. Which softwares are better ( & you use ) in CCD's
photography ?
17. Aplication of CCD image sensors in pattern recognition .
18. Astronomical Centers that you have connection with .
19. CCD seminar's that you have information about them .
20. If you have more explanation or any idea , please tell me .

Yours Faithful
Mahmoodreza Samiei Zafarghandi
Board Of Astronomy
E-mail : astronomy@board.ir
website : http://astronomy.board.ir 

Date:  Mon, 12 Jun 2006 11:54:17 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  movie C/2004 B1 Linear June 10-11-12
To the observers,

This movie is the result of 2 nights imaging on comet C/2004 B1 Linear
in strong moonlight.
from June 10 until June 12.
The total stretch of the movie is 26 hours and 16 minutes.
Please give it some time to load)

http://img161.imageshack.us/img161/8927/c2004b120060610111226hours16mi.
gif

Best regards,
Ralf Vandebergh
10 inch Newtonian & ATK-1HS)

Dennis Persyk

dense Hercules star field.

Date:  Thu, 15 Jun 2006 22:27:32 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  Re: movie C/2004 B1 Linear June 10-11-12
Hi Dennis,

At first I think this is a question of personal taste.
The professional observatories use often the comet-aligned method.

I first made movies aligned on the stars,but I turned to this
kind,because you have a better eye on the comet,when it keeps
at one point in the field.I discovered this,when I made a movie
of P/SW-3 fragment B with a small mini-fragment.This kind of small
detail is not visible well when it moves,for this movie see:

http://img260.imageshack.us/img260/8615/73pb20060503003201564do.gif

http://img471.imageshack.us/img471/852/73pb2006050300320156neg4xj.gif

Best wishes,
Ralf

Date:  Fri, 16 Jun 2006 14:25:45 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: movie C/2004 B1 Linear June 10-11-12
Hi Rolf,

I like the two animations you posted now. They depict smooth motion,
whereas the previous one seemed a bit bumpier.

I used to align on the comet, thinking that it was a good way of
revealing changes in the tail structure during the course of the
animation. I have since concluded that somehow the background level
changes from one frame to the next, which has the effect of
revealing more or less tail structure, but no actual changes. I'm
not sure why the background varies, even during clear, steady skies,
but I always seem to have a few frames that are different.

Clear skies,

Dennis
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "ralf_vandebergh"
wrote:
>
> Hi Dennis,
>
> At first I think this is a question of personal taste.
> The professional observatories use often the comet-aligned method.
>
> I first made movies aligned on the stars,but I turned to this
> kind,because you have a better eye on the comet,when it keeps
> at one point in the field.I discovered this,when I made a movie
> of P/SW-3 fragment B with a small mini-fragment.This kind of small
> detail is not visible well when it moves,for this movie see:
>
> http://img260.imageshack.us/img260/8615/73pb20060503003201564do.gif
>
http://img471.imageshack.us/img471/852/73pb2006050300320156neg4xj.gif
>
> Best wishes,
> Ralf
>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Dennis Persyk"
> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Ralf,
> >
> > I got airsick watching the movie ! I believe you get a
> smoother presentation stacking on the stars instead of the comet.
> >
> > I'm working on B1 tonight, but it keeps bumping into stars in
the dense Hercules star field.
> >
> > Clear skies,
> >
> > Dennis Persyk
> > Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
> > Hampshire, IL
> >
> > 41P Movie http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

> > > I believe the link to this movie didn't work.
> > > Here is a new try:
> > >
http://img63.imageshack.us/img63/1646/c2004b12006061011125ws.gif
> > >
> > > Ralf
> >
> > > To the observers,
> > >
> > > This movie is the result of 2 nights imaging on comet C/2004
B1 Linear in strong moonlight. from June 10 until June 12.
> > > The total stretch of the movie is 26 hours and 16 minutes.
> > > Please give it some time to load)
> > >
> > > > Best regards,
> > > Ralf Vandebergh

Date:  Fri, 16 Jun 2006 22:20:10 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  Re: movie C/2004 B1 Linear June 10-11-12
Hi Dennis,

This bumping was caused by the fact that the movie is created of
images from 3 nights! So the stars are not the same,and the camera
position has possibly changed a bit.But I think it was an
interesting experiment to make a movie of several days.This is also
the reason why it is unpossible to make a star-aligned movie of it,
because the stretch of the comet is too large during that time to
show in one image-animation.Aligning on the comet was the only
solution here.

Ralf

Date:  Sat, 17 Jun 2006 16:13:30 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  Re: movie C/2004 B1 Linear June 10-11-12
Dennis,about this:

''but I always seem to have a few frames that are different.''
You can correct every frame on same brightness level before convert
in into GIF.You can do that simply by moving the next layer a bit
from its place,until you see the greytones of both layers.Then
corret the brightness until you get the same greytone.

Ralf

Date:  Mon, 19 Jun 2006 19:49:56 +0200
From:  Klaas Jobse 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images C/2004 B1 (LINEAR)

Hi,

My image ( 06-16) of C/2004 B1 (LINEAR) shows a tail of about 14' :
http://www.klaas-jobse.net/cyclops/kometen/20060616B1_2245UT24x60sweb.jpg

I was not sure if the tail was real, so I also took a picture on 06-17, on that picture there was no sign of the tail at all.
The observing conditions on 06-17 were a bit more humid then the previous night.
When I saw the picture posted today, I realised that the tail must be real. To detect it from my location will only be possible under the best observing conditions.

Best Regards,

Klaas Jobse

----- Original Message -----
From: Michael Mattiazzo
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, June 19, 2006 1:19 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] recent comet images

Hello all,

I've uploaded CCD images of the following comets to my website:

Rob McNaughts latest comet discovery C/2006 L2, June 17th 2006 at 11:55 UT.
71P Clark, June 17th 2006 at 12:08 UT.
45P Honda-Mrkos-Pajdusakova gif animation June 6th.
73P fragment C 2006 June 6th at 20:06 UT
73P fragment B 2006 June 6th at 20:11 UT

http://www.yp-connect.net/~mmatti/

All images unfortunately affected by light pollution!

Cheers,
Michael Mattiazzo

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Tue, 20 Jun 2006 10:10:54 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images C/2004 B1 (LINEAR)
> When I saw the picture posted today, I realised that the tail must be real. To detect it from my location will only be possible under the best observing conditions.

Hi Klaas,
we faced the same problem: shooting at this comet with less than perfect skies, blows out its faint appendage. The signal originated by the tail is very close to the sky background, so any kind of light pollution and/or haze will hamper its visibility.
Cheers,
Giovanni 

Date:  Tue, 20 Jun 2006 10:35:23 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images
Hello Michael,
very nice image of comet 41P! I possibly see evidence of two elongation in the coma, that are also visible in the shoots took by Ernesto on 2006, June 17 from the NM Skies site: a narrow one, is almost 1.2' long in PA 94 deg, while the other (much wider and faint) is almost 0.7' in PA 290 deg.
Cheers,
Giovanni 

Date:  Tue, 20 Jun 2006 22:43:55 +0930
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] recent comet images
Hi Mike,

The exposure time of 71P is the same as 2006 L2, that is 15x10 seconds.
However, 71P was imaged at lower elevation over city light pollution whilst
2006 L2 was directly overhead, hence it's difficult to make a comparison.
Have not had the opportunity yet to observe 2006 L2 visually from a dark
site.

Kind regards,
Michael Mattiazzo
Adelaide, South Australia

Date:  Tue, 20 Jun 2006 21:38:40 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2004 B1 - 06/20/2006
I wanted to add this comet to my files. The weather was HOT. 96F out
side the dome with 74% humidity and so the focus was changing all the
time. 10x30 sec exp with the 4" FSQ and FLI Maxcam10 ccd just after
dark or about 0300UT.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/BC5351750C2EA8D/orig.jpg

From: gvnn64@libero.it

Subject: Re:[Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello Michael,
very nice image of comet 41P! I possibly see evidence of two elongation in the coma, that are also visible in the shoots took by Ernesto on 2006, June 17 from the NM Skies site: a narrow one, is almost 1.2' long in PA 94 deg, while the other (much wider and faint) is almost 0.7' in PA 290 deg.
Cheers,
Giovanni

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "gvnn64\@...\.it"
wrote:
>
> > When I saw the picture posted today, I realised that the tail
must be real. To detect it from my location will only be possible
under the best observing conditions.
>
> Hi Klaas,
> we faced the same problem: shooting at this comet with less than
perfect skies, blows out its faint appendage. The signal originated
by the tail is very close to the sky background, so any kind of
light pollution and/or haze will hamper its visibility.
> Cheers,
> Giovanni
> 

Date:  Thu, 22 Jun 2006 10:11:04 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Observations? Machholz (C/2004 Q2)
During the past three very deep nights, we have been tracking Machholz
(C/2004 Q2); I would like to get some feedback from anyone else who might
have been imaging (high resolution) or recording this object as it appears
incredibly delineated or perhaps even segmented in a NE-SW orientation. At
first I assumed that this might be a result of proper motion, but tracking
over 2-3 minutes on the comet itself is resulting in the same narrow streak
surrounded by a very faint coma; if it is indeed separated, it is slightly
beyond the resolution of our 0.41m RC.

Thanks for any assistance on this.

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

Subject:  73P mosaic
Hi!

We have uploaded a file, where 73P fragment B shows not only his
prominent dust tail but also a very faint ion tail, which you can
better recognize on the stretched black and white version (mouse over)
Mosaic of 4 frames with ASA 8" f3.8 AStrograph, FLI 6303camera
Exp. each frame: 2x2 binning RGB 120/120/180 sec.
30.5.2006 UT 2h40m, Farm Tivoli/Namibia/SW-Africa

http://www.astrostudio.at/startpage/page.php

imager expect? Will the progress be such that a day by day increase
will be obvious? Will it be along the lines of Encki at last aproach
as far as an imaging object or perhaps another comet in the recent
past. Thanks for your patients, Mike H.

Date:  Fri, 30 Jun 2006 10:23:53 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Comet M3 as far as Imaging.
Hi Mike,
thanks for your mail; you raised an interesting question.
If we look at the orbital circumstances of this passage, we can notice the following facts:

2006, Jun. 30 (current situation)
distance from Earth: ~0.44 AU; distance from the Sun: ~1.44 AU

2006, Jul. 19 (perigee)
distance from Earth: ~0.36 AU; distance from the Sun: ~1.28 AU

2006, Aug. 28 (perihelium)
distance from Earth: ~0.51 AU; distance from the Sun: ~1.10 AU

So, in the next couple of weeks, the comet will slightly decrease its distance from Earth, then it will get a little farther away from us at the time of perihelium. Looking at this numbers, I suspect that this circumstances should not affect too much the visibility of details like the faint (but huge) external coma that made the difference at the time of 2P/Encke previous passage you mentioned. About the latter: I understand that at least one observer has recently reported the CCD detection of a faint & extended coma in comet Barbard. The images obtained by E. Guido and myself doesn't show this detail: we can we see just a small (~12") compact coma. However it's plenty possible that the observing conditions (sensitivity od the instrumentation, hight above horizon of the target, crowded star fields, etc.) could have hamperred our detection of this fine detail. For this reason, any additional imaging by other fellow comet observers would be very valuable in order to clarify the situation.

Cheers,
Giovanni

Date:  Wed, 05 Jul 2006 17:21:05 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  C/2004 B1 passes galaxies
Hi all,

When I grabbed the first frames of comet Linear on july 3, I was
surprised to see not 1 but 3 spots with a cometary appearance.
After some minutes,it was clear that one of these is was the
comet,and the other faint galaxies of the same brightness.
The movie shows how this comet C/2004 B1 passes these galaxies in
Corona Borealis (from 22:42 UTC---01:15 UTC)
According to the latest downloaded data,the brightness of the comet
is magn. 13.9 currently.

images: http://img489.imageshack.us/img489/390/c2004b1200607038mh.jpg

movie:
http://img351.imageshack.us/img351/4654/c2004b120060704224201153zr.gi
f

10 inch Newtonian & ATK-1HS)

Best regards,
Ralf Vandebergh 

Date:  Thu, 06 Jul 2006 09:59:58 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  Re: C/2004 B1 passes galaxies
-I believe the movie-link did not work.
Here is a new try:

http://img86.imageshack.us/img86/7898/c2004b1200607046ei.gif

Ralf

Date:  Tue, 11 Jul 2006 08:11:15 -0002
From:  Bernd Brinkmann 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] New images from 2005B1, 2004B1 and 2003WT42
Hello Stefan,

> I have uploaded new images to my website
> http://www.cometchaser.de/comets.html
>
> and to the website of the german comet section
> http://www.fg-kometen.de/bildere.htm

I just looked at this
http://www.fg-kometen.de/pix/2006M3/2006M3_03072006.htm
image from Norbert. Its phantastic to see the dim green coma. But secondly I
noticed at once the trail in the lower left. It has another direction as the rest! It's
the minor planet (532) Herculina with mag 9.5. North is up and east to the right.

This was the technic of Eric Elst, who discovered hundreds of MPs on Schmidt
Plates at La Silla. He made multiple exposures on the same plate and moved the
plate in declination each time. All dots which weren't aligned north-south were
MPs. He told me this when I met him at Hoher List (Bonn University
Observatory, MPC 017) some years ago.

Clear skies
Bernd

Bernd Brinkmann

Sternwarte Herne, MPC code A18
Herne, Germany

e-mail: info@sternwarte-herne.de
http://www.sternwarte-herne.de 

Date:  Fri, 14 Jul 2006 13:40:26 -0000
From:  gvnn64 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Comet M3 as far as Imaging.
Hi all,
the visibility conditions for this comet have improved significantly
for northern observers. Now also on our images is possible to see a
faint and extend coma around the central condensation (spanning few
arcminutes in diameter). An image took few hours ago is available here:
http://tinyurl.com/gsyxc

Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero and Ernesto Guido (Remanzacco Obs, CARA) 

Date:  Fri, 14 Jul 2006 23:05:24 +1000
From:  Vello Tabur 
Subject:  C/2006 M4  (SWAN)
I've just posted an image of this comet from 2006 July 12, taken by Rob
McNaught with the 0.5m Uppsala Schmidt, to the Miscellaneous folder of
the Comet Images group. Rob reports "it was near the bottom edge of the
field, hence the horizontal bands from an imperfect flatfield."

Thanks to Rob for sharing this image and congratulations to Rob Matson
and Michael Mattiazzo for their find!

Date:  Sun, 16 Jul 2006 00:54:29 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] Re: C2006 M4 Swan
Yes - pleasingly close. (whew!) Actually, the real reason for the accuracy must
be attributed to the accuracy of your pre-discovery image measurement.
Congratulations.

In broad terms the ephemeris I sent yesterday remains a good indication for this
comet. I think the main problem with visibility of this comet is that while it
gets a reasonable solar elongation, it will be largely north of the sun, rather
than east or west. As a result, the better views will be had by those living in
high northern latitudes....

As a post-script (and thinking of C/2006 A1 Pojmanski), I hope we don't have
wishful thinkers suggesting that this comet is going brighten to be a
spectacular comet...... It clearly will brighten significantly from the present,
and we can assume the tail will grow significantly as it gets closer to the sun.
But there is currently no reason to expect anything more than this. I think we
can also assume that there will only be a small number of observations reported
prior to it being lost in the twilight at around the end of July/early August.
It will be interesting to see who is the first to see it as it comes away from
the Sun in late September.... [This is a challenge.... - with the 'prize' being
the _glory_ of being the first to see it past solar conjunction.]

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From: "Terry Lovejoy"
To:
Sent: Saturday, July 15, 2006 11:47 PM
Subject: [comets-ml] Re: C2006 M4 Swan

David's orbit actually looks pretty close to the one just published
by CBAT (admittedly they are still working on a short arc)

http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/mpec/K06/K06N38.html

Looks like a nice object later on.

Terry

--- In comets-ml@yahoogroups.com, "Dave Herald" wrote:
>
> T 2006 Sep 29.35
> e = 1
> q = .8062
> peri = 61.26
> Node = 148.59
> i = 111.89
>
> Ho = 8.5
>
> The RMS residual is 0.5". The greatest uncertainty in the orbit is
the accuracy
> of Terry Lovejoy's position of 30 June. The orbit is effectively
an 'exact' fit
> to that one early position. The next uncertainty arises from the
fact that the
> comet had only moved about 1/2 degree in the 24hrs between Rob
McNaught's
> observations and mine.
>
> A 10-day ephemeris to judge general future location is:
>
> Ephemeris of C2006 M4 Swan at 0 Hrs UT
> (2000.0)
> Date R.A. Dec Distance
elong Moon
> y m d h m o ' delta R o
Mag o %
> 2006 7 14* 9 7.94 - 1 20.8 2.341 1.585 32.8
12.3 158 89
> 2006 7 24* 9 20.34 2 7.9 2.314 1.450 24.3
11.9 39 2
> 2006 8 3* 9 33.76 5 34.4 2.264 1.317 15.8

> 2006 8 13* 9 48.41 9 6.5 2.185 1.187 7.3

> 2006 8 23* 10 4.83 12 53.2 2.076 1.065 1.4

> 2006 11 1* 16 57.05 32 55.4 1.039 1.012 59.7
8.6 91 73
> 2006 11 11* 18 18.07 23 24.9 1.165 1.129 62.5
9.4 125 67
> 2006 11 21* 19 11.88 14 56.1 1.375 1.255 61.6
10.2 64 0
> 2006 12 1* 19 49.11 8 40.4 1.628 1.387 58.1
11.0 75 79
> 2006 12 11* 20 16.86 4 15.8 1.897 1.522 52.9
11.7 146 65
>
> From this you will note that the comet is in conjunction with the
sun in RA at
> the end of August, and again in mid-October. That is, it will be an
evening
> object until mid-August and after mid-October, and a morning object
in-between.
>
> Looking out the window, the chances of me getting a position tonite
is zero (if
> not less!) Hopefully someone else can get some positions so that
the orbit will
> get tied down. Weather permitting, I estimate I will be able to
follow this for
> the next 2 weeks at most. I think we can assume that there will be
no astrometry
> from late July through to about mid September.
>
> Dave Herald
> Canberra, Australia
>

Date:  Sat, 15 Jul 2006 14:54:53 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  P/2006 M3 - 07/15/2006 - increase information
Greetings. This comet was an attention holder even if i couldn't get
satisified with the extreme heat and humidity. In this image N is up
with E to the left. Brighter star to the S/E is a 9.01 mag.
Information was taken over about 1 1/2 hours and only the better 18
images are used so the gaps in the stars. I cannot decide if the
structure to the west side is real or not. A negative inset shows this
as did all images but still I would like to see it another night.
Could be dim stars grabing pixel info but----? File is croped but
still left full 1x1 bin size at 450kb
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/9A01CB9731A8FCB/orig.jpg

Date:  Mon, 17 Jul 2006 23:59:42 +0200

Subject:  177P/Barnard_2006_Jul_16 image (Remanzacco Observatory).
Giovanni,

image ( 16.92 to 16.97 UT ), among the same stars. After coming back

Juan Jos Gonzlez 

Date:  Wed, 19 Jul 2006 19:24:49 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  C/2006 M4 Swan
I've just sent some positions of this comet to the MPC. It is hard for me to get
a decent image - the window for when it is dark enough to get an image, and when
it disappears behind a tree (& then my observatory wall) is currently only about
15 mins.

Anyway, I plugged the positions from M.P.E.C. 2006-N38, plus my two positions of
tonite, into Orbfit. There is a significant change in the elements, which I now
get (with an RMS of 0.66"):

T 2006 Sep 26.642
q = 0.6600
e = 1
Peri 71.167
Node 148.855
Incl 113.352

The significant change in perihelion distance means the comet will be brighter
than previously anticipated. Given this, I will be particularly interested in
the orbit that the MPC comes up with.

An indicative ephemeris based on these elements follows. Note that compared to
the previous ephemeris, the position is different by about 8 deg at the
beginning of October, and 25 deg at the end of October ... This clearly
illustrates the fact that the orbit is still not well defined, so the position
and behaviour in October is at best 'indicative'.

Ephemeris of C2006 M4 Swan at 0 Hrs UT
(2000.0)
Date R.A. Dec Distance elong
y m d h m o ' delta R o Mag
2006 7 19* 9 15.38 0 35.7 2.292 1.483 28.7 12.0
2006 7 24* 9 21.43 2 16.1 2.269 1.408 24.4 11.8
2006 7 29* 9 27.76 3 56.6 2.240 1.333 20.2 11.5
2006 8 3* 9 34.41 5 38.2 2.203 1.258 15.9 11.2
2006 8 8* 9 41.40 7 22.3 2.159 1.184 11.6 10.9
2006 8 13* 9 48.80 9 9.9 2.107 1.110 7.3 10.6
2006 8 18* 9 56.72 11 2.6 2.047 1.037 3.0 10.2
2006 8 23* 10 5.28 13 1.7 1.977 0.966 1.5 9.8
2006 8 28* 10 14.66 15 8.9 1.897 0.898 5.9 9.4
2006 9 2* 10 25.17 17 25.8 1.807 0.834 10.4 9.0
2006 9 7* 10 37.21 19 53.6 1.706 0.777 14.9 8.6
2006 9 12* 10 51.45 22 32.6 1.596 0.728 19.4 8.1
2006 9 17* 11 8.83 25 21.5 1.476 0.691 23.9 7.7
2006 9 22* 11 30.77 28 15.6 1.349 0.667 28.4 7.4
2006 9 27* 11 59.19 31 4.4 1.221 0.660 32.7 7.1
2006 10 2* 12 36.46 33 27.2 1.097 0.670 36.9 7.0
2006 10 7* 13 24.54 34 47.4 0.987 0.695 40.9 6.9
2006 10 12* 14 22.93 34 13.5 0.904 0.734 45.1 6.9
2006 10 17* 15 26.41 31 3.9 0.858 0.785 49.4 7.1
2006 10 22* 16 26.62 25 30.9 0.856 0.843 53.5 7.4
2006 10 27* 17 17.64 18 47.3 0.898 0.907 57.0 7.8
2006 11 1* 17 58.35 12 11.8 0.978 0.976 59.4 8.3
2006 11 6* 18 30.35 6 27.7 1.084 1.047 60.4 8.9
2006 11 11* 18 55.80 1 45.1 1.209 1.120 60.3 9.4
2006 11 16* 19 16.51 - 2 1.9 1.345 1.194 59.2 9.9

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

Date:  Wed, 19 Jul 2006 13:05:32 -0000
From:  gvnn64 
Subject:  Re: 177P/Barnard_2006_Jul_16 image (Remanzacco Observatory).
Hi Juan José,
nice coincidence!

Yesterday night we imaged it again; the external coma of this comet now
appears to be elongated (major axis aligned toward South), but we don't
know if this is a spurious effect of the background stars within the
coma. Do you, or any other observer/imager in [Comet-Images], noticed
anything like this?

Here is the link for last night's image:
http://tinyurl.com/nko2w

Cheers,
Giovanni 

Date:  Wed, 19 Jul 2006 23:50:20 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] C/2006 M4 Swan
Well, the orbit below is wrong...... Oops - how embarrassing!.

It turns out that I didn't use Orbfit properly to get the solution..... didn't
press the right button. [Annoying that when you load an observation file into
Orbfit it presents an immediate result which look like a valid solution having
good RMS residuals - and yet that solution can be totally invalid]. Anyway the
orbit on M.P.E.C. 2006-N38 is good, with the perihelion distance reducing by
perhaps 0.01 units. Expect an MPEC update at the end of the week.... But my
'revised' elements (which differ only marginally from M.P.E.C. 2006-N38) are:

T 2006 Sep 28.620
q = 0.7788
e = 1
Peri 62.840
Node 148.748
Incl 111.818

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From: "Dave Herald"
To: "Comets-ml" ;
Sent: Wednesday, July 19, 2006 7:24 PM
Subject: [comets-ml] C/2006 M4 Swan

I've just sent some positions of this comet to the MPC. It is hard for me to get
a decent image - the window for when it is dark enough to get an image, and when
it disappears behind a tree (& then my observatory wall) is currently only about
15 mins.

Anyway, I plugged the positions from M.P.E.C. 2006-N38, plus my two positions of
tonite, into Orbfit. There is a significant change in the elements, which I now
get (with an RMS of 0.66"):

T 2006 Sep 26.642
q = 0.6600
e = 1
Peri 71.167
Node 148.855
Incl 113.352

The significant change in perihelion distance means the comet will be brighter
than previously anticipated. Given this, I will be particularly interested in
the orbit that the MPC comes up with. 

Date:  Wed, 19 Jul 2006 16:13:26 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: 177P/Barnard_2006_Jul_16 image (Remanzacco Observatory).
There does appear to be a bit of elongation to both the nucleus and the
inner portions of the coma; note that the proper motion of 177P is now quite
rapid and longer exposures (even on the order of 45 seconds) are resulting
in nuclear elongation. We detected what might be a slight sunward extension
this morning and well as some slight indication of tail separation, in spite
of quarter moonlight.

I will post this image on the ASO site (Comet Page) in an hour or so.

Dr. Clay
-------------
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Wed, 19 Jul 2006 16:43:41 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  [Comet-Images]  177P/Barnard_2006_Jul_19 image
I just posted an image (60 sec CCD) of 177P from this morning on the Photos
section of this group; it is found as well at the ASO website Comets Table
at:

http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/ComC51630C.jpg

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Thu, 20 Jul 2006 01:22:40 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: 177P/Barnard_2006_Jul_16 image (Remanzacco Observatory).
> There does appear to be a bit of elongation to both the nucleus and the
> inner portions of the coma; note that the proper motion of 177P is now quite
> rapid and longer exposures (even on the order of 45 seconds) are resulting
> in nuclear elongation.

Hi dr.Clay,
thanks for your answer and image. I agree: the high proper motion (~4.1"/min) of this comet is a real problem: for this reason we were forced to stack a number (60) of short exposures (30 seconds each) shots, with a scope having a scale of ~2.5 arcsec/px. This resulted in a perfectly starlike central condensation.

What we (possibly) noticed is an elongation of the outer coma (say, ~3 arcmin radius from the central condensation). However this detail is just at the threshold limit stacking 60 exposures of 30 seconds, and possibly influenced by the luminosity of some backgroud stars.
Cheers,
Giovanni

________________________________________________________________
Il primo circolatore d'aria! Vornado riduce i costi e migliora il clima nelle case, rendendo la temperatura gradevole
http://click.libero.it/dmail

Date:  Wed, 26 Jul 2006 18:31:42 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Comet 2006 M4 (SWAN) image
Hi all,

I imaged newly discovered comet C/2006 M4 (SWAN) last Saturday night (22.27 July - UT) The image was taken through my 16" (41cm) f4.5 Newt with a Canon 10D DSLR camera. The cropped FOV is about 30' x 20'. I only had time to image 16 x 45 second exposures before rushing off to watch the All Blacks play South Africa in rugby. The comet was very low in the west (about 10 degrees up).

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_2006-m4-swan-060722-16x45sec-41cm@f4,5@800asa-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/occv6

Information and ephemerides re this comet can be found at:
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet2006m4-swan.htm

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Wed, 26 Jul 2006 17:19:36 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet 2006 M4 (SWAN) image
Nice image... The 22nd July was the last date I imaged the comet - and I doubt I
will see it again.

For your info, the orbital elements you have are a little out-of-date. The Minor
Planet Center elements of 21 July are:

Orbital elements:
C/2006 M4 (SWAN)
T 2006 Sept. 28.613 TT
q 0.77860 (2000.0)
Peri. 62.851
Node 148.746
e 1.0 Incl. 111.822
>From 39 observations 2006 July 12-21.

The elements I get by including my positions on July 22 are:
T 2006 Sept. 28.624 TT
q 0.77898 (2000.0)
Peri. 62.829
Node 148.745
e 1.0 Incl. 111.823

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

Date:  Sat, 29 Jul 2006 23:33:07 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Comet 177P Barnard  I imaged it so why couldnt I see it?
Comet 177P Barnard is currently magnitude 8.4. I imaged it last
night and thought I'd visually observe it and post an "eyepiece
view" image beside the camera image. But as carefully as I searched
the sky with my 14-inch SCT I could not see it!

Now I can assuredly see magnitude 8.4 stars with my 14-inch scope
from my VLM 5.6 site, so why couldn't I see the comet? The camera
of course saw it with ease on the six-inch astrograph.

Images and simulated eyepiece view of the invisible comet at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

I'd appreciate comments on the why I can't see a magnitude 8.4 comet
with my scope! Help! Please check out my site for details  they are
all there  and let me know what went wrong.

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Sun, 30 Jul 2006 17:36:33 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  VIS OBS and Images - 41P, C/2006M3, 71P (Clark)
Hi all,

I visually observed the following comets two nights ago (Fri 28 July 2006)...

CometObs - ( http://groups.yahoo.com/group/CometObs/ )

41/P
2006 July 28.36 UT: m1 = 12.0, Dia.= 4'.0, DC = 1, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [41P is very diffuse and faint. Much fainter than one month ago. No nucleus seen - just a diffuse patch of coma. No tail. 24˚ alt in the NW (Virgo). Stellar LM = 15.0 near comet (scope), dark rural sky]. Photo taken…

C/2006 M3
2006 July 28.38 UT: m1 = 8.5, Dia.= 6'.0, DC = 2, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [C/2006 M3 has a huge coma! Very large and diffuse. Looks like a large, loose globular cluster. No tail seen. A very faint nucleus seen. 26˚ alt in the NNW (Her). Stellar LM = 15.0 near comet (scope), dark rural sky]. Photo taken…

71P (Clark)
2006 July 28.41 UT: m1 = 11.0, Dia.= 2'.5, DC = 5, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [71P fairly easy to see. Smallish coma with some central condensation. No tail seen. 80˚ alt in the SE (Sag). Stellar LM = 15.8 near comet (scope), dark rural sky].

Charles Morris's, 'The New Comet Observations Page' ( http://cometobservation.com/ )

41P
2006 Jul. 28.36 UT: m1=12.0, Dia.=4'.0, DC=1, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [41P is very diffuse and faint. Much fainter than one month ago. No nucleus seen - just a diffuse patch of coma. No tail. 24˚ alt in the NW (Virgo). Stellar LM = 15.0 near comet (scope), dark rural sky]. Photo taken…

C/2006 M3
2006 Jul. 28.38 UT: m1=8.5, Dia.=6'.0, DC=2, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [C/2006 M3 has a huge coma! Very large and diffuse. Looks like a large, loose globular cluster. No tail seen. A very faint nucleus seen. 26˚ alt in the NNW (Her). Stellar LM = 15.0 near comet (scope), dark rural sky]. Photo taken…

71P (Clark)
2006 Jul. 28.41 UT: m1=11.0, Dia.=2'.5, DC=5, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [71P fairly easy to see. Smallish coma with some central condensation. No tail seen. 80˚ alt in the SE (Sag). Stellar LM = 15.8 near comet (scope), dark rural sky].

ICQ (International Comet Quarterly) ( http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/icq/CometMags.html )

41P
July 28.36, 12.0, 4'.0, John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand), 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)

C/2006 M3
July 28.38, 8.5, 6'.0, John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand), 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)

71P (Clark)
July 28.41, 11.0, 2'.5, John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand), 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)

Images from tonight can be seen at...

41P -
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet-41p-Tuttle-Giacobini-Kresak-060728-16x3-6min@800asa-41cm@f3,5@800asa-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/rx2oo

http://tinyurl.com/ozrrd

be. Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Tue, 01 Aug 2006 10:51:14 +0200

Date:  Tue, 01 Aug 2006 20:33:23 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Two faint comets
The first image is quite convincing. The stacking results in the comet being
circular, and the stars trailed.

The 2nd image (of C/2006 M1)is less convincing. Because it is a single exposure,
and (at least from what I can see on the image) there is no evident coma or
tail, this is (at least in my mind) a case of there being an object in the
expected position of the comet. When I do astrometry on such objects, I ALWAYS
make sure I have positions at two different epochs (at least) so that the
identification is confirmed by the motion. From that one image there is no
reason for concluding that the identified object is the comet.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From:
To: "Comet-Images"
Sent: Tuesday, August 01, 2006 6:51 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Two faint comets

Hi,
these are two faint and distant comets imaged a couple of nights ago:
http://tinyurl.com/no3de
http://tinyurl.com/kvudf

Cheers,
Giovanni and Luca

Remanzacco Observatory, Italy
http://www.afamweb.com
http://cara.uai.it

Yahoo! Groups Links 

Date:  Tue, 01 Aug 2006 15:08:15 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Two faint comets
> The first image is quite convincing. The stacking results in the comet being
> circular, and the stars trailed.
>
> The 2nd image (of C/2006 M1)is less convincing. Because it is a single exposure,
> and (at least from what I can see on the image) there is no evident coma or
> tail, this is (at least in my mind) a case of there being an object in the
> expected position of the comet. When I do astrometry on such objects, I ALWAYS
> make sure I have positions at two different epochs (at least) so that the
> identification is confirmed by the motion. From that one image there is no
> reason for concluding that the identified object is the comet.

Hi Dave,
in principle, I would have agreed with you.
However there are a number of reasons that convince me about the correct identification of this object:
1) indeed, it does have a tail; see:
http://tinyurl.com/emgst
2) it has a FWHM of 5.1" (field stars of comaprable magnitude have 4")
3) its S/N is above 9 (ulikely to be noise)
4) there is no counterpart in POSS catalogue in this position
5) its measured astrometric position lies within A.R.= 0.03s, Decl.= 0.15" from its predicted position.

Anyway, if these reasons are not enough for you, let's wait and see the astrometric residuals of our frame (we submit it to the MPC) in the next MPEC obital update of this comet.
Cheers,
Giovanni 

Date:  Tue, 01 Aug 2006 23:57:16 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Two faint comets
I guess there is an important point of difference...

When I report astrometry of faint moving objects, I _always_ make sure that I
can detect motion before I report a position. The fact that you have identified
an object at the 'predicted' position means no more than there is an object at
that location. To be sure that its the comet (and not a star or small galaxy),
you really need to be able to demonstrate motion. Note that a reported position
that is in accordance with the ephemeris will have acceptable residuals by
definition... - so that the MPC residual is of no guidance. Indeed, if you
happen to measure a star rather than the comet, the data will have a corrupting
impact on the MPC database! In this regard I'm sure the MPC operates on the
basis that the observer has good reason to believe that the object is the
particular object in question - and coincidence with the predicted place is (in
itself) a very poor determinative.

Oh - and I'm not convinced from your image about the tail. The faint elongation
could be caused by a faint background star - there are plenty of similar
markings in your image.

I should note that occasionally some observers don't report positions if the
residuals from the MPC orbit are significant - in an erroneous belief that their
observations might be wrong in some manner. This is the 'other side of the coin'
on the issue of coincidence of position with prediction. If you are sure that
the object you are measuring is the object in question, the size of the
residuals should not be relevant to whether or not you report the position. And
if you filter observations to those having a small residual - you will finish up
with a biased set of observations, and the orbit fit will be similarly biased
(and therefore erroneous). Similarly reporting observations of objects that
happen to be at the predicted location (with no other basis for identifying them
as the object in question) merely biases the observations data set to positions
that closely match the previously determined orbit, and not the actual object.

In conclusion, the way I see the situation is that you have a number of reasons
to believe that you _may_ have imaged the comet (and I would agree that this is
_likely_). But your one image is insufficient to establish that in fact you have
imaged the comet, and not something else. It really is a pity that you only have
the one image. And I would STRONGLY urge you to report positions of faint comets
only when you can demonstrate motion (or _clear_ cometary features).

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From:
To: "Comet-Images"
Sent: Tuesday, August 01, 2006 11:08 PM
Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] Two faint comets

> The first image is quite convincing. The stacking results in the comet being
> circular, and the stars trailed.
>
> The 2nd image (of C/2006 M1)is less convincing. Because it is a single
> exposure,
> and (at least from what I can see on the image) there is no evident coma or
> tail, this is (at least in my mind) a case of there being an object in the
> expected position of the comet. When I do astrometry on such objects, I ALWAYS
> make sure I have positions at two different epochs (at least) so that the
> identification is confirmed by the motion. From that one image there is no
> reason for concluding that the identified object is the comet.

Hi Dave,
in principle, I would have agreed with you.
However there are a number of reasons that convince me about the correct
identification of this object:
1) indeed, it does have a tail; see:
http://tinyurl.com/emgst
2) it has a FWHM of 5.1" (field stars of comaprable magnitude have 4")
3) its S/N is above 9 (ulikely to be noise)
4) there is no counterpart in POSS catalogue in this position
5) its measured astrometric position lies within A.R.= 0.03s, Decl.= 0.15" from
its predicted position.

Anyway, if these reasons are not enough for you, let's wait and see the
astrometric residuals of our frame (we submit it to the MPC) in the next MPEC
obital update of this comet.
Cheers,
Giovanni

Yahoo! Groups Links 

Date:  Tue, 01 Aug 2006 17:30:27 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Two faint comets
Dave,
I agree about the fact that all the points you listed (in particular the multiple exposures) is the rigorous procedure one must follow. And, incidently, this is what I normally do when imaging or measuring a comet (in this particular case, I used a single exposure because the others were ruined by some passing clouds). All in all, I'm pretty confident about its identification, for the reasons I listed previously. Yes, on a rigorous basys, this is not correct, and you are right. However, IMHO, all the hypothesis you need to find out to explain differently what in my picture is labelled as "C/2006 M1" (something that occupies the proper position and is not present in the POSS, with a good S/N, a nice comet-looking FWHM, does have a small tale, etc.) are less likely than the comet hypothesys itself.

And, to be ultimately rigorous, even the multiple exposure procedure is not enough. Actually you must go there and land on the comet to be absolutely sure about what you measured, since you can always be fooled by a passing asteroid that, during such particular time span, was moving along a path that simulates the comet's motion...

Cheers,
Giovanni

Date:  Thu, 03 Aug 2006 20:55:22 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Comet 177P Barnard Movie
Comet 177P is moving at a relative speed of 3.6 arc seconds per
minute against the star field in Hercules. This makes it difficult
to image as one must take short exposures so the comet is not
blurred  and autoguiding on a comet is very difficult.

But the good news is that the fast-moving comets make for nice
movies. I've put a short, modem-friendly 432 kb movie that shows
seven arc minutes of travel from 59 minutes of subframes.

Images, movie and accompanying data at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Fri, 04 Aug 2006 12:10:53 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  P/2006 HR30 (Siding-Spring) and 177P/Barnard
Hi all,
this is the link to an archive image of comet P/2006 HR30 (Siding Spring):
http://tinyurl.com/ft6nk

This is comet 177P/Barnard imaged on 2006, August 3.89:
http://tinyurl.com/kz49a

Both were imaged from the Remanzacco Observatory (Italy).

Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero and Ernesto Guido

http://www.afamweb.com
http://cara.uai.it

Date:  Sun, 06 Aug 2006 13:09:13 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  A Quick Notice
This summer has been as hot as any I can remember in my 55+ years.
When the heat is 104F for weeks and a cold front approaches bad things
happen. Lightning struck and entered my dome. It blew up 2 computers,
my FSQ refractor and the new FLI Maxcam 10. also my Losmandy GM8
mount. It somehow bypassed the surge protectors which were active.
travled through the scope and blew a hole in the lense cap and bent the
metal frame. It would have killed anyone working there. So much for
sad stories but let me say. If you don't have your equiptment
protected now, do it. Not that it will make any difference when
something really bad happens. I am going to take some pictures and
show the damage as I think all will enjoy to see what a really bad
mother nature can do.
Mike H. 

Date:  Sun, 06 Aug 2006 06:31:14 -0700
From:  FRANK GUTOWSKI 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] A Quick Notice
Hey Mike,

That really is some bad news.Always have enjoyed the
photos that you have put out. Was the equipment and
dome insured? Take care.

Frank G.

Date:  Sun, 06 Aug 2006 15:17:36 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] A Quick Notice
Hi Mike,
I'm sad to read about these bad news; I hope that you will be able to recover soon from this disaster, so we will be able to enjoy again your beautiful images.

We had a similar misfortune few years ago at our observatory, in Remanzacco: all the PCs, CCD, etc. were switched off and unplugged from the power live, *however* the internet cable was still plugged in. We get a lightening from the phone line, that fried our go-to telescope electronics, the PCs and the CCD...

Good luck,
Giovanni

lense cover has a hole blown in it. Other parts are blue from heat.
I will be back---sometime soon.
Mike H.

Date:  Sun, 06 Aug 2006 20:59:10 +0200
From:  Juan José González Suárez 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] A Quick Notice.
Dear Mike,

I too am very sorry for the damage in your observatory. But human life
is the most important consideration. As you say, the lightning would have
killed anyone working there.
Thirty years ago, I was involved in a long and hard mountain rescue of
a climber killed by a lightning strike in a difficult peak, Torre Santa,
rescue carried out in snow and cold conditions. I have been involved in
very different mountain and cave rescues for a very long time, but I will
never forget the experience in Torre Santa: the body killed by the
lightning make the difference.

You are alive. That is the most important thing. Stay safe ...

Best wishes,

Juan Jos Gonzlez

---------------------------------------

Date:  Mon, 07 Aug 2006 23:52:07 +0200

Date:  Mon, 07 Aug 2006 22:01:58 -0000
From:  Dave Kodama 
Subject:  Re: A Quick Notice
Mike,

Ouch! No doubt about what happened there! Sorry to hear about the
damage. Even in southern California we've been getting a lot of
thunderstorms with a spectacular show a couple of weeks ago at my
club's site:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/nature/2006/0722a/index.htm

During this storm, even though the lightning itself was an estimated 5
miles away at its closest, I personally saw a fence a few hundred feet
away light up as if it were a rope of fluorescent light bulb. Now I
always unplug all of my equipment power and signal cables on *both* ends.

Fortunately this storm skirted our site, but after several years of
enduring failures of our hard-wired LAN switches across our site, we
finally switched to fiber optics and so far we're OK this year.

Dave

Date:  Sun, 13 Aug 2006 14:23:28 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: A Quick Notice
Hello. I have had a lot of emails wanting to see the actual dome
entrance and exit of the lightning. Images have been loaded to the
same storage file. A couple of extras of the scope were also taken.
I want to say one thing. Some of the post and emails after my images
were published were excellent even though I don't understand the
lingo. I am currently trying to devise protection for my dome
without obstructing the view. I am also waiting for insurance to
show up which has now been 9 days.
Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/inv/DA17B09C38BDD42

Please accept my appologies for the somewhat off topic and please
keep the images of comets you take posted.

Date:  Fri, 18 Aug 2006 18:47:03 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  CLA001 still attempting to confirm
Still trying to salvage any possibility of recovering the object that I followed fo
rnearly two hours on August 17; many thanks to those who have been searching and who
have communicated results to me.

Some changes in the calculated position of my suspected comet can be substantial if the
large residuals are removed from the original observations; as originally stated,
getting a good astrometric center for this object was very difficult due to its large
size and low surface brightness. By 06h UT tonight (Aug. 19) the original ephemeris may
be off as much as 2.5 to 3.0 minutes because of questionable centroid locations. What
we followed is very large and faint with no discerable concentration. Questions of a
reflection are valid, but locking star motion in a computer program and allowing for
object proper motion suggests that this may not be the cause.

Using only the 9 observations with acceptable residuals based on recalculations by
Hirohisa Sato
Sukagawa, Fukushima, Japan

There is a substantial offset eastward in RA (about 2 arc minutes) for the calculated
positon of this object, should it exist.

**As an example, the New Object Ephemeris Generator provides (using only the 9
acceptable observations):
2006 08 19 00 22 31.58 +37 21.6 128.9 19.3 1.72 060.1 232 +11 +10
0.21 111 -17
2006 08 19 01 22 31.71 +37 22.5 128.9 19.3 1.71 059.8 239 +21 -02
0.21 111 -23
2006 08 19 02 22 31.83 +37 23.3 128.9 19.3 1.69 059.5 244 +32 -13
0.20 112 -26

**While the NEO Confirmation Page (MPC) which is utlizing all original observations:
2006 08 19 00 22 30 21.5 +37 21 23 128.9 18.8 1.37 053.6
2006 08 19 01 22 30 27.1 +37 22 12 128.9 18.8 1.37 053.6
2006 08 19 02 22 30 32.6 +37 23 00 128.9 18.8 1.37 053.7
-------------------------

>From H. Sato:
"The parabolic orbital elements by the observations of CLA001 is as follows.

Orbital elements:
CLA001
T 2006 July 24.5314 TT Sato
q 0.946157 (2000.0) P Q
Peri. 330.0026 +0.3788552 +0.9027568
Node 321.2102 -0.7712156 +0.1862939
e 1.0 Incl. 18.9764 -0.5115616 +0.3877174
>From 9 observations 2006 Aug. 17, mean residual 0".98.
Residuals in seconds of arc
060817 H45 1.2+ 1.6+ 060817 H45 (4.3+ 0.5+) 060817 H45 0.2+ 2.4+
060817 H45 (2.7+ 0.1-) 060817 H45 (2.8+ 1.8+) 060817 H45 0.9+ 0.5-
060817 H45 0.3+ 0.7- 060817 H45 (3.6+ 1.9+) 060817 H45 0.4+ 0.1-
060817 H45 0.6+ 0.3- 060817 H45 (5.7+ 3.5+) 060817 H45 0.1+ 1.7-
060817 H45 1.0+ 1.1- 060817 H45 0.1+ 0.4+ 060817 H45 (3.2+ 2.6+)

---------------
Thanks again to all. This was a very intriguing object and at this point I do not
believe it was a reflection or stray light based on the circumstances.

Clay
-------------
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/ 

Date:  Sat, 19 Aug 2006 11:37:36 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] CLA001 still attempting to confirm
I would still like to see an image.....

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From: "P. Clay Sherrod"
To:
Sent: Saturday, August 19, 2006 9:47 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] CLA001 still attempting to confirm

Still trying to salvage any possibility of recovering the object that I followed
fo
rnearly two hours on August 17; many thanks to those who have been searching and
who
have communicated results to me.

Some changes in the calculated position of my suspected comet can be substantial
if the
large residuals are removed from the original observations; as originally
stated,
getting a good astrometric center for this object was very difficult due to its
large
size and low surface brightness. By 06h UT tonight (Aug. 19) the original
ephemeris may
be off as much as 2.5 to 3.0 minutes because of questionable centroid locations.
What
we followed is very large and faint with no discerable concentration. Questions
of a
reflection are valid, but locking star motion in a computer program and allowing
for
object proper motion suggests that this may not be the cause.

Using only the 9 observations with acceptable residuals based on recalculations
by
Hirohisa Sato
Sukagawa, Fukushima, Japan

There is a substantial offset eastward in RA (about 2 arc minutes) for the
calculated
positon of this object, should it exist.

**As an example, the New Object Ephemeris Generator provides (using only the 9
acceptable observations):
2006 08 19 00 22 31.58 +37 21.6 128.9 19.3 1.72 060.1 232 +11
+10
0.21 111 -17
2006 08 19 01 22 31.71 +37 22.5 128.9 19.3 1.71 059.8 239
21 -02
0.21 111 -23
2006 08 19 02 22 31.83 +37 23.3 128.9 19.3 1.69 059.5 244
32 -13
0.20 112 -26

**While the NEO Confirmation Page (MPC) which is utlizing all original
observations:
2006 08 19 00 22 30 21.5 +37 21 23 128.9 18.8 1.37 053.6
2006 08 19 01 22 30 27.1 +37 22 12 128.9 18.8 1.37 053.6
2006 08 19 02 22 30 32.6 +37 23 00 128.9 18.8 1.37 053.7
-------------------------

>From H. Sato:
"The parabolic orbital elements by the observations of CLA001 is as follows.

Orbital elements:
CLA001
T 2006 July 24.5314 TT Sato
q 0.946157 (2000.0) P Q
Peri. 330.0026 +0.3788552 +0.9027568
Node 321.2102 -0.7712156 +0.1862939
e 1.0 Incl. 18.9764 -0.5115616 +0.3877174
>From 9 observations 2006 Aug. 17, mean residual 0".98.
Residuals in seconds of arc
060817 H45 1.2+ 1.6+ 060817 H45 (4.3+ 0.5+) 060817 H45 0.2+ 2.4+
060817 H45 (2.7+ 0.1-) 060817 H45 (2.8+ 1.8+) 060817 H45 0.9+ 0.5-
060817 H45 0.3+ 0.7- 060817 H45 (3.6+ 1.9+) 060817 H45 0.4+ 0.1-
060817 H45 0.6+ 0.3- 060817 H45 (5.7+ 3.5+) 060817 H45 0.1+ 1.7-
060817 H45 1.0+ 1.1- 060817 H45 0.1+ 0.4+ 060817 H45 (3.2+ 2.6+)

---------------
Thanks again to all. This was a very intriguing object and at this point I do
not
believe it was a reflection or stray light based on the circumstances.

Clay

Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories

> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "P. Clay Sherrod"
> To:
> Sent: Saturday, August 19, 2006 9:47 AM
> Subject: [Comet-Images] CLA001 still attempting to confirm
>
> Still trying to salvage any possibility of recovering the object that I followed
> fo
> rnearly two hours on August 17; many thanks to those who have been searching and
> who
> have communicated results to me.
>
> Some changes in the calculated position of my suspected comet can be substantial
> if the
> large residuals are removed from the original observations; as originally
> stated,
> getting a good astrometric center for this object was very difficult due to its
> large
> size and low surface brightness. By 06h UT tonight (Aug. 19) the original
> ephemeris may
> be off as much as 2.5 to 3.0 minutes because of questionable centroid locations.
> What
> we followed is very large and faint with no discerable concentration. Questions
> of a
> reflection are valid, but locking star motion in a computer program and allowing
> for
> object proper motion suggests that this may not be the cause.
>
> Using only the 9 observations with acceptable residuals based on recalculations
> by
> Hirohisa Sato
> Sukagawa, Fukushima, Japan
>
> There is a substantial offset eastward in RA (about 2 arc minutes) for the
> calculated
> positon of this object, should it exist.
>
> **As an example, the New Object Ephemeris Generator provides (using only the 9
> acceptable observations):

Date:  Sun, 20 Aug 2006 01:05:15 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Comet 177P Barnard  Easy to image  hard to observe!
Comet 177P Barnard is currently magnitude 8.5. Your planetarium
program probably says its 13.8, but that's wrong. The comet is
presently much brighter than the standard light curve predicts.

But it is a very diffuse blob, and pretty difficult to observe
visually. Observers and imagers in North America will find it
positioned nicely in Hercules. It transits in the early hours of
astronomical darkness. It is an excellent imaging target with a ten
arc minute coma. Alas, it has no tail.

Images sky finder maps and other info at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Date:  Tue, 22 Aug 2006 13:07:35 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Appendages of P/2006 HR30 (Siding Spring)
Hi all,
yesterday night we made a pretty long series of exposures about P/2006 HR30 (Siding Spring). According to our data, there are no new features visible on this comet, as recentrly claimed by one observer, but probably the evolution of those structures already mentioned in this mailing-list on August 5 and 6 by seberal observers, like (e.g.) Peter and Rafael.

In detail:
1) we have evidence of an extension toward PA354 deg, almost 0.4 arcmin long; an image is available here:
http://tinyurl.com/rweaw

2) a diffuse and sightly bent tail, some 2 arcmin long, toward PA 205 deg; an enhanced image is available here:
http://tinyurl.com/zubqu

Position and morphology of these features seems to correspond to those mentioned previously in mail nr. #10383, nr. #10390 (and subsequents) of this mailing-list.

Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero and Luca Donato (Remanzacco Obs., Italy)
http://www.afamweb.com
http://cara.uai.it

___________________________________________________________________
Mutui a tassi scontati da 30 banche. Richiedi online e risparmia.. Servizio gratuito.
http://click.libero.it/mutuionline2 

Date:  Wed, 23 Aug 2006 17:24:34 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Comet 177P  Movie and Seeing Comments
I made a small (243 kB) movie of 177P Barnard traversing 5 arc
minutes of sky. In all of my movies I usually see a bit of jitter
from frame-to-frame. I finally think I know the source of the
jitter I think it's seeing. My seeing for the movie was poor,
about Pickering 3 or 4 arc seconds or so FWHM. This is typical for
the Midwest USA.

If you look at the movie you will see the PSF of stars changing from
one frame to the next. It is easiest to see on the faintest stars.
The image scale is 2.5 arc seconds per pixel, re-sampled from 5.0
arc seconds per pixel in the original 2x2 binning.

Each frame is a four minute exposure, and I'd have thought that
seeing effects would average out during this long a period, but I
still think seeing is the predominant effect. I'd appreciate
comments from others on the root cause.

Movie and other info at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Thu, 24 Aug 2006 00:33:41 +0200
