In a message dated 8/27/06 6:51:59 AM, Tricks46 writes:

> Greetings!
> Thought you might like to see what has happened.  I was just amazed at the
> destruction
> Mike Holloway
> Holloway Comet observatory
> Van Buren, AR
>
> http://www.aoas.org/article.php?story=20060826165852113
>

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Mon, 28 Aug 2006 09:36:12 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Re: P/2006 HR30 (Siding Spring) on 2006, August 23
> There appears to be a tail trailing to the South-SouthWest. Is that
> new?

Hi Dennis,
IMHO this tail is an evolution of what was already visible on several deep shots obtained at the beginning of August: in particular I'm reffering to the images of Rafael Ferrando and Peter Birtwhistle:

http://tinyurl.com/hbmeb
http://tinyurl.com/en4q8

It looks like that the comet is evolving quickly, in spite of the coma aspect (still almost stellar in amateur's images).
Cheers,
Giovanni

1.9.2006 UT 21h00m:
http://www.astrosysteme.at/ikreator/asa/cms_pub/file_00000174/177P20060901UT2100v3.jpg

Date:  Sun, 03 Sep 2006 22:18:25 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images
> If you posted this as a new comet discovery I would wonder if it was
> a comet. (Looks?)

Hi Mike,
thanks for your comment. Yes, indeed this doesn't seem a comet, unless you increase the stretching parameters to show the faint outer coma and/or you check for its astrometry, comparing the field with the POSS survey.

It's an odd comet, that produces an almost starlike central condensation when it's experiencing in active phase, like during these days.

Cheers,
Giovanni 

Date:  Sun, 03 Sep 2006 22:58:37 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  P/2006 HR30  Siding Spring Uncomet-like Comet
I keep thinking the name is Sliding Spring, but the observatory in
Australia is in fact Siding Spring.

This 13.4 magnitude comet(?),was formerly designated an asteroid. In
my 45 minute image it sure looks more like an asteroid than a comet.
I was unable to capture any hint of a tail as others have.

Images, sky finder maps and other info at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Mon, 04 Sep 2006 10:14:06 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[comets-ml] P/2006 HR30  Siding Spring - no tail?
> I was unable to detect any hint of a tail in my 1 Sep image. Others
> have imaged a tail. Has it vanished or didn't I get enough signal
> during my moonlight exposrues?

Hi Dennis,
in the image obtained from the Remanzacco Observatory on 2006, August 31.81 (i.e. almost 8 hours before your shot) the faint tail toward South-West is just a hint even on the negative and false colors palette, while the diffuse detail toward North is visible with higher contrast:

http://tinyurl.com/o6xuv

It's plenty possible that it's vanishing; another possibility is due to its extremely low contrast, so if you don't match the appropriate sky conditions, you are prevented to evidence it: sometime we cannot see it as well, albeit we use the same instrumentation that showed it up readily just the night before.

Cheers,
Giovanni

Hi,
our image about 29P/Schwassmann-Wachmann obtained few hours ago:
http://tinyurl.com/f2otl
show that the comet is still in an active phase.

Now it's possible to see the typical after outburst spiral-like coma of 29P that starts to develope.

Date:  Sun, 10 Sep 2006 14:34:38 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: A Quick Notice
Greetings. There are two images posted in the same file showing
progress on a home made lightning protection for a rotating dome.
How to get to the center or close and still be able to rotate the
observatory. This is not finished but for $134.00 and about 1 hour
of my time I feel this will help although if lightning wants you it
will get you. The images show the observatory which was designed
from the ground up to handle a fiberglass dome and a 12x12 office.
Power is not to the building yet and I need to trim the grass. If
you have any ideas to add to this project please tell me as this is
not finished. I would sudgest that anyone like myself that has an
observatory with no trees or structures to divert a strike consider
some kind of protection.
I am sorry for this off topic but if I can help one other person it
would be worth it. I have new equiptment on order now and will be
moving to a 5" Televue 127is 660mm @ F5.2 without a FR and F4.6? 530mm
with it. Also a bigger go-to mount to handle the added size. I was
not going to put the new equiptment up untill changes were made to
help protect from another lightning strike.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/inv/DA17B09C38BDD42

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Holloway"
wrote:
>
> This summer has been as hot as any I can remember in my 55+ years.
> When the heat is 104F for weeks and a cold front approaches bad
things
> happen. Lightning struck and entered my dome. It blew up 2
computers,
> my FSQ refractor and the new FLI Maxcam 10. also my Losmandy GM8
> mount. It somehow bypassed the surge protectors which were
active.
> travled through the scope and blew a hole in the lense cap and bent
the
> metal frame. It would have killed anyone working there. So much
for
> sad stories but let me say. If you don't have your equiptment
> protected now, do it. Not that it will make any difference when
> something really bad happens. I am going to take some pictures and
> show the damage as I think all will enjoy to see what a really bad
> mother nature can do.
> Mike H.
>

> This 13.4 magnitude comet(?),was formerly designated an asteroid.

> my 45 minute image it sure looks more like an asteroid than a

visible anymore; however there is still some evidence of a faint
structure (jet, fan or whatever) toward North:

Giovanni & Ernesto

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "gvnn64\@...\.it"
wrote:
>
> Hi Hichael,
> this picture is amazing! Which was the comet altitude at the time of
your shoots?
> Cheers,
> Giovanni
>

Date:  Fri, 22 Sep 2006 12:14:04 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  4p Faye from last night
Sent: Friday, September 22, 2006 2:07 PM
Subject: 2006/09/22 comet 4p-Faye

Observations of comet 4p Faye (magn 11.2) on Sept 22 , 2006
Dist: 0.8259 AU (123.6 million km)

http://img158.imageshack.us/img158/635/4pfaye20060922ppt7.jpg

The movement of the comet in front of the stars was obviously slow.
The sky transparance was exellent considering the average
circumstances on location.
Probaply a moderate föhn-wind from the south.

10 inch Newtonian/ATK-1HS f/4.8)
Best regards,
Ralf Vandebergh 

Date:  Fri, 22 Sep 2006 14:17:59 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  anti-tail for 4P Faye?
These images of 4P Faye from last night, under, for this location,
exellent air transparance,may show a sign of some anti-tail.
(arrowed in the negative)but I'm not sure,see:

http://img46.imageshack.us/img46/4082/4pfaye20060922p1hc5.jpg

Best regards,
Ralf Vandebergh 

Date:  Fri, 22 Sep 2006 16:43:17 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] anti-tail for 4P Faye?
> These images of 4P Faye from last night, under, for this location,
> exellent air transparance,may show a sign of some anti-tail.

Hi Ralf,
our images obtaind almost simultaneusly, doesn't show the detail you mentioned. What we can readily see on the imaging we made on two separate nights, is a clear asimmetry of the coma (visible also on your images) likely due to the presence of a fan-like feature developing clockwise in N-E direction:
http://tinyurl.com/n6yoy
The scale of the image is almost 0.9"/px, the FWHM of the fields stars was close to 2"

Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero and Ernesto Guido
(Remanzacco Observatory, CARA)

http://www.afamweb.com
http://cara.uai.it

Date:  Sun, 24 Sep 2006 11:42:51 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Several comets from last night
In your last image,
http://tinyurl.com/r8nuv
it says 35 exposures, 90 seconds each. That's at least
52.5 minutes total.

Why are there are no elongated stars (trails)??

TheSky6 shows for Chiron:
RA rate (arcsecs/sec): -0.0008
Dec rate (arcsecs/sec): -0.0005

that is SQRT(X^2 + y^2) = 0.001064 (arcsecs/sec for
3150 secs or 3.35 arc secs or a little more the FWHM
of a star in good seeing.

Great images. This is just a question from my own
curiosity.

Charles Bell

Date:  Mon, 25 Sep 2006 00:39:15 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Several comets from last night
Hi Charles!

> Why are there are no elongated stars (trails)??

> 3150 secs or 3.35 arc secs or a little more the FWHM
> of a star in good seeing.

The problem is that at the time of our exposure, the seeing was awful, and object ~25 deg above the horizon. To make it short, the FWHM of the field stars is ~6.5 arcsec and, actually, you can notice that they looks like defocused: it's not a real defocusing, but the effect of the bad seeing!

> Great images. This is just a question from my own
> curiosity.

Thanks, no problem: it was a pertinent question.
Cheers,
Giovanni

------------------------------------------------------
Dimagrire in 30 Giorni! Con New Giorno e Notte!
http://click.libero.it/webnation

Date:  Thu, 28 Sep 2006 12:47:43 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Possible splitting of P/2006 S1 (Christensen)
Hi,
on 2006, September 27.84 we imaged P/2006 (Christensen) from the Remanzacco Observatory (0.45m reflector + CCD). On our multiple stackings (28 unfilterd exposures, 60 seconds each, scale 1.9"/px, seeing FWHM= 4") a secondary nucleus or condensation is well visible:
http://tinyurl.com/p8455
Upon blinking, this tailward appendage is moving together with the main nucleus. The main condensation has m2= 17.7, the secondary has m2= 18.5 (unfiltered magnitudes, USNO-B1 catalogue) and is placed almost 10" in PA 240 deg from the main one. The secondary component appears less condensed than the main one; both nuclei are embedded within a tail extending 1.5' toward PA 240 deg. Our images, obtained on 2006, Sept. 20.97 with the same instrumentation (stellar limiting magnitude almost 20), show nothing in the vicinity of the primary nucleus.

The secondary condensation in P/2006 S1 (Christensen) seems to be significantly similar to those we observed last May on 73P/Schwassmann-Wachmann, during its consecutive splitting events. Additonal observations are encouraged.

Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero and Ernesto Guido (Remanzacco Observatory, CARA)

------------------------------------------------------
Perdi 2 Taglie in 60 Giorni! Con PerdiPeso Cerotto rimodellante!
http://click.libero.it/webnation1

540mm and KAF 1603).

michael

seeing FWHM= 4") a secondary nucleus or condensation is well visible:

> Upon blinking, this tailward appendage is moving together with the
main nucleus. The main condensation has m2= 17.7, the secondary has
m2= 18.5 (unfiltered magnitudes, USNO-B1 catalogue) and is placed

Date:  Thu, 28 Sep 2006 16:10:21 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Re: Possible splitting of P/2006 S1 (Christensen)
> interested thing. on sep 23.9 UT i could only see one cc (with f-
> 540mm and KAF 1603).

Hi Michael,
thanks for your reply: on our images of Sept. 20, it wasn't present, neither. I hope that someone will be able to image it soon (goog S/N is needed), since looking at our frames, the suspect is that we are possibly seeing at a cloud of debris (like in 73P-B) instead of a "solid" secondary nucleus. From 73P-B, we understand the lesson that this kind of features could show a very quick variability (from hours to days) and that they could have a pretty short lifetime...

Cheers,
Giovanni

------------------------------------------------------
Perdi 2 Taglie in 60 Giorni! Con PerdiPeso Cerotto rimodellante!
http://click.libero.it/webnation1

Date:  Sun, 01 Oct 2006 09:59:52 -0400
From:  KCStarguy@aol.com
Subject:  Comet Swan in the morning

Comet Swan in the morning
For those who are interested in observing a bright comet (now a little below
6th magnitude) for the Siilver or Gold comet award, check out Comet Swan. It
has nice tail and can be seen in the morning. Use your favorite planetarium sky
program or look at spaceweather.com with the mapsfor early October.

Dr. Eric Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com), Olathe, KS: State of Kansas Solar
System Ambassador: Comet Observers Coordinator- Astronomy League/ Astronomical
Society of Kansas, KC, MO-Louisburg,KS:
http://www.astroleague.org/al/obsclubs/comet/comet.htm: CometObserversAwardAL-subscribe@yahoogroups.com - Dr. Eric
Flescher (kcstarguy@aol.com), Olathe, KS: State of Kansas Solar System
Ambassador:
E.O.A.S. (Earth, Oceans, Atmosphere and Space Blog) -<
http://www.xanga.com/dreric1kansas>
: Subscribe to (send your email to)< blacksuneclipse-subscribe@egroups.com>
:Eric's Black Sun Eclipse Website-
http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/blacksun/eclipse.htm: Satori Astronomy Website-
http://members.aol.com/kcstarguy/satoriastronomy/satoriastronomy.htm

An: Comet Images Yahoo
Betreff: [Comet-Images] C/2006 M4 SWAN 09-30

Hi,

We had a clear sky this morning over here at the North-Sea coast and I took
the opportunity to image C/2006 M4 SWAN.

In spite of a low altitude and some light pollution, the comet shows very
well!

http://www.klaas-
r_web.jpg>
jobse.net/cyclops/kometen/20060930_M4%20_comb9x60s_zwcollor_web.jpg

http://www.klaas-

Date:  Mon, 02 Oct 2006 19:43:54 +0000
From:  Bernd Brinkmann 
Subject:  C2006 M4 from 10/01/2006
Hello,

here http://www.sternwarte-herne.de/kometen/2006m4.html you can find an
image I took yesterday from the Sternwarte Kirchheim in Thuringia,
Germany with a 500 mm f/5 Newton an a SBIG ST-L 6303 camera.

Clear skies
Bernd 

Date:  Mon, 02 Oct 2006 14:13:45 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C2006 M4 from 10/01/2006
That is a very fine image of the tail structure.

It is encouraging to learn that this can be
accomplished with an SBIG camera, and that it does not
require a Schmidt camera.

The Schmidt camera images posted here recently are
superb.

I am curious if you see in your images any changes in
the tail structure with time?

Perhaps when it gets further above the horizon, this
could make an interesting study. Your camera/scope
combination resolve the tail of this comet very well.

This is something I have not been able to do well with
my equipment which are probably all I will ever be
able to afford.

Best wishes,

Charles

--- Bernd Brinkmann
wrote:

Date:  Thu, 05 Oct 2006 19:37:25 -0000
From:  dougdurig 
Subject:  Images of Comet SWAN 2006 M4 and Comet Levy 2006 T1
I have posted some of my recent images of Comet SWAN. The tail structure seems to show
almost daily changes, but I am not sure how much may be due to atmospheric conditions.
I also included an image of Comet Levy from last night which was a stack of 120 x 30 sec
exposures and still there is only a hint of a tail.

The images can be found on my quick link webpage at

http://arthur.sewanee.edu/obsv/view.php

Date:  Fri, 06 Oct 2006 08:16:41 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images
Could you please comment on the equipment and
processing used to create your wonderful images?

I know very little about a schmidt camera.

I know they are very expensive!

Is this camera equipment owned by an observatory or
university or is it something a self financed
astronomer could ever afford?

Since you do not mention a CCD camera, do you take a
film image and then digitize it?

Also, is JGER & RHEMANN a team of two astronomers or
part of an observatory team?

I wonder if a series of images taken perhaps 60
minutes apart would reveal propagation detail in the
tail? Perhaps it might show rotation with time? If so
are there astronomy papers published with any
analyses?

Thanks for posting your images. They are terrific.

Date:  Fri, 06 Oct 2006 23:07:47 -0000
From:  schmidtcamera2500 
Subject:  Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images
hello charles

thank you four your nice words.
we are amateur astronomer. the schmidtcamera is now around 15 years
old. some times ago i changed from film to ccd. this year i get
a corrector for working with larger sensors.

the images you see are taken with a SIGMA 1603 (KAF 1603ME sensor).
maybe i will change in the next time to a KAF6303

michael

Date:  Sat, 07 Oct 2006 22:12:35 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  M4 Swan full moonlight observation
Structures were very faint with full moonlight and an altitude from
the comet of only 12°.But is is my first observation of M4 Swan
and the evening-appearance is clearly started.
Despite the poor circumstances,sky was clear and some image-processing
revealed nice thin 'streamers'from the coma into the gas-tail.
It wil become interesting when the moonlight is away and M4 Swan
is at a higher altitude soon.

http://img176.imageshack.us/img176/2968/c2006m4swan20061007puy8.jpg

Best regards,
Ralf Vandebergh
10inch Newton/ATK-1HS@f/4.8) 

Date:  Sat, 07 Oct 2006 23:42:43 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  unique 73P/B view
Hi all, the previous mail showed the current comet, now some other
work of the great May comet;
Animation of images obtained on May 5 , 2006 of fragment B from comet
Schwassmann-Wachmann-3,
here fragmented into a short chain of mini-fragments.

http://img215.imageshack.us/img215/7769/73pbkopiekc6.gif

10 inch Newtonian/ATK-1HS)

Best regards,
Ralf Vandebergh 

Date:  Sun, 08 Oct 2006 01:55:58 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  2006 M4-After Sun Set?
Greetings.
I was in the observatory tonight trying to get the new mount in some
kind of shape using a new scope that as yet doesn't have the
attachments to connect my camera. I managed to get the eyepiece to
work and to see how close I was to go-to abilities. I put in 2006 M4.
It was still light in the west but there was a small fuzzy. Tried to
connect a 120mm 35mm lense to the camera but it was just too low and
not enough time was there. Good to see that it is now accessible after
dark in the N/W sky.

Thanks, Mike H. 

Date:  Sun, 08 Oct 2006 11:58:33 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  Re: 2006 M4-After Sun Set?
Hi Mike,
I looked through the eyepiece too,before starting my imaging-
session,see previous mail.Due to the moonlight, I did not see it
through the binoculair or the finder scope,but it was an easy
object in my 10 inch Newton and visible at 60x as a globular cluster-
like object.

Ralf

Date:  Thu, 12 Oct 2006 01:08:16 +0200
From:  Ralf Vandebergh 
Subject:  possible  jets M4 SWAN_Oct 10
subject: possible jets M4 SWAN Oct 10 , 2006

sum of exposures between 0.5 and 10 sec from 19:01 -- 19:45 UTC

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 12 Oct 2006 13:17:26 +0200
From:  Ralf Vandebergh 
Subject:  fw: possible  jets M4 SWAN_Oct 10
To give a better discription about this image: we see the dust tail at about PA 40 and
2 brighter jets.The brightest is at PA 185-190 and we see another one at PA 275-280.
the one at PA 185 was already easily visible in the original stack of short exposed(0.5s)
images.

http://img150.imageshack.us/img150/8184/m4swan20061010rgraddm1.jpg

Ralf

Sent: Thursday, October 12, 2006 1:08 AM
Subject: possible jets M4 SWAN_Oct 10

subject: possible jets M4 SWAN Oct 10 , 2006

sum of exposures between 0.5 and 10 sec from 19:01 -- 19:45 UTC

see:

http://img150.imageshack.us/img150/8184/m4swan20061010rgraddm1.jpg

Best regards,
Ralf

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 12 Oct 2006 14:00:02 +0200
From:  Ralf Vandebergh 
Subject:  observations dust tail M4 SWAN
subject: observations dust tail M4 SWAN

date: Oct 7 ,2006
The shape of the coma looks typically like Hyacutake,This Rgrad processing
shows a good extended dust-tail:

http://img151.imageshack.us/img151/9527/m4swan20061007dusttailvi9.jpg

Best regards,
Ralf Vandebergh

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 12 Oct 2006 21:36:47 +0200
From:  Ralf Vandebergh 
Subject:  Re: possible  jets M4 SWAN_Oct 10
Subject: fw: possible jets M4 SWAN_Oct 10

The previous image I posted concerning this subject was not of maximal quality
proved later, it was caused by the failure I made by using JPEG for the pre-result.
I attach a new link to the better result:

http://img121.imageshack.us/img121/9937/m4swan20061010rgradaqe4.jpg

Best regards,
Ralf Vandebergh

Sent: Thursday, October 12, 2006 1:17 PM
Subject: fw: possible jets M4 SWAN_Oct 10

To give a better discription about this image: we see the dust tail at about PA 40 and
2 brighter jets.The brightest is at PA 185-190 and we see another one at PA 275-280.
the one at PA 185 was already easily visible in the original stack of short exposed(0.5s)
images.

http://img150.imageshack.us/img150/8184/m4swan20061010rgraddm1.jpg

Ralf

Date:  Fri, 13 Oct 2006 07:55:36 -0000
From:  kometman55 
Subject:  comet SWAN and cirrus clouds
Hi everybody!

Yesterday we had pitch with the weather. Overcasted sky by thick
cirrus clouds limited our possibilities to reach a good shot of the
comet. But in a small window the clouds are more thin and we exposed:

http://www.astrostudio.at/Astrofotos/astrofotos.php?k_id=69

Michael and Gerald

Date:  Fri, 13 Oct 2006 12:29:49 +0200
From:  Ralf Vandebergh 
Subject:  M4-SWAN and a new technique(Oct 8)
subject: M4-SWAN and a new technique_observations Oct 8

The image shows again a good extended dust-tail at left, a large outer-coma and structures
in the Ion-tail.Observations from Oct 8 processed using a new technique in which I
combined a filtered processing with a standard image.

http://img214.imageshack.us/img214/9272/m4swan20061008rgrpca1.jpg

images: 10inNewtonian/ATK-1HS camera @f/4.8)

Best regards,
Ralf Vandebergh

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Fri, 13 Oct 2006 12:38:07 +0200
From:  Ralf Vandebergh 
Subject:  M4-SWAN and a new technique(Oct 8)
Another 2 processings can be found here:
http://img83.imageshack.us/img83/3158/m4swan20061008rgrapdy9.jpg

Note especially the large outer coma.

Ralf

Subject: M4-SWAN and a new technique(Oct 8)

subject: M4-SWAN and a new technique_observations Oct 8

The image shows again a good extended dust-tail at left, a large outer-coma and structures
in the Ion-tail.Observations from Oct 8 processed using a new technique in which I
combined a filtered processing with a standard image.

Date:  Fri, 13 Oct 2006 13:01:47 -0000
From:  kometman55 
Subject:  overview of developement comet M4 Swan
Hi everybody again!

We have just posted a nice overview of the developement of this comet
from Sept.30 up to Oct. 11. All pictures are taken with the same
instruments (Schmidtcamera and Sigma 1603 ccd camera)

http://www.astrostudio.at/Astrofotos/astrofotos.php?k_id=69

Michael and Gerald 

Date:  Fri, 13 Oct 2006 13:15:36 -0000
From:  kometman55 
Subject:  comet M4Swan developement documentation
Hi everybody!

We have just updated our website with a documentation of the
development of comet M4 Swan. All pictures are taken with the same
instrumentation. Schmidtcamera with ASA correctorlens and with
1603Sigma CCDcamera:

http://www.astrostudio.at/Astrofotos/aufnahme.php?a_id=527&page=1&kategorie=&k_id=69

Michael and Gerald 

Date:  Fri, 13 Oct 2006 17:05:55 -0000
From:  gvnn64 
Subject:  Re: possible  jets M4 SWAN_Oct 10
Hi Ralf,
yes, C/2006 M4 (SWAN) do show a very structured inner coma, with a
prominent solar-pointing fan. We are observing it since last week:
http://tinyurl.com/ydfgxj
http://tinyurl.com/uawf9
http://tinyurl.com/y7scoo
but we didn't care to report this stuff because, as noted by Eric
Christensen on [Comets-ml] about a similar feature observed previously
on 4P/Faye, this kind of solar-pointing fans seems to be as common as
ordinary tails, for most of the active comets.
Cheers,
Giovanni 

Date:  Fri, 13 Oct 2006 22:11:55 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  Re: comet M4Swan developement documentation
Hello Michael and Gerald,
Thanks for sending me this exellent overview.

Best wishes,
Ralf

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sat, 14 Oct 2006 20:01:56 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Is The Comet Images Group Still Alive?
You better beleive it! How many comet imagers are there in the world
compaired to those that choosen to image other sky wonders, which for
the most part are always there or will be back next year. 262
members is more than I would ever have dreamed would have joined.
Dave and I started this for a rare kind of imager. The comet imager.
Comets come from everywhere at magnitudes as varied as there
outburst. Members of this board are published in magazines,
scientific articles - studies, text books and yes the adds in sales
broshures. For my part I am as proud of the members here as I can
be. I know how hard a comet is to image because I am totally hooked
on putting them on a chip. Comet imagers need to be ready to go out
with a nights notice to photograph an object that might only show for
a few minutes a day or get ready for a comet that is years away from
an encounter. Searching the skys not only try to somehow put the
known objects on record but searching the skys to discover the new
faint fuzzies still out there. Imaging areas that sometimes can't be
distinguished from chip noise and faint areas that show what most
people could care nothing about and surly would never drive miles in
all weather to image. To get excited about something that most time
is at the limit of even the most powerfull ccd's and to faint to show
color because what detail is there would be lost if color filters are
used. Not much glory but great personal satisitifaction is what is
received.
Is this board dead? Not even close! Not one time have any members
been called on by Dave or myself for attacks to another member for
flaming on this board. Images just keep coming in and help is always
there when ask for. Member names are seen in all media. You supply
and contribute without reward most time. You are a few that know and
understand what comet imaging can bring for personal satisifaction
and I will say only a comet imager knows what I am saying. Members
go out at a moments notice to confirm or backup anothers observation
and are glad to do it when the only objective in mind is to help.
Is this board dead? No Way! I can't name individual people
because this board is a collective of imagers all contributing images
as there sky permits. You area few special people in the world and
I, for one, thank you.
Thanks
Mike Holloway 

Date:  Sat, 14 Oct 2006 15:45:14 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Is The Comet Images Group Still Alive?
Excellent....good work Mike.

Dr. Clay
-------------
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

You better beleive it! How many comet imagers are there in the world
compaired to those that choosen to image other sky wonders, which for
the most part are always there or will be back next year. 262
members is more than I would ever have dreamed would have joined.
Dave and I started this for a rare kind of imager. The comet imager.
Comets come from everywhere at magnitudes as varied as there
outburst. Members of this board are published in magazines,
scientific articles - studies, text books and yes the adds in sales
broshures. For my part I am as proud of the members here as I can
be. I know how hard a comet is to image because I am totally hooked
on putting them on a chip. Comet imagers need to be ready to go out
with a nights notice to photograph an object that might only show for
a few minutes a day or get ready for a comet that is years away from
an encounter. Searching the skys not only try to somehow put the
known objects on record but searching the skys to discover the new
faint fuzzies still out there. Imaging areas that sometimes can't be
distinguished from chip noise and faint areas that show what most
people could care nothing about and surly would never drive miles in
all weather to image. To get excited about something that most time
is at the limit of even the most powerfull ccd's and to faint to show
color because what detail is there would be lost if color filters are
used. Not much glory but great personal satisitifaction is what is
received.
Is this board dead? Not even close! Not one time have any members
been called on by Dave or myself for attacks to another member for

there when ask for. Member names are seen in all media. You supply

Date:  Sun, 15 Oct 2006 20:10:59 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Now Three Bright Comets to Image
There are presently three bright comets to image:
C/2006 M4 (SWAN) magnitude 6.4 (7.9)
4P/Faye magnitude 9.4 (10.7)
P/2006 T1 (Levy) magnitude 9.6 (11.2)

Note: The above magnitudes are correct  they are the currently
observed values. Your planetarium programs will indicate different
calculated magnitudes, as indicated above in parentheses. The
calculated magnitudes are usually greatly in error.

I imaged the brightest of the three - C/2006 M4 (SWAN) - because it
was well positioned at sunset  the other two require staying up
quite late to get them at transit.

Images and supporting data at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Sun, 15 Oct 2006 19:02:46 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Comet 4P/Faye October 15, 2006 0426UT
Comet 4P/Faye October 15, 2006 0426UT

http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/imagefiles/4P-10152006-0426UT.jpg

40 minutes total exposure
20 x 120 sec subframes stacked with CCDSoft
Log-log stretch applied with Fits Liberator plug in
and Adobe Photoshop CS2

0.75 arc secs/pixel or about 80 pixels per arc minute
Approximate field of view: 20 x 15 arcminutes

Meade 12 inch LX-200GPS at F/6.3 + ST-2000XCM + AO7

Imaged under very dark sky under average seeing.

C. Bell H47 Vicksburg
http://www.quantumhyperspace.com/

Date:  Mon, 16 Oct 2006 10:07:02 -0400
From:  Maynard Pittendreigh 
Subject:  [Comet-Images] Faye images passing a galaxy, taken over several nights.
I posted some photos of Faye on my astronomy blog page. On several
consecutive photos I set the telescope to the exact same position, thus
showing the movement through the skies. Go to
http://myquestar.blogspot.com/

I was unaware of Faye passing close to the field of view of anything, but by
coincidence I captured a galaxy in these photos.

Maynard Pittendreigh

www.MyQuestar.com

Date:  Mon, 16 Oct 2006 15:04:50 +0200
From:  Ralf Vandebergh 
Subject:  spinning of M4 core?
I made this animation of observations of the core-area of M4 SWAN yesterday evening (Oct 15)
Possibly there is a sign of some effects caused by the comet's spinning visible:

movie:
http://img165.imageshack.us/img165/739/m4swan2006101518201944wc7.gif

images:
http://img150.imageshack.us/img150/1420/m4swancore20061015bwqx0.jpg

Best regards,
Ralf Vandebergh

Eric 

Date:  Mon, 16 Oct 2006 21:38:55 -0000

Date:  Tue, 17 Oct 2006 23:52:30 +0200
From:  Ralf Vandebergh 
Subject:  Re: spinning of M4 core?
This is a 3-frame animation of images from the Oct 16 session of the core-area of M4-SWAN(R-gr filtered)
Interesting maybe is the movement of the bright patch in direction of the Ion-tail at PA~45 compared to
the 'lob' with faint jets actually part of the coma in the sunward position at PA~225 which seems to be a at one steady position.

time stretch of this animation: 18:17 UTC -- 19:41 UTC

http://img178.imageshack.us/img178/893/m4swan20061016rgrcorere4.gif

Best regards,
Ralf

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Wed, 18 Oct 2006 11:45:12 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: spinning of M4 core?
I've been watching this thread with interest, and make the following comments.

1. There is no doubt that your 3 images show differences. But the critical issue
is the explanation for the differences - and whether a range of potential causes
are sufficiently excluded.

2. I find the animation too fast to analyse carefully. Also, it is not apparent
which image is the first in the sequence. So while the animation highlights the
variation, it detracts from analysis.

3. My assumption is that the comet is still somewhat difficult to observe in the
twilight. After all, you _only_ have 3 images. Significantly some of the
variation in the images is strongly suggestive of twilight effects - notably the
different extent of the faint regions.

4. It is not apparent to me how you have co-aligned all the images - and thus
the extent to which any displacements might be alignment-related. Similarly,
have the 3 images been identically processed?

5. It is also not apparent to me what the scale of the images are. That is, are
the variations occurring over a distance at the comet of 1,000km, 10,000km,
100,000km or 1,000,000km. This issue is important in the context of assessing
whether variations over the time scale are consistent with the spatial area
involved.

6. Trying to deduce systemic variability from 3 images is a hard ask. Random
variations can easily appear as ordered variations. Particularly for small-scale
features, IMHO you need to have _at least_ 5 images that show a consistent
variation to exclude random variations, and the other possible issues that have
been suggested by others.

So, while I'm not prepared to conclude there are no rotational effects involved,
at this time I don't believe your images are sufficient to establish their
existence. In my mind there are too many issues that aren't clearly excluded....

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From: "Ralf Vandebergh"
To: "Ralf Vandebergh" ; ;

Sent: Wednesday, October 18, 2006 7:52 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Re: spinning of M4 core?

Interesting maybe is the movement of the bright patch in direction of the
Ion-tail at PA~45 compared to
the 'lob' with faint jets actually part of the coma in the sunward position at
PA~225 which seems to be a at one steady position.

time stretch of this animation: 18:17 UTC -- 19:41 UTC

http://img178.imageshack.us/img178/893/m4swan20061016rgrcorere4.gif

Best regards,
Ralf

Date:  Wed, 18 Oct 2006 23:23:18 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] Re: [Comet-Images] Re: spinning of M4 core?
The Oct 8 animation is _far_ more convincing of short-term changes in the ion
tail. However (i) the images you have combined are clearly of different exposure
(as indicated by at least one image with a short star trail length) - and the
greatest tail displacement is associated with this image of different exposure
(which raises questions of whether the displacement is real or
exposure-related), (ii) again the animation is too fast to critically analyse,
(iii) the images are not contiguous, so that you have no sense of continuity in
any variations, and (iv) it doesn't look like you have many images involved.

I mention these issues in the hope that you will be able to make future
animations that avoid these issues - such that there can be better confidence in
the apparent changes. In particular, it is _really_ important that you exclude
any differences that are under your control - so that differences in the images
cannot be attributed to those issues (such as processing issues). Thus you
should take a contiguous series of images (so that any changes are visibly
continuous), the images being of constant exposure - preferably relatively short
to avoid blurring of any tail motion, and have the same processing applied to
them before combining (even if the effects of twilight affect the image
density). And I would prefer to see more background than you have shown - as
this will better indicate general background variations that might indicate the
presence/absence of other issues.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From: "Ralf Vandebergh"
To: "Dave Herald" ; ;

Sent: Wednesday, October 18, 2006 7:32 PM

Date:  Thu, 19 Oct 2006 01:33:00 +0200
From:  Ralf Vandebergh 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: spinning of M4 core?
To bring this discussion to a good end, here are some images and animation
from a day later
(Oct 16) same technique used as the previous day.No special things are
visible except
a small jet at about PA~140 and a sign of fainter activity at PA~190
approximately.

Considering that the same technique was used, there is a thought that I may
registrated
some special activity on the 15th, which was able to cause such relative
impressive
changings in the images,whether rotation-related or not.

animation:
http://www.kk-system.co.jp/Alpo/kk06/e061016a1.gif

images:
http://www.kk-system.co.jp/Alpo/kk06/e061016a1.jpg

Best regards,
Ralf

From:  Ralf Vandebergh 
Subject:  comparison M4-SWAN nucleus area in 5 days
subject: comparison M4-SWAN nucleus-area in 5 days

I made a comparison of images obtained on 10/10 and 10/15.(Rot-grad filtered)
The general view seems similar, with the 2 obvious jets at PA~ 225 and PA~ 280 approximately.
Sorry for the difference in saturation,caused by the different circumstances:

http://img214.imageshack.us/img214/5173/m4swannucl20061015ya7.jpg

Date:  Fri, 20 Oct 2006 22:29:01 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 M4 - 10/20/2006
Hello.
I finally got enough equiptment together last night to take first image
after the lightning strike back on Aug 4th. The camera is my older
ST2000XM attached to a TV 127is 5" refractor at F5.2. The skys were
bad with haze and the comet was low in the N/W . This is a 4x30 sec
image with N up. Faint hint of coma detail on the top/North side being
pushed back to the east.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://fototime.com/60E2F4346983504/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 21 Oct 2006 00:21:20 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  Re: spinning of M4 core?

Here is a new animation of other frames from the oct 15 session,
is certainly worthy to look at:

http://img84.imageshack.us/img84/7292/m4swan20061015negsj7.gif

I re-processed and R-grad filtered images, even twice or even to third
to see if for every frame the same result came out,until there were no
differences.So I'm very sure that no processing factors are there.

There was certainly something going on on that evening.

Ralf

Date:  Sat, 21 Oct 2006 06:19:39 -0500
From:  "Dr. D. T. Durig" 
Subject:  Images of new 17th mag comet in Gemini !!!
There is a new comet in Gemini at about 17th mag with a tail longer than 10
arc minutes in longer images. I made a quick animation of five 20x30sec
stacks and have posted the image here:

http://arthur.sewanee.edu/obsv/view.php

Dr. D. T. Durig

Cordell-Lorenz Observatory

OBS COD 850

Date:  Sat, 21 Oct 2006 11:28:05 -0000
From:  ralf_vandebergh 
Subject:  Re: spinning of M4 core?
For clearity,
I do not say that it is certain rotation what we see, I only
mentioned the possibility of it,to discuss it,it is also possible
that we see activity of jets,which give only an impression of
rotation.Just want to report it.

Ralf

> Subject: [Comet-Images] Re: spinning of M4 core?
>
> Here is a new animation of other frames from the oct 15 session,
> is certainly worthy to look at:
>
> http://img84.imageshack.us/img84/7292/m4swan20061015negsj7.gif
>
> I re-processed and R-grad filtered images, even twice or even to
third
> to see if for every frame the same result came out,until there
were no
> differences.So I'm very sure that no processing factors are there.
>
> There was certainly something going on on that evening.
>
> Ralf
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>

Subject:  Re: Images of new 17th mag comet in Gemini !!!

or was it accidentally?

tanks,
Ralf

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Dr. D. T. Durig"
wrote:
>
> There is a new comet in Gemini at about 17th mag with a tail
longer than 10
> arc minutes in longer images. I made a quick animation of five
20x30sec
> stacks and have posted the image here:
>
> http://arthur.sewanee.edu/obsv/view.php
>
> Dr. D. T. Durig
>
> Cordell-Lorenz Observatory
>
> OBS COD 850

> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
> 

Date:  Sat, 21 Oct 2006 08:39:02 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: spinning of M4 core?
Ralf...you have been reporting this as rotation, spinning and the sort for two weeks
now. Now you want to be objective?
Not every observation will lead to a "discovery" of some sort. They are very valuable
images and badly needed by the community, but let the scientific community judge for
itself what we are dealing with, if anything. You have posted dozens of observations on
many forums about the "spinning" of this comet's nucleus, nothing which has been
substantiated by high resolution large telescopes around the world.

Your observations are valuable....just keep them objective.

Dr. Clay
-------------
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

From: "ralf_vandebergh"
To:
Sent: Saturday, October 21, 2006 6:28 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Re: spinning of M4 core?

> For clearity,
> I do not say that it is certain rotation what we see, I only
> mentioned the possibility of it,to discuss it,it is also possible
> that we see activity of jets,which give only an impression of
> rotation.Just want to report it.
>
> Ralf
>

Date:  Sat, 21 Oct 2006 14:40:21 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 - 10212006
Greetings.
http://www.fototime.com/D1A8F666EE326F2/orig.jpg
Thanks, Mike H. 

Date:  Sat, 21 Oct 2006 15:06:38 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 M4 - 10/21/2006
Greetings.
30x20 sec exposures. Standing back from the screen looking and also in
the processing I though I saw two streamers above the core and to the
right of the tail in the dust but camera is a little weak. Used the 5"
TV 127is refractor and ST2KXM ccd.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/8209C10AC94B351/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 21 Oct 2006 16:04:48 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  4/P - 10/21/2006
Hello.
http://www.fototime.com/AD4BBB102E3E916/orig.jpg
Thanks, Mike H

Date:  Sun, 22 Oct 2006 13:11:40 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: spinning of M4 core?
I fully support and encourage observations to be reported and discussed.

The main tenor of those that have bought into the discussion seems to be - we
are not convinced that the variations are not due to image processing issues.
[Sorry about the double negative - but that is the appropriate way of expressing
the issue...] There have been several suggestions made about how such issues can
be avoided, and I hope that these will be of assistance in the future.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From: "ralf_vandebergh"
To:
Sent: Sunday, October 22, 2006 7:41 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Re: spinning of M4 core?

give a suggestion of what possibly is visible on the image.
Thats not forbidden I guess?

Ralf

Date:  Sun, 22 Oct 2006 06:19:29 -0000
From:  rferrand1 
Subject:  Animations comet P/2006 U1
An animation of 6 takings of 60 seconds and another animation of 2
images (each image this formed by the sum of 18 images of 60 seconds)
http://www.manteka.com/Cometas/Paginas/Detalle.asp?ID=195

The field of the animations is of about 17x7 minutes of arch

Greetings
Rafa
941 

Date:  Sun, 22 Oct 2006 13:08:31 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 - P/96 Machholz
Looking at the animated orbits of these two comets, I was thinking of
how close these are at two dates. Differences are known but the fact
that one is going to be for the north and one for the south moving
opposite directions is what I see. The two links show.
C/2006 P1
http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/cgi-bin/db_shm?sstr=2006+p1&group=all
Run the animation to the date of Jan 9 2007.

96P Machholz
http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/cgi-bin/db_shm?sstr=96p&group=all
advance this one to April 9 2007.

All depends on daylight and your horizion view. Both north and south
will have a comet about the same unless of course I am missing
something.
Just looking ahead
Thanks, Mike H. 

Date:  Sun, 22 Oct 2006 15:58:16 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Re: Animations comet P/2006 U1
What is the magnitude of this comet? It must be fairly bright to be
imaged so nicely in a 60 second subframe? My usual sources (Seiichi
Yoshida and Skyhound) ) don't have it posted yet.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Date:  Mon, 23 Oct 2006 01:43:31 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /michael jaeger/2006U120061022UT2340s7x160s.jpg
Uploaded by : schmidtcamera2500
Description : 2006 U1 2006-10-22 UT 23.40 7x170 sec 8"/f-540mm SIG;MA 1603 JGER & RHEMANN

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/michael%20jaeger/2006U120061022UT2340s7x160s.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/help/us/groups/files

Regards,

schmidtcamera2500 

Date:  Mon, 23 Oct 2006 11:10:21 -0000
From:  kometman55 
Subject:  movie comet M4swan
Movie of comet C/2006 M4 Swan October 16

10 images are stacked together to show the drift of matter along the
tail in a period of approximately 30 minutes. Pictures have been taken
with an ASA Astrograph 8" f 2.75 and a FLI Maxcam10 by Michael Jäger
and Gerald Rhemann. Unfortunately a problem occured with the camera.
Every dark, biased and light frame shows a bright stripe at a
different location. Therefore the movie looks jerky.

http://www.astrostudio.at/common/video/page.php

Gerald and Michael 

Date:  Mon, 23 Oct 2006 21:36:07 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] movie comet M4swan
Still, a nice animation where you can gain confidence in the motions in the
tail....

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

10 images are stacked together to show the drift of matter along the
tail in a period of approximately 30 minutes. Pictures have been taken
with an ASA Astrograph 8" f 2.75 and a FLI Maxcam10 by Michael Jger
and Gerald Rhemann. Unfortunately a problem occured with the camera.
Every dark, biased and light frame shows a bright stripe at a
different location. Therefore the movie looks jerky.

http://www.astrostudio.at/common/video/page.php

Gerald and Michael

http://www.astrostu
dio.at/common/video/page.php

Gerald and Michael

Date:  Mon, 23 Oct 2006 10:03:53 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] movie comet M4swan
I noticed a knot in the tail that seemed to be moving
slightly with respect to the coma in the animation.
You would have to keep the comet stationary and let
the background move in order to see any relative
movement in the tail structure.

You can align centroids in gif images with CCDSoft.

--- Jose Pablo wrote:

> With his animation it can calculate speed of
> propagation gas and dust of tail .
>
> Kind Regards , Jose Pablo Navarro Pina
> MPC-J70

>
> 10 images are stacked together to show the drift
> of matter along the
> tail in a period of approximately 30 minutes.
> Pictures have been taken
> with an ASA Astrograph 8" f 2.75 and a FLI
> Maxcam10 by Michael Jger
> and Gerald Rhemann. Unfortunately a problem
> occured with the camera.
> Every dark, biased and light frame shows a bright
> stripe at a
> different location. Therefore the movie looks
> jerky.

Date:  Tue, 24 Oct 2006 04:09:05 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Comet 2002 L9 Neat - what's going on?
This comet is at about 9AU, but is still observable. I have posted a number of
images taken on Oct 10 & 11, ad 21, 22, and 23 at:

http://www.igomoo.com/aaa/index.php?option=com_rsgallery2&Itemid=26&page=inline&id=100&catid=29&limitstart=2

The images are stacks of between 5 and 8 images, each of 5 mins exposure (the
comet is faint!), and the image scale is about 1 arcmin per side. The images
have north up, east to the left - with the comet moving to the south-west. The
comet is at -43 deg.

I would like to hear the views of others as to what is going on. In particular,
the images of Oct 21 show a bright extended nucleus which appears bipolar - with
little tail. The image of Oct 22 shows a single condensation with some tail.
Tonight's image shows almost no condensation - but a sickle-shaped coma/tail.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia 

Date:  Mon, 23 Oct 2006 22:24:02 +0200
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  AW: [Comet-Images] movie comet M4swan

Gerald

Date:  Mon, 23 Oct 2006 22:21:56 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 - 10/23/2006
Greetings.
A 2x2 bin showing about 1 degree of sky across the image.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/ECBA1ED51C46694/orig.jpg 

Date:  Mon, 23 Oct 2006 23:50:17 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 M4 - 10/23/2006 - 3xMosaic
Hello. Put to gether a 3x mosaic. It is a 2x2 bin and left full size.
I reduced the file quality down to 350 kb and also posted a smaller
size. Comet is rotated to show sideways.
Thanks, Mike H.
Standard Size
http://www.fototime.com/81403B843094943/standard.jpg
Full Size
http://www.fototime.com/81403B843094943/orig.jpg 

Date:  Tue, 24 Oct 2006 17:45:41 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Movie: C/2006 M4 (SWAN)
Upon close inspection of a single subframe of my comet image from
Oct 15 I noted a galaxy or two. I aligned the images on the stars
and lo and behold, out popped a bunch of 14 to 17 mag galaxies!

I also made a small movie illustrating the very rapid (5.1 arc
seconds per minute) motion of the comet for 60 minutes.

Images and supporting data at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Rolando 

Date:  Tue, 24 Oct 2006 20:25:05 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Re: C/2006 M4 - 10/23/2006 - 3xMosaic
Thanks Rolando. Good to hear from you as I have not done so in a while.
I like the 127is. My problem is that after upgrading to the new 5"
refractor and also going to the losmandy G11 to better hold it, I spent
my money and was unable to get a new camera. The SBIG ST2000XM is old
and after the Maxcam10, which was "blowed up" I am hard to please. The
camera has been a really good one and one I can always depend on but
the 3200 chip is just a big leap ahead and would have made a really
good match for the new scope. I have a Focal Reducer on order which
will bring the 127is down from a 660mm to a 530mm which will image at
F4.2 The FSQ which I lost was a 530mm working at F5.3 so I am gaining
alot in speed. I am looking for a used camera if anyone knows of any.
Hope to see more of your images soon!
Thanks, Mike

Date:  Tue, 24 Oct 2006 22:51:33 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 M4 - 10/23/2006-1x1 Bin
Hello. I processed 30 images which are Bin 1x1. I was or thought I
was seeing some streamers north from the core area on the 20th. The
comet has now improved this area into a ---something---I don't know
what to call it? It shows well and I guess is dust and can be the
start for the recent brightning as it was much brighter when these
images were taken over the 20th images. I couldn't really tell the
tail was any brighter.
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/C87B4B4BB03005D/orig.jpg 

Date:  Wed, 25 Oct 2006 11:44:17 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Inner coma structures of C/2006 M4 (SWAN)
Hi all,
we have processed an image obtained last night by our fellow observer, Fabrizio Montanucci (Rome, Italy). It appears that the inner coma of this comet is showing a remarkable evolution, probably related to its recent outburst.

The visibility of several jets is strengthened (one obvious feature points toward SE). The central condensation show a very odd -"peanut-like"- shape.

An image is available here:
http://tinyurl.com/yjef87

Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero and Ernesto Guido (Remanzacco Obs., CARA)
http://www.famweb.com
http://cara.uai.it

------------------------------------------------------
Vinci un TomTom One! Fai subito un preventivo gratuito con Genialloyd e puoi vincere un fantastico TomTom One!
http://click.libero.it/genialloyd25ott

From:  Danilo Pivato 
Subject:  Comet C/2006 M4 (SWAN)
Hi all,

here's available a new shot of the comet SWAN M4
The instrument is
Refractor APO 400/4, unfiltered + ccd Sbig ST-10XME
Exposure 20x30 seconds
http://xoomer.alice.it/danilo_pivato
Clear Skies

Danilo Pivato

Images here : http://webs.ono.com/jpab

Regards , J.P.Navarro Pina .

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 26 Oct 2006 01:33:07 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Evolution of C/2006 M4 (Swan)
Hi all,
we imaged again C/2006 M4 (SWAN) with the same instrumentation we used yesterday night: it appears that during this last 24h, its inner coma has changed again: now the central condensation appears less structured (just an E-W elongation, no "peanut-shape" features), while the jet toward SE we commented yesterday (that's probably the same stuff mentioned by Rolando) has decreased its strenght.
Our image is available here:
http://tinyurl.com/tg6yc

The image obtained by a friend of us (Silvano Casulli) show a very structured ion tail:
http://tinyurl.com/y7wye9

Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero, Fabrizio Montanucci and Ernesto Guido

Date:  Sat, 28 Oct 2006 12:59:35 +0200
From:  Klaas Jobse 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] P/2006 T1 (Levy) passing NGC 3521
Hi Peter,

Very nice images!

After imaging C/2006 L1 (Garradd ) :

http://www.klaas-jobse.net/cyclops/kometen/20061027_0400UT_L1_11x45sweb.jpg

I tried to catch P/2006 T1 (Levy ) but could not find in on my first images!

I wondered because Guide 8 positioned the Comet next to NGC 3521, but it was not there at all.

I searched the area but no sign of T1.

Then I realized that I had not updated the ephemerid's in Guide for two weeks and at the same moment I saw T1 slowly crawling from under NGC 3521!

Unfortunately the observations where hampered by passing clouds, bad seeing and low altitude, nevertheless I am pleased with my images after all.

http://www.klaas-jobse.net/cyclops/kometen/20061027_T1andNGC3521_web1.jpg

Best regards

Klaas

I've added a couple of stacks of P/2006 T1 passing 9th mag galaxy NGC
3521 in Leo, the first guided on the comet and below that, guided on
the galaxy here:

http://www.birtwhistle.org/GalleryC2006T1.htm#2006-Oct-27

Peter
J95

Date:  Sat, 28 Oct 2006 16:06:45 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  Just what are these?
I waited last night for the edge of the clouds to pass after a strong
cold front passed. It was windy with 35mph northwinds and still some
thin clouds but I put some information on the chip.
In the past I have seen dark streaks behind comets. I figured they
were boundry lines between outgasing activity. The images last night
show this but if this was boundry lines it would follow the dust or gas
boundry. These are perfectly straight if you combine images. Not so
straight with one image. These almost look like shadows. Very strong
in nature. I have put muptible images on one picture and labeled
them. It occured this might be noise but they are always there. 4
images are reduced in size and the bottom one is at full size but
croped with a bin of 1x1. Anyone know what the dark streaks are. This
has probable been discussed before but I don't remember it.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/9A059D918CA4244/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sat, 28 Oct 2006 17:57:55 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  M4 - 2x-10/28/2006
Big wind, little camera.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/EAC0F395ECC55F0/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/EAC0F395ECC55F0/orig.jpg

Date:  Sun, 29 Oct 2006 15:36:31 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  OBS VIS: Faye, Garrard, (Levy)
Hi all,

I visually observed and photographed the following comets on Friday...

CometObs - ( http://groups.yahoo.com/group/CometObs/ )

4P (Faye)
2006 October 27.61 UT: m1 = 9.9, Dia.= 2'.5, DC = 6, Tail: 4' in PA 260 deg...41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [4P easy to see in 16". Appears as a tight, condensed nucleus surrounded by a diffuse coma. I can just see a slight tail extended to the west for about 4'. 40˚ alt in the NNW (Cetus). Stellar LM = 15.8 near comet (scope), dark rural sky].

C/2006 L1 (Garradd)
2006 October 27.68 UT: m1 = 10.0, Dia.= 3'.5, DC = 2, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Garradd low in east just prior to twilight. Fairly easy to see. Very diffuse coma with very slight central condensation. No tail seen. 17˚ alt in the ENE (Sextans). Stellar LM = 15.0 near comet (scope), dark rural sky].

Charles Morris's, 'The New Comet Observations Page' ( http://cometobservation.com/ )

4P (Faye)
2006 Oct. 27.61 UT: m1=9.9, Dia.=2'.5, DC=6/9, Tail: 4' in PA 260 deg...41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [4P easy to see in 16". Appears as a tight, condensed nucleus surrounded by a diffuse coma. I can just see a slight tail extended to the west for about 4'. 40˚ alt in the NNW (Cetus). Stellar LM = 15.8 near comet (scope), dark rural sky].

C/2006 L1 (Garradd)
2006 Oct. 27.68 UT: m1=10.0, Dia.=3'.5, DC=2/9, 41cm f4.5 Reflect (59x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Garradd low in east just prior to twilight. Fairly easy to see. Very diffuse coma with very slight central condensation. No tail seen. 17˚ alt in the ENE (Sextans). Stellar LM = 15.0 near comet (scope), dark rural sky].

ICQ (International Comet Quarterly) ( http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/icq/CometMags.html )

4P (Faye)
Oct. 27.61, 9.9, 2'.5, (John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand, 16"L, 59x)

C/2006 L1 (Garradd)
Oct. 27.68 10.0, 3'.5, (John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand, 16"L, 59x)

Images of these comets plus Comet Levy (C/2006 T1) can be seen at (note: scope = 16" f4.5 Newt; camera: Canon 10D; FOV: ~40' x 25'...

Faye:
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet-meteor-rasnz/assets/comet-004p-faye-41cm_f4,5-17x3min@800asa-061027-mag10-john_drummond-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/ym5t7x

Garradd:
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet-meteor-rasnz/assets/comet-2006l1-garradd-41cm_f4,5-7x3min@800asa-061027-mag10-john_drummond-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/yn223y

Levy (plus galaxy NGC 3521. Note, T1 is the very faint smudge on the right. Only 4 x 1 minute exposures in early twilight sky):
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet-meteor-rasnz/assets/comet-2006t1-levy-41cm_f4,5-4x1min@800asa-061027-john_drummond-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/yfzyk9

Cheers

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

Date:  Sun, 29 Oct 2006 10:32:29 +0100
From:  "gianluca@bellatrixobservatory.org" 
Subject:  C/2006 M4 (SWAN)
Dear All,

I'm pleased to introduce some images of this comet, as well
as movies. The page is in Italian (working on the english
page very soon), and the images and movies are at its
bottom.

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/galleria.html

Good comets,
Gianluca

Date:  Sun, 29 Oct 2006 15:35:43 +0100
From:  Toni Scarmato 
Subject:  images c2006m4
Dear all,

finally I am subscribed at this list.

I Have posted some images of the comet C/2006 M4 (SWAN) at the following address
http://digilander.libero.it/infosis/homepage/astronomia/c2006m4.htm

It si possibile to note the strong evolution of the ions tail since 2006 10 18, before the outburst to 2006 10 27after the strong outburst.

Regards,
Toni Scarmato

P.S. Need dsl connection due to the high resolution of the images.

Date:  Sun, 29 Oct 2006 14:57:13 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 M4 - 10/29/2006
Hello. Image from last night. Most information is on the image.
http://www.fototime.com/15B8B40723EE509/orig.jpg
The next link is a little more in the way of looking for a possible
result of the recent outburst. Actually the same image as above but
processed a little different. The 5" at this time shows no parts that
stand out although I was seeing what I thought were more than 1 bright
area which is about all I would expect of my equiptment. False color
added to ease the eye.
http://www.fototime.com/477C00C1EB61B44/orig.jpg
Thanks, Mike H. 

Date:  Sun, 29 Oct 2006 15:26:16 -0000

appearing to orbit the head. Need sleep!
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/609229AD693A697/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 29 Oct 2006 16:49:03 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  P/2006 HR30 - 10/29/2006-Need a little help
A 5" is ok for faint comets as long as they look like comets. The
image posted has the info on it. My problem is according to Guide I
have the comet but I don't know which spot it is. If someone imaged it
last night or can point it out I would appreciate it. The two lines
point to where it is suppost to be - about.
File is over 500kb and left full size although reduced in quality.
Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/3285B67117577A2/orig.jpg

minutes..

Philippe HAAKE

Date:  Sun, 29 Oct 2006 18:46:11 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 M4 - 7xMosaic - 10/29/2005
Greetings once again. This one is or was a big image. It covers 5' of
comet. The small galaxy at the end of the tail is NGC 6255 at
magnitude 13.5. Took 7 different images stiched in photoshp to show.
Original is almost 4000 pix wide. The original shows very good tail
structure with all kinds of kinks, waves and some strange sudden
stops. If you look at #2 and #3 from right to left on the top side of
the tail you can see the sudden stops I talk about. Almost as if they
came out in cycles. Anyway this is a big image still at 1600 pix wide
but any less and you loose what is there. 500 kb with the original at
25+mb. You have gotta love this comet!
Thanks, Mike H.

http://www.fototime.com/3CA3A8D3E5FA7E7/standard.jpg

http://www.fototime.com/3CA3A8D3E5FA7E7/orig.jpg 

Date:  Sun, 29 Oct 2006 19:54:51 +0100

Date:  Mon, 30 Oct 2006 15:32:49 +0100
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] swan october 29
> Is there a hint of a developing dust tail in the coma region? I
> assume the vertical grey band in the coma is not processing artefacts.

We imaged C/2006 M4 (SWAN) almost simultaneously with Michael and Rerald, using a narrowband filter centered @ 647nm (FWHM= 10nm): what is seen in our picture is virtually pure dust:
http://tinyurl.com/yjsed5

The dust tail stretch vertically (toward north) the frame.
Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero and Ernesto guido

------------------------------------------------------
Mutui a tassi scontati da 30 banche. Richiedi online e risparmia...Servizio gratuito. www.mutuionline.it
http://click.libero.it/mutuionline30ott 

Date:  Mon, 30 Oct 2006 15:35:36 -0000
From:  Maik Meyer 
Subject:  Re: P/2006 HR30 - 10/29/2006-Need a little help
Hi Mike,

> A 5" is ok for faint comets as long as they look like comets. The
> image posted has the info on it. My problem is according to Guide I
> have the comet but I don't know which spot it is. If someone imaged it
> last night or can point it out I would appreciate it. The two lines
> point to where it is suppost to be - about.
> File is over 500kb and left full size although reduced in quality.
> Mike H.
>
> http://www.fototime.com/3285B67117577A2/orig.jpg

The comet is not inside the FOV. When using the latest orbital
elements then the comet about 30' is below the lower edge of the FOV
for Oct. 29, 04:00 UT.

Cheers, Maik 

Date:  Mon, 30 Oct 2006 17:53:14 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  SWAN: DSLR vs. Astrograph/Cooled CCD
I imaged C/2006 M4 SWAN with my Canon 20D and EF 75-300 mm lens at
f/8 and my E-160 f/3.3 6-inch astrograph with SXV-H9 for similar
times. I was quite surprised at the results! The DSLR subs were 19
x 2 minutes while the cooled CCD's were 19 x 1 minute  but the
cooled CCD was binned 2x2.

I used simple JPGs rather than RAWs with the DSLR so my imaging
technique is not optimal. I haven't figured out how to use the Canon
software to download RAWs yet.

Images and simulated refractor and binocular eyepiece views at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

New Images http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Really appreciate your help.
Mike H.

Date:  Mon, 30 Oct 2006 21:34:35 -0000
From:  Bill 
Subject:  C/2006 M4 (SWAN)
Hi all,

My first post to this group, I've been a member for some time and
enjoyed all the images posted.

I wanted to share some images I've taken of SWAN using a Scotch mount,
or Barn Door Tracker, with my Nikon D70 and a 75-300mm telephoto lens.

Image taken on October 13th.
http://web.ics.purdue.edu/~wlsnyder/c2006m4swan1.htm

Image taken on October 29th
http://web.ics.purdue.edu/~wlsnyder/c2006m4swan2.htm

Enjoy and Clear Skies!
Bill

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/michael%20jaeger/2006m420061026neu.jpg

Date:  Mon, 30 Oct 2006 21:44:36 -0500
From:  Charlie Trump 
Subject:  C/2006 M4 (SWAN)
Hi All

I have been a member for a couple of months and have not posted to the
group before. I have been seeing
all these great images of Swan 2006 M4 and other comets everyone is
getting, so I thought I would try one. I took a
mosaic image last night and just finished trying to process it, not as
good as most here produce but I am trying to learn.
All of the information about it is below the image, if you would like to
see my version here is a link.
http://www.ct-computerservice.com/comet_swan_m4.htm

If you would like to see some of my other comet images follow the link
on top of the Swan image page.

Thanks for looking and comments are welcomed.
C T 

Date:  Mon, 30 Oct 2006 21:03:44 -0600
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2006 M4 (SWAN)
Hello and wow Charlie...that is actually quite an incredibly good image and an excellent
job at the mosaic. Beautiful star images and your processing is excellent.

Dr. Clay
-------------
Arkansas Sky Observatories
Harvard MPC/ H43 (Conway)
Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Tue, 31 Oct 2006 14:50:34 -0000
From:  Dave Kodama 
Subject:  Comet Swan and M13 (10/28)
The moon was bright enough on this evening that visually I could not
see much of a tail. This photo was greatly contrast enhanced to show
the tail:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2006/1028a/

Dave Kodama

Date:  Sat, 04 Nov 2006 20:43:33 +0100

A small error in the text: the second jet is at PA=180, not 18.

Best regards,
Ralf
-----
Sent: Saturday, November 04, 2006 8:42 PM
Subject: jets M4 SWAN like a spider

subject: jets C/2006 M4 SWAN 2006/10/30

An impressive view of jets in this Rotation gradient image from
Oct 30, with jets on ever side: PA=90, PA=18, PA=270 and the brightest Ion-tail streamer
at PA=0.The negative presentation shows a view like a spider.

http://img441.imageshack.us/img441/6784/m4swan20061030setwz1.jpg

Best regards,
Ralf Vandebergh

Date:  Mon, 06 Nov 2006 16:27:57 -0000
From:  jonesgerainth 
Subject:  Re: Just what are these?
Mike - Yes, very curious features. These dark lanes in the ion tail
are due to structures in the solar wind, rather than due to changes in
the comet's activity.

The wind carries the Sun's magnetic field outwards past the comet, and
this magnetic field varies in direction. When the wind approaches a
comet, it gets slowed down because of the ions that are added to the
flow. The amount of decrease in solar wind speeds depends on the
flow's distance from the centre of the comet: wind that passes closest
to the nucleus is slowed down the most. So, a solar wind
feature/boundary like a change in magnetic field direction is
stretched out in the shape of a hairpin, or in 3D, like a cone.

The motion of small-scale solar wind structures through the comet
usually shows up as bright tail rays, as are obvious in many images of
comet SWAN. However, it looks like you've caught a rarer and
particularly sharp example of the magnetic field causing a decrease in
ion numbers along the line of sight. Although people who work on this
are agreed that it's solar wind structures that cause such features,
the exact details of what's going on is open to debate.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Holloway"
wrote:
>
> In the past I have seen dark streaks behind comets. I figured they
> were boundry lines between outgasing activity. The images last night
> show this but if this was boundry lines it would follow the dust or gas
> boundry. These are perfectly straight if you combine images. Not so
> straight with one image. These almost look like shadows. Very strong
> in nature.

magnitude. All the brighter stars around the comet are 13+ to 15+
magnitude. Knowing this I don't know how dim the faint stars are.
How long do you plan to be able to image this comet?
Mike H.

Date:  Thu, 09 Nov 2006 23:04:54 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 M4 - 11/09/2006
Hello. I tried everything I could think of to show more than I have in
these images. It is condensed into 1 single image at the link.

http://www.fototime.com/36FCC1DB8803132/orig.jpg

I have 1x1 bin, 2x2 bin, sharp, inverted, enlarged, reduced, wide field
and LR resampled that I can remember. I did everything but show a
picture of my kitchen sink and it just wouldn't produce last night.
Only the dust to the North (up) and a couple of thin streaks where the
ion tail is. Maybe it will turn on just a little before it tracks far
away.
Thanks, Mike H.

Thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Fri, 17 Nov 2006 06:50:17 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  4P - 11/17/2006
This comet has had me fooled. I thought that the tail was towards the
E and a little north of East. Images showed what looked to be the
tailand I had not checked my locations. This image shows the correct
orentation listed. Kind of reminds me of 2005 E2 and that wierd tail
that always pointed to the Sun.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/7F88C8670743BDF/orig.jpg

Date:  Mon, 20 Nov 2006 02:20:24 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 M4 - 11/20/2006
Hello. I found this comet on another pretty clear night. Only used
one 30 second image. It is interesting because of the position. It is
entering the Dark nebula LDN 678 (209) in Aquila. To the W or right is
a very busy star field and E is the nebula. I left this, after
croping, at a little over 1600 pix wide with the 1x1 bin.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/ADD71583C6BAE27/orig.jpg

http://hometown.aol.com/tricks46/myhomepage/photo.html?mtbrand=AOL_US

Date:  Wed, 22 Nov 2006 17:57:00 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  181P (P/Shoemaker-Levy) very faint
Hi all,

just to add my 2 cents re the 181P puzzle, last night I imaged comet 181P. I took 30 x 4 minute exposures @ 800iso with my 16" f4.5 scope and 10D DSLR camera from a dark rural site (the FOV is about 40' x 25'). I took the images on November 21.35-50 UT. It appears to be VERY faint. I could hardly see it on the 4 minute subframes.

Based on the images (and the best subframe image I had), I roughly estimate the m1 magnitude to be 15 - 16ish. Based on previous experience of visually observing and then imaging comets, I would say this object is definitely not visually detectable with my 16" scope (note that I couldn't detect it on November 9th - my LM was mag 15.7 (~14 for comets))...

The stack of 30 x 4minute (2 hours total) can be seen at:

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_181p-shoemaker-levy-20061121-41cm-f4,5-30x4min@800asa-web-john_drummond.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/yascj2

A single cropped subframe (1 x 4 minute, Nov 21.39 UT) can be seen at (note, the comet can hardly be seen):

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_181p-shoemaker-levy-20061121-41cm-f4,5-1x4min@800asa-web-john_drummond.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/ydkzjy

Cheers.

John Drummond
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 178* 03', S 38* 40'
email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Comet 4P/Faye November 24, 2006 0407UT
Comet 4P/Faye November 24, 2006 0407UT

http://bellsouthpwp2.net/c/h/charbell/4P-11242006-0407UT.jpg

5 x 120 sec binned 2x2 (no color)
Stacked with Astrometrica Track and Stack
Log stretched with FITS Liberator and Photoshop CS2
Image Scale: 1.5 arcsec/pixel 800 x 600 binned pixels
Telescope: 12 inch Meade 200LX-GPS
Camera: SBIG ST-2000XCM + AO7

Date:  Mon, 27 Nov 2006 15:04:26 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Comet P/2006 U1 (LINEAR) November 26, 2006 0656UT
Comet P/2006 U1 (LINEAR) November 26, 2006 0656UT

http://bellsouthpwp2.net/c/h/charbell/P2006U1-11262006-0656UT.jpg

14 x 120 sec binned 2x2 (no color)
Stacked with Astrometrica Track and Stack
Log stretched with FITS Liberator and Photoshop CS2
Image Scale: 1.5 arcsec/pixel 800 x 600 binned pixels
Telescope: 12 inch Meade 200LX-GPS
Camera: SBIG ST-2000XCM
Adative Optics: SBIG AO7 unit

This is the most unusual and one of the faintest comets I have been
able to image. I was surprised to see the westward pointing tail in
all of my sub exposures. Its as if the tail is brighter than the
head. 

Date:  Tue, 28 Nov 2006 02:46:28 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet P/2006 U1 (LINEAR) November 26, 2006 0656UT
In response, I've just posted an image of this comet I took on Oct 21, in poor
seeing. See:

http://www.igomoo.com/aaa/index.php?option=com_rsgallery2&Itemid=26&page=inline&id=121&catid=29&limitstart=3

Image taken with 14" Meade, stack of 8 x 90s exposures. Image is 10 x 14 arc
mins. Tail is a good 7 arcmins long in PA 290.

Comet structure looks quite similar - although the tail seems broader in the
Oct image

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

Telescope: 12 inch Meade 200LX-GPS
Camera: SBIG ST-2000XCM
Adative Optics: SBIG AO7 unit

This is the most unusual and one of the faintest comets I have been
able to image. I was surprised to see the westward pointing tail in
all of my sub exposures. Its as if the tail is brighter than the
head.

Date:  Wed, 29 Nov 2006 17:57:40 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: Comet P/2006 U1 (LINEAR) November 26, 2006 0656UT
On October 26, 2006 the phase was about 60 degrees according to
http://scully.harvard.edu/~cgi/MPEph2.COM

and was around 4 degrees on November 26, 2006

Reaches minimum around November 30, 2006 or December 1, 2006

Date:  Sat, 02 Dec 2006 03:34:50 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 - 12022006
Hello. Image is 10x10 sec exp. Croped, inverted and enlarged 2x.
Gradients were exteme with the low elevation and time.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/5F1F8BDBDD9BF3B/orig.jpg

Date:  Thu, 07 Dec 2006 17:56:14 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 - 12/07/2006
Hello.
Digging through the dirt to shoot below the horizion. This is not what
I had in mind for a nice picture. I don't know what to say except it
appeared brighter to me. I was seeing string like filaments to the N/E
with extreem processing which is not shown here. It had a fuzzier
appearence as compaired to a starlike, what ever that is, but I don't
think all was related to atmosphere. Hope the tail starts to grow
pretty soon because if it were not for the Winter type of weather this
kind of imaging would not be possible and may not last.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/4842C4606C9142B/orig.jpg 

Date:  Thu, 07 Dec 2006 19:13:22 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 M4 - 12/07/2006
Hello. The comet is far enough away now to be able to stack on the
stars for a few minutes. Better get this one while you can.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/70800E5308B0121/orig.jpg

Date:  Fri, 08 Dec 2006 03:14:57 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  2P-Encke Animation
Hello. This is a tough one. I am pretty sure I have the comet. This
animation is a two frame 24hr. space between. Each one is 12x30 sec
exp with a 2x2 Bin. There were so many flaws and pix that gave false
impression I often wondered whether to remove them. In this animation
just below the galaxy PGC70004 mag 15.4 there is a spot that moves
which I left. Like I said I can be incorrect but The charts put the
comet where it is in the images at the two dates of 12/07/2006 and
12/08/2006 with the 7th being the top arrow. Hope your screen will
show this very small 18 to 19 magnitude speck. (If I am correct)
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/AFE6EB1FA6967D9/orig.gif 

Date:  Sat, 09 Dec 2006 13:01:57 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 - 12/08/2006
Hello. I was forced to do things a little different tonight. That
sounds a little strange considering the time of day this image was
shot. I was unable to do a Bin of 2x2 and do an add combination. The
amount of information gathered was too great and washes out the image.
This is back to a 1x1 bin and 10 sec images with the add combination.
Because of this I don't know how much the comet has changed because of
the processing and imaging, but the tail to the N/E is there. I added
15x10 second images, croped, enlarged 3x original, removed a gradient
and adjusted the levels a small bit but not much. I understand that
some will think this is useless according to some private mails, but I
am not seeing an influx of pretty images right now. I hope to continue
to post images as I can and maybe the guys on the other half of this
crazy planet will pick up where we leave off.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/DCDEE069318BD4C/orig.jpg

Date:  Thu, 14 Dec 2006 00:45:14 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 P1 - 12/12/2006
Hello. Here is the latest attempt to follow the comet. Clouds in the
distance gathered Sunlight and over exposed the 10 second images so I
cut them down to 6 seconds each. Arrows point to stars but actually I
was having a problem figuring out which ones they are. I had the
brightest at Mag 10.6 but it was the dimmer one in lower center. No
processing after Dark-flat and small level adj with a 12x1 bin and
imaged croped from original.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/3FF7D1C24253FDD/orig.jpg

Date:  Sat, 16 Dec 2006 23:47:45 -0000
From:  Piotr Guzik 
Subject:  Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images
Michael,

I just tried to identify the stars at the image. I guess left one is
HD 163405 (VTmag = 9.06 mag) and right is HD 162796 (VTmag = 7.97
mag). I can see that the comet is much brighter than both of these - I
think it is definitely brighter than 7 mag (and that's only central
condenstaion...)

Best Regards
Piotr Guzik

Date:  Mon, 18 Dec 2006 10:54:44 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  7 comets from UK on Dec 16th
Dear Group,

I imaged 7 comets from the UK on December 16th,
namely 2P, 4P, 29P, 76P, 2006 HR30, 2006 L1 and
2006 M4. All the images can be found on my comet
page at:
http://uk.geocities.com/martinmobberley/Comets.html

All with a Celestron 14 at f/7.7 + SBIG ST9XE CCD.

Regards,
Martin Mobberley 

Date:  Tue, 19 Dec 2006 22:11:35 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  4P Faye December 19, 2006 0304UT
4P Faye December 19, 2006 0304UT

http://bellsouthpwp2.net/c/h/charbell/4P-12192006-0304UT.jpg

Telescope: 12 inch Meade 200LX-GPS at f/6.3

CCD: ST-2000XCM + AO-7
10 x 120 sec L channels stacked with Astrometrica Stack and Track
Log stretched with FITS Liberator, inverted and adjusted with Levels
and Curves in PhotoshopCS2.

Time Stamp: 2006 12 19, 3:03:34 UT
Motion: 0.64"/min in PA 76.0°
Astrometry:
0004P C2006 12 19.12748 02 31 09.84 +02 24 37.3 13.7
N H47

to the WSW.

http://bellsouthpwp2.net/c/h/charbell/76P-12172006-0704UT.jpg
