Date:  Wed, 20 Dec 2006 12:22:35 +0100
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Faint fan tail 76P/West-Kohoutek-Ikemura December 17, 2006 0704UT
> 76P/West-Kohoutek-Ikemura December 17, 2006 0704UT
>
> Shows faint fan shaped tail at PA 260 extending a couple of arc minutes
> to the WSW.

Hi Charles,
prompted by your note, we imaged this comet from the Remanzacco Obs.:
http://tinyurl.com/y8x7lv

In our picture there is evidence of a narrow tail (possibly an ion tail?!) toward South-West.
Cheers,
Giovanni and Ernesto

Date:  Sat, 23 Dec 2006 23:36:12 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  For The Season!
Hello.
In a time of quick communication and really not knowing much about the
person on a personal basis, I have in the past learned that
communication is at best difficult, at least for me. Lack of language
and different meanings in cultures makes a lose bond difficult and a
permanent bond almost impossible to grasp. Comets have become the tie
that bonds. For the love of comets and in the spirit of the season I
want to wish all my friends at the Comet Images and the Comet Ml boards
all the best of luck in the new year and hope you and yours obtain your
goals whatever they may be.
Mike Holloway
Holloway Comet Observatory
Van buren AR
Owner Comet images board 

Date:  Sun, 24 Dec 2006 14:23:30 -0000
From:  Mike Holloway 
Subject:  C/2006 p1-12/22/2006
Can't get a clear sky.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/0D230749B7FE9E5/orig.jpg

Gerald

and different meanings in cultures makes a lose bond difficult and a

Date:  Wed, 27 Dec 2006 01:36:20 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  C/2002 L9 [Neat] - still active
I thought I would mention that this comet remains active, even though it is
9.4 AU from the sun (9.0 AU from the Earth) and over 2 1/2 years from
perihelion. I've just placed an image (stacked - 12 x 5 mins) at:
http://www.igomoo.com/aaa/index.php?option=com_rsgallery2&Itemid=26&page=inline&id=135&catid=29&limitstart=4

The image size is almost 5 arcmin square. The nucleus is quite diffuse, and
there is clear indication of a faint tail in PA 225 - of over 2 arc mins.

A previous series of images (in October) is at:
http://www.igomoo.com/aaa/index.php?option=com_rsgallery2&Itemid=26&page=inline&id=100&catid=29&limitstart=2

I think I'm the only one to have reported astrometry of this comet for over 12
months now. Given that it is still active at such a large distance, it is
perhaps disappointing that others are not observing this comet.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

Harvard MPC/ H41 (Petit Jean Mountain)
Harvard MPC/ H45 (Petit Jean Mtn. South)
http://www.arksky.org/

----- Original Message -----
From: "Mike Holloway"
To:
Sent: Tuesday, December 26, 2006 5:09 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images

> Michael. You nailed it good this time. Clouds were close I see.
> Each day at my location clouds roll in from the plains to the NW. I
> like the way astronomical cameras and high dollar telescopes are
> being used to take almost daylight images.
> Mike H.

Date:  Wed, 27 Dec 2006 01:26:38 +0100
From:  Juan Jose Gonzalez Suarez 
Subject:  Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images - C/2006 P1 (McNaught).
Very useful image, Michael. Thanks for sharing !

In my recent visual negative observation ( Dec. 21.74 UT: m1= [ 5.0, 25x100B, mountain
location, very clear sky; nautical twilight; alt. 3 deg ), I've used Zeta Scuti as one of the
references in the field, finishing the observing session when this star set behind a snowy
ridge. A beautiful view in the binoculars.

I'm glad to see now C/2006 P1 in good health, near Zeta Scuti ...

Clear skies,

J. J. Gonzalez

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Date:  Thu, 28 Dec 2006 12:03:12 +0100
From:  Juan Jose Gonzalez Suarez 
Subject:  Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images - C/2006 P1.
Splendid and detailed work, Michael ! McNaught's comet seems to be developing a nice tail.

[ The dim star SAO 142320 (9.7) is also visible in the image near C/2006 P1 ].

The previous night and this morning I also tried again to observe the comet with 25x100
binoculars from the Cantabrian Mountains in nautical twilight, but the atmospheric
conditions were not clear enough near the horizon. Coming back to home, It's good to see
your splendid image of the same field.

Good luck and clear skies in the next days,

J. J. Gonzalez

------------------------------------------------------------------------

some values of very interesting afrho.

Date:  Sat, 30 Dec 2006 23:23:44 +0100
From:  Bernd Brinkmann 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images - C/2006 P1.
Hello Michael,

> it is a broad dust tail >10'
> maybe piotr and other northern observers could see this tail next
> week.

Bernd Gaehrken from Munich reports (in a german CCD-mailing-list) a positive visual
sighting of a beginning tail with the 80 cm - telescope of the Volkssternwarte
Muenchen at 06:10 UT on 30.12.2006.

My own photographic attempt between 16:25 and 16:41 UT on 26.12.2006 with an EOS
10D and 105 mm f/2.8 telelens had no success (that was the only clear evening for
more than 2 weeks now).

Clear skies
Bernd

Bernd Brinkmann
Sternwarte Herne, MPC code A18

http://www.sternwarte-herne.de
info@sternwarte-herne.de
